sentences.zh: 周后稷，名棄。

translations.literal: Zhou's Hou Ji was named Qi.
translations.idiomatic: The Zhou dynasty's Hou Ji was named Qi.

sentences.zh: 其母有邰氏女，曰姜原。

translations.literal: His mother was a woman of the You Tai clan named Jiang Yuan.
translations.idiomatic: His mother was a woman of the Youtai clan named Jiang Yuan.

sentences.zh: 姜原為帝嚳元妃。

translations.literal: Jiang Yuan was Emperor Ku's primary consort.
translations.idiomatic: Jiang Yuan was Emperor Ku's chief consort.

sentences.zh: 姜原出野，見巨人跡，心忻然說，欲踐之，踐之而身動如孕者。

translations.literal: Jiang Yuan went into the wilds and saw a giant's footprint. Her heart was joyfully pleased, and she wished to tread upon it. When she trod upon it, her body moved as if she were pregnant.
translations.idiomatic: Jiang Yuan ventured into the wilderness and spied a giant's footprint. Her heart filled with delight, and she desired to step upon it. When she stepped on it, her body stirred as though with child.

sentences.zh: 居期而生子，以為不祥，棄之隘巷，馬牛過者皆辟不踐；

translations.literal: At term she gave birth to a son. Considering it inauspicious, she abandoned him in a narrow lane. Horses and oxen passing by all avoided him and did not tread upon him.
translations.idiomatic: When her time came, she bore a son. Deeming it an ill omen, she abandoned him in a narrow alley. Horses and cattle passing by all shied away and spared him their hooves.

sentences.zh: 徙置之林中，適會山林多人，遷之；

translations.literal: She moved him and placed him in the forest. It so happened that many woodcutters were there, and they moved him away.
translations.idiomatic: She carried him to the woods and left him there. As it happened, many woodcutters were in the forest and relocated him.

sentences.zh: 而棄渠中冰上，飛鳥以其翼覆薦之。

translations.literal: Then she abandoned him in a ditch upon the ice, but flying birds covered and warmed him with their wings.
translations.idiomatic: She abandoned him in a ditch atop the ice, but flying birds sheltered him and warmed him with their wings.

sentences.zh: 姜原以為神，遂收養長之。

translations.literal: Jiang Yuan considered it divine and took him in, raising and nurturing him.
translations.idiomatic: Jiang Yuan deemed this miraculous and took him home, raising him with care.

sentences.zh: 初欲棄之，因名曰棄。

translations.literal: Initially she had wished to abandon him, so she named him Qi.
translations.idiomatic: She had at first wanted to abandon him, so she named him Qi.

translations.literal: Zhou's Hou Ji was named Qi. His mother was a woman of the Youtai clan named Jiang Yuan. Jiang Yuan was the primary consort of Emperor Ku. Jiang Yuan went into the wilds and saw a giant's footprint. Her heart was joyfully pleased, and she wished to tread upon it. When she trod upon it, her body moved as if she were pregnant. When her term was complete, she gave birth to a son. Considering it inauspicious, she abandoned him in a narrow lane. Horses and oxen that passed by all avoided treading on him; She moved him into the forest, but just then many people from the mountains and forests happened to pass by and moved him; Then she abandoned him in a ditch on the ice, but flying birds covered and warmed him with their wings. Jiang Yuan considered it divine and took him in, raising and nurturing him. Initially she had wished to abandon him, so she named him Qi.

sentences.zh: 棄為兒時，屹如巨人之志。

translations.literal: When Qi was a child, he stood firm like a giant's resolve.
translations.idiomatic: As a boy, Qi stood as resolute as a giant's determination.

sentences.zh: 其游戲，好種樹麻、菽，麻、菽美。

translations.literal: In his play, he liked planting hemp and beans, and the hemp and beans grew beautifully.
translations.idiomatic: In his games, he loved sowing hemp and soybeans, and they flourished splendidly.

sentences.zh: 及為成人，遂好耕農，相地之宜，宜穀者稼穡焉，民皆法則之。

translations.literal: When he became an adult, he loved farming. He examined what the land was suitable for, planted and harvested where grain would grow well, and all the people followed and imitated him.
translations.idiomatic: Upon reaching adulthood, he grew fond of tilling the soil. He surveyed the terrain to see what suited it, sowed and reaped where grain would thrive, and all the people emulated his ways.

sentences.zh: 帝堯聞之，舉棄為農師，天下得其利，有功。

translations.literal: Emperor Yao heard of this and appointed Qi as the farming teacher. The realm benefited from him and he achieved merit.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Yao learned of this and made Qi the master of agriculture. The empire prospered from his efforts, and he earned great merit.

sentences.zh: 帝舜曰：「棄，黎民始饑，爾后稷播時百穀。」

translations.literal: Emperor Shun said: 'Qi, when the common people first went hungry, you, Hou Ji, sowed the seasons of the hundred grains.'
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Shun declared: 'Qi, when the black-haired people first knew famine, you, Lord of Millet, planted the seasons of the hundred grains.'

sentences.zh: 封棄於邰，號曰后稷，別姓姬氏。

translations.literal: He enfeoffed Qi at Tai, titled him Hou Ji, and established the separate surname Ji clan.
translations.idiomatic: He enfeoffed Qi at Tai, bestowed upon him the title Hou Ji, and created the separate surname of the Ji clan.

sentences.zh: 后稷之興，在陶唐﹑虞﹑夏之際，皆有令德。

translations.literal: Hou Ji's flourishing was during the time between Tao Tang, Yu, and Xia, and all had excellent virtue.
translations.idiomatic: Hou Ji rose to prominence in the transitional era between Tao Tang, Yu, and Xia, and all possessed admirable virtue.

translations.literal: When Qi was a child, he stood firm with the will of a giant. In his play, he liked planting hemp and beans, and the hemp and beans grew beautifully. When he became an adult, he loved farming. He examined what land was suitable, planted and harvested where grain would grow well, and all the people followed and imitated him. Emperor Yao heard of this and appointed Qi as the farming teacher. The realm benefited from him and he achieved merit. Emperor Shun said: 'Qi, when the common people first began to starve, you, Hou Ji, sowed the hundred grains in season.' He enfeoffed Qi at Tai, titled him Hou Ji, and established the separate surname of the Ji clan. Hou Ji's flourishing was during the time between Tao Tang, Yu, and Xia, and all had excellent virtue.

sentences.zh: 后稷卒，子不窋立。

translations.literal: Hou Ji died, and his son Bu Xu was established.
translations.idiomatic: Hou Ji passed away, and his son Bu Xu ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 不窋末年，夏后氏政衰，去稷不務，不窋以失其官而犇戎狄之間。

translations.literal: In Bu Xu's final years, the Xia Hou clan government declined. They departed from Ji's ways and were not diligent. Bu Xu lost his office and fled among the Rong and Di.
translations.idiomatic: In Bu Xu's later years, the Xia Hou clan's rule grew feeble. They abandoned Ji's teachings and grew neglectful. Bu Xu forfeited his position and fled among the Rong and Di peoples.

sentences.zh: 不窋卒，子鞠立。

translations.literal: Bu Xu died, and his son Ju was established.
translations.idiomatic: Bu Xu died, and his son Ju took his place.

sentences.zh: 鞠卒，子公劉立。

translations.literal: Ju died, and his son Gong Liu was established.
translations.idiomatic: Ju passed away, and his son Gong Liu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 公劉雖在戎狄之間，復修后稷之業，務耕種，行地宜，自漆、沮度渭，取材用，行者有資，居者有畜積，民賴其慶。

translations.literal: Although Gong Liu was among the Rong and Di, he again took up Hou Ji's undertakings, devoting himself to farming and planting. He acted according to what the land was suitable for, crossed the Wei from Qi and Ju, took materials for use. Travelers had provisions, residents had stores of goods, and the people relied on his blessings.
translations.idiomatic: Though Gong Liu dwelt among the Rong and Di barbarians, he revived Hou Ji's legacy, dedicating himself to agriculture and cultivation. He adapted to the land's nature, forded the Wei from Qi and Ju, gathered materials for use. Wayfarers found sustenance, settlers built reserves, and the people depended on his bounty.

sentences.zh: 百姓懷之，多徙而保歸焉。

translations.literal: The common people cherished him, and many moved to settle and find protection there.
translations.idiomatic: The people held him dear, and many migrated to seek refuge under his protection.

sentences.zh: 周道之興自此始，故詩人歌樂思其德。

translations.literal: The flourishing of the Zhou way began from this time. Therefore poets sang joyfully and thought of their virtue.
translations.idiomatic: The rise of the Zhou way began here. Thus poets composed songs celebrating and pondering their virtue.

sentences.zh: 公劉卒，子慶節立，國於豳。

translations.literal: Gong Liu died, and his son Qing Jie was established. Their state was at Bin.
translations.idiomatic: Gong Liu died, and his son Qing Jie took the throne. Their realm was established at Bin.

translations.literal: Hou Ji died, and his son Bu Xu was established. In Bu Xu's final years, the Xia Hou clan government declined. They departed from Ji's ways and were not diligent. Bu Xu lost his office and fled among the Rong and Di. Bu Xu died, and his son Ju was established. Ju died, and his son Gong Liu was established. Although Gong Liu was among the Rong and Di, he again took up Hou Ji's undertakings, devoting himself to farming and planting. He acted according to what the land was suitable for, crossed the Wei from Qi and Ju, took materials for use. Travelers had provisions, residents had stores of goods, and the people relied on his blessings. The common people cherished him, and many moved to settle and find protection there. The flourishing of the Zhou way began from this time. Therefore poets sang joyfully and thought of their virtue. Gong Liu died, and his son Qing Jie was established. Their state was at Bin.

sentences.zh: 慶節卒，子皇仆立。

translations.literal: Qing Jie died, and his son Huang Pu was established.
translations.idiomatic: Qing Jie died, and his son Huang Pu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 皇仆卒，子差弗立。

translations.literal: Huang Pu died, and his son Cha Fu was established.
translations.idiomatic: Huang Pu passed away, and his son Cha Fu took the throne.

sentences.zh: 差弗卒，子毀隃立。

translations.literal: Cha Fu died, and his son Hui Yu was established.
translations.idiomatic: Cha Fu died, and his son Hui Yu ascended.

sentences.zh: 毀隃卒，子公非立。

translations.literal: Hui Yu died, and his son Gong Fei was established.
translations.idiomatic: Hui Yu passed on, and his son Gong Fei was enthroned.

sentences.zh: 公非卒，子高圉立。

translations.literal: Gong Fei died, and his son Gao Yu was established.
translations.idiomatic: Gong Fei died, and his son Gao Yu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 高圉卒，子亞圉立。

translations.literal: Gao Yu died, and his son Ya Yu was established.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Yu died, and his son Ya Yu took his place.

sentences.zh: 亞圉卒，子公叔祖類立。

translations.literal: Ya Yu died, and his son Gong Shu Zu Lei was established.
translations.idiomatic: Ya Yu passed away, and his son Gong Shu Zu Lei ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 公叔祖類卒，子古公亶父立。

translations.literal: Gong Shu Zu Lei died, and his son Gu Gong Dan Fu was established.
translations.idiomatic: Gong Shu Zu Lei died, and his son Gu Gong Dan Fu was established.

sentences.zh: 古公亶父復修后稷、公劉之業，積德行義，國人皆戴之。

translations.literal: Gu Gong Dan Fu again took up Hou Ji and Gong Liu's undertakings, accumulated virtue and practiced righteousness. All the people of the state supported him.
translations.idiomatic: Gu Gong Dan Fu revived the legacies of Hou Ji and Gong Liu, amassing virtue and practicing benevolence. All the people of the realm revered him.

sentences.zh: 薰育戎狄攻之，欲得財物，予之。

translations.literal: The Xun Yu Rong Di attacked him, desiring to obtain wealth and goods. He gave them what they wanted.
translations.idiomatic: The Xunyu Rongdi attacked him, coveting wealth and possessions. He granted them their desires.

sentences.zh: 已復攻，欲得地與民。

translations.literal: They attacked again, desiring to obtain land and people.
translations.idiomatic: They attacked once more, seeking to seize land and subjects.

sentences.zh: 民皆怒，欲戰。

translations.literal: All the people were angry and wished to fight.
translations.idiomatic: All the people were furious and yearned to battle.

sentences.zh: 古公曰：「有民立君，將以利之。

translations.literal: Gu Gong said: 'When people establish a ruler, it is to benefit them.
translations.idiomatic: Gu Gong declared: 'When subjects raise up a lord, it is for their welfare.

sentences.zh: 今戎狄所為攻戰，以吾地與民。

translations.literal: Now the Rong Di attack and fight for my land and people.
translations.idiomatic: Now the Rongdi wage war to claim my territory and subjects.

sentences.zh: 民之在我，與其在彼，何異。

translations.literal: The people being with me or with them—what difference does it make?
translations.idiomatic: Whether the people belong to me or to them—what difference is there?

sentences.zh: 民欲以我故戰，殺人父子而君之，予不忍為。」

translations.literal: If the people wish to fight on my account, killing fathers and sons to make me their ruler, I cannot bear to do this.'
translations.idiomatic: If my people fight for my sake, slaying fathers and sons to enthrone me, I cannot bring myself to allow it.'

sentences.zh: 乃與私屬遂去豳，度漆、沮，踰梁山，止於岐下。

translations.literal: Then, accompanied by his private retainers, he left Bin, crossed the Qi and Ju rivers, climbed Liang Mountain, and stopped at the foot of Mount Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Then, with his personal retinue, he departed Bin, forded the Qi and Ju rivers, scaled Liang Mountain, and halted at the base of Mount Qi.

sentences.zh: 豳人舉國扶老攜弱，盡復歸古公於岐下。

translations.literal: The people of Bin, the whole state supporting the elderly and carrying the weak, all returned to Gu Gong at the foot of Mount Qi.
translations.idiomatic: The entire population of Bin, supporting the aged and bearing the young, all returned to Gu Gong at the foot of Mount Qi.

sentences.zh: 及他旁國聞古公仁，亦多歸之。

translations.literal: When other neighboring states heard of Gu Gong's benevolence, many also came to him.
translations.idiomatic: When neighboring states learned of Gu Gong's benevolence, many flocked to him as well.

sentences.zh: 於是古公乃貶戎狄之俗，而營筑城郭室屋，而邑別居之。

translations.literal: Thus Gu Gong abandoned the customs of the Rong and Di, built walled cities and houses, and settled the towns separately.
translations.idiomatic: Thus Gu Gong discarded the ways of the Rong and Di, constructed walled cities and dwellings, and organized the settlements with distinct quarters.

sentences.zh: 作五官有司。

translations.literal: He established the five officials with their directors.
translations.idiomatic: He instituted the five ministries with their overseers.

sentences.zh: 民皆歌樂之，頌其德。

translations.literal: All the people sang joyfully about him and praised his virtue.
translations.idiomatic: All the people sang praises of him and lauded his virtue.

translations.literal: Qing Jie died, and his son Huang Pu was established. Huang Pu died, and his son Cha Fu was established. Cha Fu died, and his son Hui Yu was established. Hui Yu died, and his son Gong Fei was established. Gong Fei died, and his son Gao Yu was established. Gao Yu died, and his son Ya Yu was established. Ya Yu died, and his son Gong Shu Zu Lei was established. Gong Shu Zu Lei died, and his son Gu Gong Dan Fu was established. Gu Gong Dan Fu again took up Hou Ji and Gong Liu's undertakings, accumulated virtue and practiced righteousness. All the people of the state supported him. The Xun Yu Rong Di attacked him, desiring to obtain wealth and goods. He gave them what they wanted. They attacked again, desiring to obtain land and people. All the people were angry and wished to fight. Gu Gong said: 'People establish a ruler to benefit them. Now the Rong Di attack and fight for my land and people. The people being with me or with them—what difference does it make? If the people wish to fight because of me, killing fathers and sons to make me their ruler—I cannot bear to do this.' Then, accompanied by his private retainers, he left Bin, crossed the Qi and Ju rivers, climbed Liang Mountain, and stopped at the foot of Mount Qi. The people of Bin, the whole state supporting the elderly and carrying the weak, all returned to Gu Gong at the foot of Mount Qi. When other neighboring states heard of Gu Gong's benevolence, many also came to him. Thus Gu Gong abandoned the customs of the Rong and Di, built walled cities and houses, and settled the towns separately. He established the five officials with their directors. All the people sang joyfully about him and praised his virtue.

sentences.zh: 古公有長子曰太伯，次曰虞仲。

translations.literal: Gu Gong had an eldest son named Tai Bo and a second son named Yu Zhong.
translations.idiomatic: Gu Gong had an eldest son named Tai Bo and a second named Yu Zhong.

sentences.zh: 太姜生少子季歷，季歷娶太任，皆賢婦人，生昌，有聖瑞。

translations.literal: Tai Jiang gave birth to the youngest son Ji Li. Ji Li married Tai Ren. Both were worthy women. They gave birth to Chang, who had sage omens.
translations.idiomatic: Tai Jiang bore the youngest son Ji Li. Ji Li wed Tai Ren. Both were exemplary women who gave birth to Chang, attended by auspicious signs.

sentences.zh: 古公曰：「我世當有興者，其在昌乎？」

translations.literal: Gu Gong said: 'My generation should have one who rises—perhaps it will be Chang?'
translations.idiomatic: Gu Gong declared: 'My line shall produce one who rises to greatness—perhaps it will be Chang?'

sentences.zh: 長子太伯、虞仲知古公欲立季歷以傳昌，乃二人亡如荊蠻，文身斷髪，以讓季歷。

translations.literal: The eldest son Tai Bo and Yu Zhong knew that Gu Gong wished to establish Ji Li to pass on to Chang. So the two fled to the Jing Man, tattooed their bodies and cut their hair, to yield to Ji Li.
translations.idiomatic: The eldest sons Tai Bo and Yu Zhong knew Gu Gong intended to establish Ji Li to transmit the succession to Chang. Thus the two fled to the Jing barbarians, tattooed their bodies and cropped their hair, yielding the throne to Ji Li.

translations.literal: Gu Gong had an eldest son named Tai Bo and a second son named Yu Zhong. Tai Jiang gave birth to the youngest son Ji Li. Ji Li married Tai Ren. Both were worthy women. They gave birth to Chang, who had sage omens. Gu Gong said: 'My generation should have one who rises—perhaps it will be Chang?' The eldest son Tai Bo and Yu Zhong knew that Gu Gong wished to establish Ji Li to pass on to Chang. So the two fled to the Jing Man, tattooed their bodies and cut their hair, to yield to Ji Li.

sentences.zh: 古公卒，季歷立，是為公季。

translations.literal: Gu Gong died, and Ji Li was established. He was called Gong Ji.
translations.idiomatic: Gu Gong passed away, and Ji Li succeeded him. He was known as Gong Ji.

sentences.zh: 公季修古公遺道，篤於行義，諸侯順之。

translations.literal: Gong Ji followed Gu Gong's remaining path, was devoted to practicing righteousness, and the feudal lords submitted to him.
translations.idiomatic: Gong Ji upheld Gu Gong's legacy, was steadfast in benevolence, and the lords submitted to him.

translations.literal: Gu Gong died, and Ji Li was established. He was called Gong Ji. Gong Ji followed Gu Gong's remaining path, was devoted to practicing righteousness, and the feudal lords submitted to him.

sentences.zh: 公季卒，子昌立，是為西伯。

translations.literal: Gong Ji died, and his son Chang was established. He was called the Western Lord.
translations.idiomatic: Gong Ji died, and his son Chang succeeded him. He was known as the Western Lord.

sentences.zh: 西伯曰文王，遵后稷、公劉之業，則古公、公季之法，篤仁，敬老，慈少。

translations.literal: The Western Lord was called King Wen. He followed Hou Ji and Gong Liu's undertakings, imitated Gu Gong and Gong Ji's methods, was devoted to benevolence, respected the elderly, and pitied the young.
translations.idiomatic: The Western Lord became known as King Wen. He honored Hou Ji and Gong Liu's legacies, followed Gu Gong and Gong Ji's examples, practiced steadfast benevolence, honored the aged, and showed compassion to the young.

sentences.zh: 禮下賢者，日中不暇食以待士，士以此多歸之。

translations.literal: He treated worthy people humbly. Even at noon he had no leisure to eat while waiting for scholars. Scholars therefore came to him in great numbers.
translations.idiomatic: He treated worthy men with humility. Even at midday he had no time to eat while awaiting scholars. Thus scholars came to him in great numbers.

sentences.zh: 伯夷、叔齊在孤竹，聞西伯善養老，盍往歸之。

translations.literal: Bo Yi and Shu Qi were in Guzhu. They heard that the Western Lord was good at nurturing the elderly. Why not go and join him?
translations.idiomatic: Bo Yi and Shu Qi dwelt in Guzhu. They heard the Western Lord excelled at caring for the elderly. Why not go and join him?

sentences.zh: 太顛、閎夭、散宜生、鬻子、辛甲大夫之徒皆往歸之。

translations.literal: Tai Dian, Hong Yao, San Yisheng, Yu Zi, and grandees like Xin Jia all went and joined him.
translations.idiomatic: Tai Dian, Hong Yao, San Yisheng, Yu Zi, and other nobles like Xin Jia all went to join him.

translations.literal: Gong Ji died, and his son Chang was established. He was called the Western Lord. The Western Lord was called King Wen. He followed Hou Ji and Gong Liu's undertakings, imitated Gu Gong and Gong Ji's methods, was devoted to benevolence, respected the elderly, and pitied the young. He treated worthy people humbly. Even at noon he had no leisure to eat while waiting for scholars. Scholars therefore came to him in great numbers. Bo Yi and Shu Qi were in Guzhu. They heard that the Western Lord was good at nurturing the elderly. Why not go and join him? Tai Dian, Hong Yao, San Yisheng, Yu Zi, and grandees like Xin Jia all went and joined him.

sentences.zh: 崇侯虎譖西伯於殷紂曰：「西伯積善累德，諸侯皆向之，將不利於帝。」

translations.literal: Chong Hou Hu slandered the Western Lord to Yin Zhou, saying: 'The Western Lord accumulates goodness and virtue. All the feudal lords turn toward him. This will be disadvantageous to the Emperor.'
translations.idiomatic: Chong Hou Hu slandered the Western Lord to Emperor Zhou, declaring: 'The Western Lord amasses virtue and benevolence. All the lords incline toward him. This bodes ill for Your Majesty.'

sentences.zh: 帝紂乃囚西伯於羑里。

translations.literal: Emperor Zhou then imprisoned the Western Lord at Youli.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Zhou then imprisoned the Western Lord at Youli.

sentences.zh: 閎夭之徒患之。

translations.literal: Hong Yao and his companions were worried about this.
translations.idiomatic: Hong Yao and his followers were greatly concerned.

sentences.zh: 乃求有莘氏美女，驪戎之文馬，有熊九駟，他奇怪物，因殷嬖臣費仲而獻之紂。

translations.literal: They sought a beautiful woman from the Youshen clan, patterned horses from the Li Rong, nine teams from You Xiong, and other strange treasures. Through the Yin favorite minister Fei Zhong, they presented them to Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: They procured a beauty from the Youshen clan, patterned horses from the Li Rong, nine chariot teams from You Xiong, and other wondrous treasures. Through the Yin court favorite Fei Zhong, they presented them to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 紂大說，曰：「此一物足以釋西伯，況其多乎！」

translations.literal: Zhou was greatly pleased and said: 'This one item is sufficient to release the Western Lord, let alone so many!'
translations.idiomatic: Zhou was delighted and exclaimed: 'Even one of these treasures would suffice to free the Western Lord, let alone so many!'

sentences.zh: 乃赦西伯，賜之弓矢斧鉞，使西伯得征伐。

translations.literal: Then he pardoned the Western Lord and granted him bows and arrows, axes and battle-axes, allowing the Western Lord to campaign.
translations.idiomatic: Thus he pardoned the Western Lord and bestowed upon him bows, arrows, axes, and battle-axes, granting him authority to wage war.

sentences.zh: 曰：「譖西伯者，崇侯虎也。」

translations.literal: He said: 'The one who slandered the Western Lord was Chong Hou Hu.'
translations.idiomatic: He declared: 'The slanderer of the Western Lord was Chong Hou Hu.'

sentences.zh: 西伯乃獻洛西之地，以請紂去炮格之刑。

translations.literal: The Western Lord then offered the lands west of the Luo River to request that Zhou remove the paoge punishments.
translations.idiomatic: The Western Lord then ceded the lands west of the Luo River to petition Zhou to abolish the paoge tortures.

sentences.zh: 紂許之。

translations.literal: Zhou permitted it.
translations.idiomatic: Zhou consented.

translations.literal: Chong Hou Hu slandered the Western Lord to Yin Zhou, saying: 'The Western Lord has accumulated goodness and piled up virtue. All the feudal lords turn to him. This will be disadvantageous to the Emperor.' Emperor Zhou then imprisoned the Western Lord at Youli. Hong Yao and his companions were worried about this. They sought a beautiful woman from the Youshen clan, patterned horses from the Li Rong, nine teams from You Xiong, and other strange treasures. Through the Yin favorite minister Fei Zhong, they presented them to Zhou. Zhou was greatly pleased and said: 'This one thing would be enough to release the Western Lord, let alone all these treasures!' Then he pardoned the Western Lord and granted him bows and arrows, axes and battle-axes, allowing the Western Lord to campaign. He said: 'The one who slandered the Western Lord was Chong Hou Hu.' The Western Lord then offered the lands west of the Luo River to request that Zhou remove the paoge punishments. Zhou permitted it.

sentences.zh: 西伯陰行善，諸侯皆來決平。

translations.literal: The Western Lord secretly practiced goodness, and all the feudal lords came to him for decisions and settlements.
translations.idiomatic: The Western Lord quietly practiced virtue, and all the lords came to him for judgments and arbitrations.

sentences.zh: 於是虞、芮之人有獄不能決，乃如周。

translations.literal: Thus when the people of Yu and Rui had a lawsuit they could not resolve, they went to Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: Thus when the people of Yu and Rui had a dispute they could not settle, they went to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 入界，耕者皆讓畔，民俗皆讓長。

translations.literal: Upon entering the boundary, farmers yielded their borders to each other, and the people's customs yielded to elders.
translations.idiomatic: Upon crossing the border, farmers yielded their field boundaries to one another, and the people deferred to their elders.

sentences.zh: 虞、芮之人未見西伯，皆慚，相謂曰：「吾所爭，周人所恥，何往為，秖取辱耳。」

translations.literal: The people of Yu and Rui, without yet seeing the Western Lord, all felt ashamed. They said to each other: 'What we dispute, Zhou people consider shameful. Why go there? We would only bring disgrace upon ourselves.'
translations.idiomatic: The people of Yu and Rui, before even meeting the Western Lord, were all ashamed. They said to one another: 'What we fight over, the Zhou people find disgraceful. Why go there? We would only humiliate ourselves.'

sentences.zh: 遂還，俱讓而去。

translations.literal: Then they returned, both sides yielding and departing.
translations.idiomatic: Then they returned home, both parties yielding to each other.

sentences.zh: 諸侯聞之，曰「西伯蓋受命之君」。

translations.literal: The feudal lords heard of this and said: 'The Western Lord is indeed the ruler who has received Heaven's mandate.'
translations.idiomatic: The lords heard of this and declared: 'The Western Lord is truly the ruler who has received the Mandate of Heaven.'

translations.literal: The Western Lord secretly practiced goodness, and all the feudal lords came to him for decisions and settlements. Thus when the people of Yu and Rui had a lawsuit they could not resolve, they went to Zhou. Upon entering the boundary, farmers yielded their borders to each other, and the people's customs yielded to elders. The people of Yu and Rui, without even seeing the Western Lord, were ashamed. They said to each other: 'What we disputed, the Zhou people consider shameful. Why should we go? We'd only bring humiliation upon ourselves.' Then they returned, both sides yielding and departing. The feudal lords heard of this and said: 'The Western Lord is probably the Heaven-mandated ruler.'

sentences.zh: 明年，伐犬戎。

translations.literal: The next year, he attacked the Quanrong.
translations.idiomatic: The following year, he campaigned against the Quanrong.

sentences.zh: 明年，伐密須。

translations.literal: The next year, he attacked Mixu.
translations.idiomatic: The next year, he attacked Mixu.

sentences.zh: 明年，敗耆國。

translations.literal: The next year, he defeated the state of Qi.
translations.idiomatic: The following year, he defeated the state of Qi.

sentences.zh: 殷之祖伊聞之，懼，以告帝紂。

translations.literal: Yin's Zu Yi heard of this and was afraid. He reported it to Emperor Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: Yin's ancestor Yi heard of this and grew fearful. He informed Emperor Zhou.

sentences.zh: 紂曰：「不有天命乎？

translations.literal: Zhou said: 'Is there not Heaven's mandate?
translations.idiomatic: Zhou replied: 'Is there not the Mandate of Heaven?

sentences.zh: 是何能為！」

translations.literal: What can he do!'
translations.idiomatic: What harm can he do!'

sentences.zh: 明年，伐邘。

translations.literal: The next year, he attacked Yu.
translations.idiomatic: The next year, he attacked Yu.

sentences.zh: 明年，伐崇侯虎。

translations.literal: The next year, he attacked Chong Hou Hu.
translations.idiomatic: The following year, he attacked Chong Hou Hu.

sentences.zh: 而作豐邑，自岐下而徙都豐。

translations.literal: Then he built the settlement of Feng and moved his capital from the foot of Mount Qi to Feng.
translations.idiomatic: Then he built the city of Feng and relocated his capital from the foot of Mount Qi to Feng.

sentences.zh: 明年，西伯崩，太子發立，是為武王。

translations.literal: The next year, the Western Lord passed away. Crown Prince Fa was established, and he was called King Wu.
translations.idiomatic: The next year, the Western Lord passed away. Crown Prince Fa succeeded him, and he was known as King Wu.

translations.literal: The next year, he attacked the Quanrong. The next year, he attacked Mixu. The next year, he defeated the state of Qi. Yin's Zu Yi heard of this and was afraid. He reported it to Emperor Zhou. Zhou said: 'Is there not Heaven's mandate? What can this accomplish!' The next year, he attacked Yu. The next year, he attacked Chong Hou Hu. Then he built the settlement of Feng and moved his capital from the foot of Mount Qi to Feng. The next year, the Western Lord passed away. Crown Prince Fa was established, and he was called King Wu.

sentences.zh: 西伯蓋即位五十年。

translations.literal: The Western Lord had probably been on the throne for fifty years.
translations.idiomatic: The Western Lord had likely reigned for fifty years.

sentences.zh: 其囚羑里，蓋益易之八卦為六十四卦。

translations.literal: During his imprisonment at Youli, he probably expanded the Changes from eight trigrams to sixty-four hexagrams.
translations.idiomatic: During his imprisonment at Youli, he likely expanded the Book of Changes from eight trigrams to sixty-four hexagrams.

sentences.zh: 詩人道西伯，蓋受命之年稱王而斷虞芮之訟。

translations.literal: The poets spoke of the Western Lord: in the year he received Heaven's mandate, he was called king and judged the Yu-Rui dispute.
translations.idiomatic: The poets sang of the Western Lord: in the year he received the Mandate of Heaven, he was called king and adjudicated the Yu-Rui dispute.

sentences.zh: 後十年而崩，謚為文王。

translations.literal: Ten years later he passed away and was posthumously named King Wen.
translations.idiomatic: Ten years later he passed away and was posthumously honored as King Wen.

sentences.zh: 改法度，制正朔矣。

translations.literal: He changed the laws and measures, establishing the correct calendar.
translations.idiomatic: He reformed the laws and institutions, establishing the proper calendar.

sentences.zh: 追尊古公為太王，公季為王季：蓋王瑞自太王興。

translations.literal: He posthumously honored Gu Gong as Tai Wang, Gong Ji as Wang Ji: indeed the royal omens arose from Tai Wang.
translations.idiomatic: He posthumously elevated Gu Gong to Tai Wang, Gong Ji to Wang Ji: truly the royal auspices arose with Tai Wang.

translations.literal: The Western Lord had probably been on the throne for fifty years. During his imprisonment at Youli, he probably expanded the Changes from eight trigrams to sixty-four hexagrams. The poets spoke of the Western Lord: in the year he received Heaven's mandate, he was called king and judged the Yu-Rui dispute. Ten years later he passed away and was posthumously named King Wen. He changed the laws and measures, establishing the correct calendar. He retrospectively honored Gu Gong as King Tai and Gong Ji as King Ji. The kingly omens probably began with King Tai.

sentences.zh: 武王即位，太公望為師，周公旦為輔，召公、畢公之徒左右王，師修文王緒業。

translations.literal: When King Wu ascended the throne, Tai Gong Wang served as his teacher, Zhou Gong Dan as his assistant, and Zhao Gong and Bi Gong and others attended the king on left and right. They all continued and perfected King Wen's undertakings.
translations.idiomatic: When King Wu ascended the throne, Tai Gong Wang became his mentor, Zhou Gong Dan his chief counselor, and Zhao Gong, Bi Gong, and others served at the king's side. They all continued and brought to perfection King Wen's legacy.

translations.literal: When King Wu ascended the throne, Tai Gong Wang served as his teacher, Zhou Gong Dan as his assistant, and Zhao Gong and Bi Gong and others attended the king on left and right. They all continued and perfected King Wen's undertakings.

sentences.zh: 九年，武王上祭于畢。

translations.literal: In the ninth year, King Wu made an upward sacrifice at Bi.
translations.idiomatic: In the ninth year, King Wu offered sacrifices at Bi.

sentences.zh: 東觀兵，至于盟津。

translations.literal: He reviewed his troops to the east, arriving at Mengjin.
translations.idiomatic: He mustered his forces eastward, reaching Mengjin.

sentences.zh: 為文王木主，載以車，中軍。

translations.literal: He made a wooden tablet for King Wen and loaded it on a chariot in the center of the army.
translations.idiomatic: He prepared a wooden spirit tablet for King Wen and placed it on a chariot in the midst of the army.

sentences.zh: 武王自稱太子發，言奉文王以伐，不敢自專。

translations.literal: King Wu called himself Crown Prince Fa, saying he was upholding King Wen to attack, and dared not act on his own authority.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu referred to himself as Crown Prince Fa, declaring he acted in King Wen's name to campaign, not presuming to act independently.

sentences.zh: 乃告司馬、司徒、司空、諸節：「齊栗，信哉！

translations.literal: Then he addressed the Marshal, Minister of Works, Minister of Instruction, and all the officials: 'Be reverent and careful, trustworthy indeed!
translations.idiomatic: Then he addressed the Marshal, the Ministers of Works and Instruction, and all officials: 'Be solemn and attentive, truly faithful!

sentences.zh: 予無知，以先祖有德臣，小子受先功，畢立賞罰，以定其功。」

translations.literal: I am ignorant, but my ancestors had worthy ministers. This young one receives the former merit. I will establish rewards and punishments completely to settle their achievements.'
translations.idiomatic: I am inexperienced, but my ancestors had virtuous ministers. This youth inherits their merits. I will establish rewards and punishments in full to secure their accomplishments.'

sentences.zh: 遂興師。

translations.literal: Then he raised the army.
translations.idiomatic: Thus he mobilized the army.

sentences.zh: 師尚父號曰：「總爾眾庶，與爾舟楫，後至者斬。」

translations.literal: The Army Senior Father shouted: 'Assemble your multitudes and give you boats and oars. Those who arrive late will be executed.'
translations.idiomatic: The venerable Jiang Ziya proclaimed: 'Muster your multitudes and provide you with boats and oars. Those who arrive late shall be put to death.'

sentences.zh: 武王渡河，中流，白魚躍入王舟中，武王俯取以祭。

translations.literal: King Wu crossed the river. In mid-current, a white fish leaped into the king's boat. King Wu bent down, took it, and made sacrifice with it.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu forded the river. In midstream, a white fish leaped into the royal barge. King Wu stooped, retrieved it, and offered it in sacrifice.

sentences.zh: 既渡，有火自上復于下，至于王屋，流為烏，其色赤，其聲魄云。

translations.literal: Having crossed, there was fire that went from above and repeated below, arriving at Wangwu. It flowed and became a crow, its color red, its sound powerful like thunderclouds.
translations.idiomatic: Having crossed, fire descended from above and ascended from below, reaching Wangwu Mountain. It transformed into a crow, red in color, its cry powerful as thunder.

sentences.zh: 是時，諸侯不期而會盟津者八百諸侯。

translations.literal: At this time, the feudal lords met at Mengjin without prior arrangement—eight hundred feudal lords.
translations.idiomatic: At this moment, eight hundred lords assembled at Mengjin without prior summons.

sentences.zh: 諸侯皆曰：「紂可伐矣。」

translations.literal: All the feudal lords said: 'Zhou can be attacked.'
translations.idiomatic: All the lords declared: 'Zhou may now be overthrown.'

sentences.zh: 武王曰：「女未知天命，未可也。」

translations.literal: King Wu said: 'You do not know Heaven's mandate. It is not yet possible.'
translations.idiomatic: King Wu replied: 'You misunderstand the Mandate of Heaven. The time is not yet ripe.'

sentences.zh: 乃還師歸。

translations.literal: Then he returned the army home.
translations.idiomatic: Thus he withdrew the army and returned home.

translations.literal: In the ninth year, King Wu made an upward sacrifice at Bi. He reviewed his troops to the east, arriving at Mengjin. He made a wooden tablet for King Wen and loaded it on a chariot in the center of the army. King Wu called himself Crown Prince Fa, saying he was upholding King Wen to attack, and dared not act on his own authority. Then he told the Minister of War, Minister of Works, Minister of Rites, and various officials: 'Be serious and attentive, truly! I have no wisdom. Because my ancestors had virtuous ministers, this young one has received the prior merit. I will completely establish rewards and punishments to determine their merit.' Then he raised the army. The Army Senior Father commanded: 'Assemble your multitudes. I give you boats and oars. Those who arrive late will be beheaded.' King Wu crossed the river. In mid-current, a white fish leaped into the king's boat. King Wu bent down, took it, and made sacrifice with it. Having crossed, there was fire that went from above and repeated below, arriving at Wangwu. It flowed and became a crow, its color red, its sound powerful like thunderclouds. At this time, the feudal lords met at Mengjin without prior arrangement—eight hundred feudal lords. All the feudal lords said: 'Zhou can be attacked now.' King Wu said: 'You do not know Heaven's mandate. It is not yet possible.' Then he returned the army home.

sentences.zh: 居二年，聞紂昏亂暴虐滋甚，殺王子比干，囚箕子。

translations.literal: Two years passed. He heard that Zhou's confusion and tyranny had grown increasingly severe. He had killed Prince Bi Gan and imprisoned Ji Zi.
translations.idiomatic: Two years elapsed. He learned that Zhou's madness and cruelty had grown ever more extreme. He had slain Prince Bi Gan and imprisoned Ji Zi.

sentences.zh: 太師疵、少師彊抱其樂器而奔周。

translations.literal: Grand Master Ci and Junior Master Qiang embraced their musical instruments and fled to Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: Grand Master Ci and Junior Master Qiang clutched their musical instruments and defected to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 於是武王遍告諸侯曰：「殷有重罪，不可以不畢伐。」

translations.literal: Thus King Wu informed all the feudal lords: 'Yin has grave crimes. We cannot but completely attack them.'
translations.idiomatic: Thus King Wu addressed all the lords: 'The Shang bear grievous sins. We must utterly overthrow them.'

sentences.zh: 乃遵文王，遂率戎車三百乘，虎賁三千人，甲士四萬五千人，以東伐紂。

translations.literal: Then he followed King Wen's path and led three hundred war chariots, three thousand tiger warriors, and forty-five thousand armored soldiers to attack Zhou in the east.
translations.idiomatic: Then he honored King Wen's legacy and commanded three hundred war chariots, three thousand elite guards, and forty-five thousand armored troops to campaign eastward against Zhou.

sentences.zh: 十一年十二月戊午，師畢渡盟津，諸侯咸會。

translations.literal: In the eleventh year, twelfth month, day wuwu, the army completely crossed Mengjin, and all the feudal lords assembled.
translations.idiomatic: In the eleventh year, twelfth month, day wuwu, the entire army forded Mengjin, and all the lords gathered.

sentences.zh: 曰：「孳孳無怠！」

translations.literal: He said: 'Diligently without slackening!'
translations.idiomatic: He commanded: 'Be diligent and tireless!'

sentences.zh: 武王乃作太誓，告于眾庶：「今殷王紂乃用其婦人之言，自絕于天，毀壞其三正，離逖其王父母弟，乃斷棄其先祖之樂，乃為淫聲，用變亂正聲，怡說婦人。

translations.literal: King Wu then made the Great Oath and announced to the multitudes: 'Now King Zhou of Yin uses the words of his women, cuts himself off from Heaven, destroys his three correct ways, estranges his royal parents and younger brothers. He cuts off and abandons his ancestors' music, makes licentious sounds, uses them to disorder the correct sounds, and delights in pleasing women.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu then pronounced the Great Oath and declared to the assembled host: 'Now King Zhou of Yin heeds only the counsel of his women, severing himself from Heaven's favor. He demolishes the three cardinal principles, alienates his royal kin and siblings. He discards his ancestors' sacred music for lewd tunes that corrupt the proper harmonies, finding pleasure solely in gratifying women.

sentences.zh: 故今予發維共行天罰。

translations.literal: Therefore now I, Fa, will together execute Heaven's punishment.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore now I, Fa, shall together execute Heaven's retribution.

sentences.zh: 勉哉夫子，不可再，不可三！」

translations.literal: Exert yourselves, gentlemen! It cannot be done twice, it cannot be done three times!'
translations.idiomatic: Strive on, my lords! This opportunity comes but once, not twice, not thrice!'

translations.literal: Two years passed. He heard that Zhou's confusion and tyranny had grown increasingly severe. He had killed Prince Bi Gan and imprisoned Ji Zi. Grand Master Ci and Junior Master Qiang embraced their musical instruments and fled to Zhou. Thus King Wu comprehensively told the feudal lords: 'Yin has committed heavy crimes. We cannot but attack them completely.' Then he followed King Wen's path and led three hundred war chariots, three thousand tiger warriors, and forty-five thousand armored soldiers to attack Zhou in the east. In the eleventh year, twelfth month, day wuwu, the army completely crossed Mengjin, and all the feudal lords assembled. He said: 'Be diligent and tireless!' King Wu then made the Great Oath, telling the multitudes: 'Now King Zhou of Yin uses the words of his women, cutting himself off from Heaven. He destroys his three upright principles, separates from his royal parents and brothers. He cuts off and abandons his ancestors' music, makes lewd sounds, uses changes to confuse the correct sounds, and pleases women. Therefore now I, Fa, will together execute Heaven's punishment. Exert yourselves, gentlemen! This cannot happen again, cannot happen a third time!'

sentences.zh: 二月甲子昧爽，武王朝至于商郊牧野，乃誓。

translations.literal: In the second month, day jiazi, at the dim dawn, King Wu's court arrived at the Shang suburbs at Muye, and then he swore the oath.
translations.idiomatic: In the second month, day jiazi, at break of dawn, King Wu's host reached the Shang outskirts at Muye, and there he pronounced the oath.

sentences.zh: 武王左杖黃鉞，右秉白旄，以麾。

translations.literal: King Wu held a yellow axe in his left hand and grasped a white banner in his right, using it to signal.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu gripped a yellow battle-axe in his left hand and a white command pennant in his right, waving it to direct his forces.

sentences.zh: 曰：「遠矣西土之人！」

translations.literal: He said: 'Distant indeed are the people of the western lands!'
translations.idiomatic: He called out: 'How distant you are, people of the western territories!'

sentences.zh: 武王曰：「嗟！

translations.literal: King Wu said: 'Alas!
translations.idiomatic: King Wu cried: 'Ah!

sentences.zh: 我有國冢君，司徒、司馬、司空，亞旅、師氏，千夫長、百夫長，及庸、蜀、羌、髳、微、纑、彭、濮人，稱爾戈，比爾干，立爾矛，予其誓。」

translations.literal: I have the great lords of states, the Ministers of Works, War, and Instruction, the subordinate officers and commanders, the captains of thousands and hundreds, and the people of Yong, Shu, Qiang, Mao, Wei, Lu, Peng, and Pu. Raise your spears, align your shields, plant your lances—I shall swear the oath.'
translations.idiomatic: I have the noble lords of realms, the Ministers of Works, War, and Instruction, the junior officers and commanders, the captains of thousands and hundreds, and the folk of Yong, Shu, Qiang, Mao, Wei, Lu, Peng, and Pu. Raise your spears, align your shields, plant your lances—I shall pronounce the oath.'

sentences.zh: 王曰：「古人有言『牝雞無晨。

translations.literal: The king said: 'The ancients had a saying: 'A hen should not crow at dawn.
translations.idiomatic: The king declared: 'The ancients had a proverb: 'A hen should not crow at dawn.

sentences.zh: 牝雞之晨，惟家之索』。

translations.literal: If a hen crows at dawn, the household will be desolate.''
translations.idiomatic: When a hen crows at dawn, the household comes to ruin.''

sentences.zh: 今殷王紂維婦人言是用，自棄其先祖肆祀不答，昏棄其家國，遺其王父母弟不用，乃維四方之多罪逋逃是崇是長，是信是使，俾暴虐于百姓，以姦軌于商國。

translations.literal: Now King Zhou of Yin only uses the words of women, abandons his ancestors' free sacrifices without response. He darkly abandons his household and state, abandons his royal parents and brothers without using them. He honors and grows the many criminals and fugitives from the four directions, trusts and sends them. He causes tyranny toward the common people, with evil ways in the Shang state.
translations.idiomatic: Now King Zhou of Yin heeds only women's counsel, forsaking his ancestors' generous rites unanswered. He recklessly abandons his realm and kin, neglecting his royal relations and siblings. He elevates and nurtures the countless criminals and outlaws from the four quarters, entrusting and employing them. He inflicts cruelty upon the populace, with wicked practices throughout the Shang domain.

sentences.zh: 今予發維共行天之罰。

translations.literal: Now I, Fa, will together execute Heaven's punishment.
translations.idiomatic: Now I, Fa, shall jointly execute Heaven's retribution.

sentences.zh: 今日之事，不過六步七步，乃止齊焉，夫子勉哉！

translations.literal: Today's affair is no more than six steps and seven steps, then stop and align yourselves. Gentlemen, exert yourselves!
translations.idiomatic: Today's battle requires no more than six paces, seven paces, then halt and form ranks. My lords, give your utmost!

sentences.zh: 不過於四伐五伐六伐七伐，乃止齊焉，勉哉夫子！

translations.literal: No more than four strikes, five strikes, six strikes, seven strikes, then stop and align yourselves. Exert yourselves, gentlemen!
translations.idiomatic: No more than four blows, five blows, six blows, seven blows, then halt and reform ranks. Strive on, my lords!

sentences.zh: 尚桓桓，如虎如羆，如豺如離，于商郊，不御克奔，以役西土，勉哉夫子！

translations.literal: Be valiantly martial, like tigers and bears, like leopards and wolves, in the Shang suburbs. Do not resist those who submit and flee, to serve the western lands. Exert yourselves, gentlemen!
translations.idiomatic: Be fiercely brave, like tigers and bears, like panthers and wolves, upon the Shang fields. Spare those who surrender and flee, to serve the western territories. Press on, my lords!

sentences.zh: 爾所不勉，其于爾身有戮。」

translations.literal: If you do not exert yourselves, there will be slaughter upon your persons.'
translations.idiomatic: If you fail to strive, slaughter shall befall your bodies.'

sentences.zh: 誓已，諸侯兵會者車四千乘，陳師牧野。

translations.literal: The oath finished. The assembled troops of the feudal lords numbered four thousand chariots. The army was arrayed at Muye.
translations.idiomatic: The oath concluded. The lords' assembled forces totaled four thousand chariots. The army deployed at Muye.

translations.literal: In the second month, day jiazi, at the dim dawn, King Wu's court arrived at the Shang suburbs at Muye, and then he swore the oath. King Wu held a yellow axe in his left hand and grasped a white banner in his right, using it to signal. He said: 'How far you people of the western lands have come!' King Wu said: 'Alas! I have the great lords of the state, the Minister of Works, Minister of War, Minister of Rites, the Ya Lu and Shi Shi, commanders of thousands and hundreds, and the people of Yong, Shu, Qiang, Mao, Wei, Lu, Peng, and Pu. Raise your spears, compare your shields, stand your lances. I will swear an oath.' The king said: 'The ancient people had a saying: 'A hen does not crow at dawn. If a hen crows at dawn, the household will be desolate.' Now King Zhou of Yin only uses the words of women, abandons his ancestors' free sacrifices without response. He darkly abandons his household and state, abandons his royal parents and brothers without using them. He honors and grows the many criminals and fugitives from the four directions, trusts and sends them. He causes tyranny toward the common people, with evil ways in the Shang state. Now I, Fa, will together execute Heaven's punishment. Today's matter is no more than six or seven steps. Then stop and align yourselves there. Gentlemen, exert yourselves! No more than four, five, six, or seven strikes. Then stop and align yourselves there. Exert yourselves, gentlemen! Be strong and unyielding, like tigers and bears, like leopards and wolves. At the Shang suburbs, do not resist those who overcome and flee. Serve the western lands. Exert yourselves, gentlemen! If you do not exert yourselves, slaughter will come upon your bodies.' The oath finished. The assembled troops of the feudal lords numbered four thousand chariots. The army was arrayed at Muye.

sentences.zh: 帝紂聞武王來，亦發兵七十萬人距武王。

translations.literal: Emperor Zhou heard King Wu was coming and also sent seven hundred thousand troops to resist King Wu.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Zhou learned of King Wu's advance and dispatched seven hundred thousand troops to oppose him.

sentences.zh: 武王使師尚父與百夫致師，以大卒馳帝紂師。

translations.literal: King Wu had the Army Senior Father and the commander of hundreds lead the troops, charging Emperor Zhou's army with great force.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu commanded the venerable Jiang Ziya and the commander of hundreds to lead the charge, hurling the main force against Emperor Zhou's army.

sentences.zh: 紂師雖眾，皆無戰之心，心欲武王亟入。

translations.literal: Although Zhou's troops were numerous, none had the heart to fight. Their hearts wished for King Wu to enter quickly.
translations.idiomatic: Though Zhou's forces were vast in number, none possessed the will to battle. Their hearts longed for King Wu to enter swiftly.

sentences.zh: 紂師皆倒兵以戰，以開武王。

translations.literal: Zhou's troops all turned their weapons and fought to open the way for King Wu.
translations.idiomatic: Zhou's soldiers all reversed their weapons and fought to clear the path for King Wu.

sentences.zh: 武王馳之，紂兵皆崩畔紂。

translations.literal: King Wu charged them, and Zhou's soldiers all collapsed and rebelled against Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu charged forward, and Zhou's troops crumbled, turning against their ruler.

sentences.zh: 紂走，反入登于鹿臺之上，蒙衣其殊玉，自燔于火而死。

translations.literal: Zhou fled, returned and ascended the Deer Terrace. He covered his clothes with his special jade and burned himself in the fire to die.
translations.idiomatic: Zhou fled, doubling back to ascend the Deer Terrace. He draped his garments with precious jade and immolated himself in flames.

sentences.zh: 武王持大白旗以麾諸侯，諸侯畢拜武王，武王乃揖諸侯，諸侯畢從。

translations.literal: King Wu held the great white flag to signal the feudal lords. All the feudal lords bowed to King Wu. King Wu then bowed to the feudal lords, and all the feudal lords followed.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu raised the great white banner to direct the lords. All the lords bowed to King Wu. King Wu then returned their salute, and all the lords followed.

sentences.zh: 武王至商國，商國百姓咸待於郊。

translations.literal: King Wu arrived at the Shang state. All the common people of the Shang state waited for him in the suburbs.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu reached the Shang capital. All the Shang commoners awaited him in the outskirts.

sentences.zh: 於是武王使群臣告語商百姓曰：「上天降休！」

translations.literal: Thus King Wu had his ministers announce to the Shang common people: 'Heaven has sent down blessings!'
translations.idiomatic: Thus King Wu commanded his ministers to proclaim to the Shang people: 'Heaven has bestowed its favor!'

sentences.zh: 商人皆再拜稽首，武王亦答拜。

translations.literal: All the Shang people bowed twice and touched their heads to the ground. King Wu also returned the bow.
translations.idiomatic: All the Shang folk bowed twice and prostrated themselves. King Wu returned their salute.

sentences.zh: 遂入，至紂死所。

translations.literal: Then he entered and arrived at where Zhou had died.
translations.idiomatic: Then he entered and reached the place where Zhou had perished.

sentences.zh: 武王自射之，三發而後下車，以輕劍擊之，以黃鉞斬紂頭，縣大白之旗。

translations.literal: King Wu personally shot at him. After three shots, he descended from his chariot, struck him with a light sword, chopped off Zhou's head with a yellow axe, and hung it from the great white flag.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu personally shot at the corpse. After three arrows, he alighted from his chariot, struck it with a light sword, severed Zhou's head with a yellow axe, and displayed it from the great white banner.

sentences.zh: 已而至紂之嬖妾二女，二女皆經自殺。

translations.literal: Then he arrived at Zhou's two favorite concubines. Both women had hanged themselves.
translations.idiomatic: Then he came to Zhou's two favored concubines. Both women had taken their own lives by hanging.

sentences.zh: 武王又射三發，擊以劍，斬以玄鉞，縣其頭小白之旗。

translations.literal: King Wu shot three more times, struck them with his sword, chopped off their heads with a black axe, and hung them from a small white flag.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu shot three more arrows, struck them with his sword, severed their heads with a black axe, and displayed them from a small white banner.

sentences.zh: 武王已乃出復軍。

translations.literal: King Wu then went out and returned to the army.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu then departed and returned to his army.

translations.literal: Emperor Zhou heard King Wu was coming and also sent seven hundred thousand troops to resist King Wu. King Wu had the Army Senior Father and the commander of hundreds lead the troops, charging Emperor Zhou's army with great force. Although Zhou's troops were numerous, none had the heart to fight. Their hearts wished for King Wu to enter quickly. Zhou's troops all turned their weapons and fought to open the way for King Wu. King Wu charged them, and Zhou's soldiers all collapsed and rebelled against Zhou. Zhou fled, returned and ascended the Deer Terrace. He covered his clothes with his special jade and burned himself in the fire to die. King Wu held the great white flag to signal the feudal lords. All the feudal lords bowed to King Wu. King Wu then bowed to the feudal lords, and all the feudal lords followed. King Wu arrived at the Shang state. All the common people of the Shang state waited for him in the suburbs. Thus King Wu had his ministers tell the Shang common people: 'Heaven above sends blessings!' All the Shang people bowed twice and touched their heads to the ground. King Wu also returned the bow. Then he entered and arrived at where Zhou had died. King Wu personally shot at him. After three shots, he descended from his chariot, struck him with a light sword, chopped off Zhou's head with a yellow axe, and hung it from the great white flag. Then he arrived at Zhou's two favorite concubines. Both women had hanged themselves. King Wu shot three more times, struck them with his sword, chopped off their heads with a black axe, and hung them from a small white flag. King Wu then went out and returned to the army.

sentences.zh: 其明日，除道，修社及商紂宮。

translations.literal: The next day, they cleared the roads and repaired the altars and Shang palaces.
translations.idiomatic: The following day, they cleared the roads and restored the altars and Shang palaces.

sentences.zh: 及期，百夫荷罕旗以先驅。

translations.literal: When the time came, the commander of hundreds carried the Han flag to lead as vanguard.
translations.idiomatic: When the appointed moment arrived, the commander of hundreds bore the Han banner to lead the vanguard.

sentences.zh: 武王弟叔振鐸奉陳常車，周公旦把大鉞，畢公把小鉞，以夾武王。

translations.literal: King Wu's younger brother Shu Zhenduo held the arranged regular chariot. Zhou Gong Dan grasped a large axe, Bi Gong grasped a small axe, to flank King Wu.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu's younger brother Shu Zhenduo drove the ceremonial chariot. The Duke of Zhou wielded a large battle-axe, Duke Bi a small one, flanking King Wu on both sides.

sentences.zh: 散宜生、太顛、閎夭皆執劍以衛武王。

translations.literal: San Yisheng, Tai Dian, and Hong Yao all held swords to guard King Wu.
translations.idiomatic: San Yisheng, Tai Dian, and Hong Yao all held swords to stand guard over King Wu.

sentences.zh: 既入，立于社南大卒之左，［左］右畢從。

translations.literal: Having entered, he stood south of the altar to the left of the great soldiers. On left and right, all followed.
translations.idiomatic: Having entered, he stood south of the altar to the left of the great host. On all sides, they followed.

sentences.zh: 毛叔鄭奉明水，衛康叔封布茲，召公奭贊采，師尚父牽牲。

translations.literal: Mao Shuzheng presented the clear water. Wei Kangshu Feng spread the purple mats. Zhao Gong Shi assisted with the ceremonies. The Army Senior Father led the sacrificial animal.
translations.idiomatic: Mao Shuzheng presented the purified water. Duke Kang of Wei spread the purple mats. Duke Zhao of Shao assisted with the rites. The venerable Jiang Ziya led the sacrificial beast.

sentences.zh: 尹佚筴祝曰：「殷之末孫季紂，殄廢先王明德，侮蔑神祇不祀，昏暴商邑百姓，其章顯聞于天皇上帝。」

translations.literal: Yin Qi beat the drum and made the prayer: 'Yin's last descendant Ji Zhou destroys and abandons the former kings' bright virtue, insults and despises the spirits without sacrifice, darkly tyrannizes the common people of Shang city. His evil deeds are clearly heard by the Heavenly Emperor.'
translations.idiomatic: Yin Qi beat the drum and pronounced the invocation: 'Yin's final descendant Ji Zhou extinguishes and rejects the former kings' luminous virtue, affronts and scorns the gods without offerings, savagely oppresses the people of Shang city. His notorious crimes are manifestly heard by the August Heavenly Emperor.'

sentences.zh: 於是武王再拜稽首，曰：「膺更大命，革殷，受天明命。」

translations.literal: Thus King Wu bowed twice and touched his head to the ground, saying: 'I receive the great mandate, change Yin, receive Heaven's bright command.'
translations.idiomatic: Thus King Wu bowed twice and prostrated himself, declaring: 'I accept the supreme mandate, transform the Shang, receive Heaven's luminous decree.'

sentences.zh: 武王又再拜稽首，乃出。

translations.literal: King Wu again bowed twice and touched his head to the ground, then went out.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu again bowed twice and prostrated himself, then departed.

translations.literal: The next day, they cleared the roads and repaired the altars and Shang palaces. When the time came, the commander of hundreds carried the Han flag to lead as vanguard. King Wu's younger brother Shu Zhenduo held the arranged regular chariot. Zhou Gong Dan grasped a large axe, Bi Gong grasped a small axe, to flank King Wu. San Yisheng, Tai Dian, and Hong Yao all held swords to guard King Wu. Having entered, he stood south of the altar to the left of the great soldiers. On left and right, all followed. Mao Shuzheng presented the clear water. Wei Kangshu Feng spread the purple mats. Zhao Gong Shi assisted with the ceremonies. The Army Senior Father led the sacrificial animal. Yin Yi beat the prayer and said: 'Yin's final grandson Ji Zhou extinguished and abandoned the former kings' bright virtue, insulted and despised the spirits without sacrifice, darkly tyrannized the common people of Shang city. Its manifest crimes are clearly heard by the Heavenly Emperor God.' Thus King Wu bowed twice and touched his head to the ground, saying: 'I should receive the greater mandate, change Yin, and receive Heaven's bright mandate.' King Wu again bowed twice and touched his head to the ground, then went out.

sentences.zh: 封商紂子祿父殷之餘民。

translations.literal: He enfeoffed Shang Zhou's son Lu Fu with Yin's remaining people.
translations.idiomatic: He enfeoffed Shang Zhou's son Lu Fu with the surviving Shang populace.

sentences.zh: 武王為殷初定未集，乃使其弟管叔鮮、蔡叔度相祿父治殷。

translations.literal: King Wu, because Yin was initially settled but not yet gathered together, had his younger brothers Guan Shu Xian and Cai Shu Du assist Lu Fu in governing Yin.
translations.idiomatic: Since the Shang realm was newly pacified but not yet fully unified, King Wu appointed his younger brothers Guan Shu Xian and Cai Shu Du to assist Lu Fu in administering the Shang territories.

sentences.zh: 已而命召公釋箕子之囚。

translations.literal: Then he commanded Zhao Gong to release Ji Zi from prison.
translations.idiomatic: Then he ordered Duke Zhao to free Ji Zi from captivity.

sentences.zh: 命畢公釋百姓之囚，表商容之閭。

translations.literal: He commanded Bi Gong to release the common people's prisoners and honored Shang Rong's lane.
translations.idiomatic: He commanded Duke Bi to free the people's prisoners and marked Shang Rong's alley with honor.

sentences.zh: 命南宮括散鹿臺之財，發鉅橋之粟，以振貧弱萌隸。

translations.literal: He commanded Nan Gong Kuo to distribute the Deer Terrace's wealth, open the Ju Bridge's grain, to relieve the poor weak sprouts and servants.
translations.idiomatic: He commanded Nan Gong Kuo to disperse the treasures of the Deer Terrace and open the granaries of Ju Bridge to succor the impoverished, the weak, and the enslaved.

sentences.zh: 命南宮括、史佚展九鼎保玉。

translations.literal: He commanded Nan Gong Kuo and Shi Yi to display the nine tripods and protect the jade.
translations.idiomatic: He commanded Nan Gong Kuo and Shi Yi to exhibit the nine tripods and safeguard the precious jade.

sentences.zh: 命閎夭封比干之墓。

translations.literal: He commanded Hong Yao to seal Bi Gan's tomb.
translations.idiomatic: He commanded Hong Yao to properly entomb Bi Gan's remains.

sentences.zh: 命宗祝享祠于軍。

translations.literal: He commanded the ancestral priests to perform sacrifices in the army.
translations.idiomatic: He ordered the ritual officers to conduct sacrifices within the army camp.

sentences.zh: 乃罷兵西歸。

translations.literal: Then he disbanded the troops and returned west.
translations.idiomatic: Then he demobilized the army and journeyed westward.

sentences.zh: 行狩，記政事，作武成。

translations.literal: He conducted the hunt, recorded governmental affairs, and made the Wu Cheng.
translations.idiomatic: He undertook the imperial hunt, documented state affairs, and composed the Completion of the Martial Achievements.

sentences.zh: 封諸侯，班賜宗彝，作分殷之器物。

translations.literal: He enfeoffed the feudal lords, distributed and granted the ancestral vessels, and made the vessels for dividing Yin.
translations.idiomatic: He enfeoffed the regional lords, apportioned and bestowed the ritual bronzes, and crafted the vessels for apportioning the Shang territories.

sentences.zh: 武王追思先聖王，乃褒封神農之後於焦，黃帝之後於祝，帝堯之後於薊，帝舜之後於陳，大禹之後於杞。

translations.literal: King Wu, reminiscing about the former sage kings, honored and enfeoffed Shen Nong's descendants at Jiao, the Yellow Emperor's descendants at Zhu, Emperor Yao's descendants at Ji, Emperor Shun's descendants at Chen, and Great Yu's descendants at Qi.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu, reflecting upon the ancient sage rulers, graciously enfeoffed Shen Nong's descendants at Jiao, the Yellow Emperor's descendants at Zhu, Emperor Yao's descendants at Ji, Emperor Shun's descendants at Chen, and Great Yu's descendants at Qi.

sentences.zh: 於是封功臣謀士，而師尚父為首封。

translations.literal: Thus he enfeoffed the meritorious ministers and counselors, and the Army Senior Father was first to be enfeoffed.
translations.idiomatic: Thus he enfeoffed the worthy ministers and advisors, with the venerable Jiang Ziya receiving the first fief.

sentences.zh: 封尚父於營丘，曰齊。

translations.literal: He enfeoffed the Senior Father at Yingqiu, calling it Qi.
translations.idiomatic: He enfeoffed the venerable elder at Yingqiu, naming it Qi.

sentences.zh: 封弟周公旦於曲阜，曰魯。

translations.literal: He enfeoffed his younger brother Zhou Gong Dan at Qufu, calling it Lu.
translations.idiomatic: He enfeoffed his younger brother the Duke of Zhou at Qufu, naming it Lu.

sentences.zh: 封召公奭於燕。

translations.literal: He enfeoffed Zhao Gong Shi at Yan.
translations.idiomatic: He enfeoffed Duke Zhao of Shao at Yan.

sentences.zh: 封弟叔鮮於管，弟叔度於蔡。

translations.literal: He enfeoffed his younger brother Shu Xian at Guan, and younger brother Shu Du at Cai.
translations.idiomatic: He enfeoffed his younger brother Shu Xian at Guan and younger brother Shu Du at Cai.

sentences.zh: 餘各以次受封。

translations.literal: The rest each received enfeoffment in order.
translations.idiomatic: The others each received their fiefs in due succession.

translations.literal: He enfeoffed Shang Zhou's son Lufu with Yin's remaining people. Because Yin was initially settled but not yet gathered together, King Wu had his younger brothers Guan Shu Xian and Cai Shu Du assist Lufu in governing Yin. Then he commanded Zhao Gong to release Ji Zi from prison. He commanded Bi Gong to release the common people's prisoners and honored Shang Rong's lane. He commanded Nan Gong Kuo to distribute the wealth of the Deer Terrace and open the grain stores of Juqiao to relieve the poor, weak, and new servants. He commanded Nan Gong Kuo and Shi Yi to display the nine tripods and protect the jade. He commanded Hong Yao to seal Bi Gan's tomb. He commanded the ancestral priests to make sacrifices in the army. Then he dismissed the troops and returned west. He conducted a hunt, recorded government affairs, and made the Martial Achievement. He enfeoffed the feudal lords, distributed and granted ancestral vessels, and made the utensils for dividing Yin. King Wu reminisced about the former sage kings and honorably enfeoffed Shen Nong's descendants at Jiao, the Yellow Emperor's descendants at Zhu, Emperor Yao's descendants at Ji, Emperor Shun's descendants at Chen, and Great Yu's descendants at Qi. Thus he enfeoffed the meritorious ministers and counselors, with the Army Senior Father being the first enfeoffed. He enfeoffed the Senior Father at Yingqiu, calling it Qi. He enfeoffed his younger brother Zhou Gong Dan at Qufu, calling it Lu. He enfeoffed Zhao Gong Shi at Yan. He enfeoffed his younger brother Shu Xian at Guan and his younger brother Shu Du at Cai. The remaining lords each received enfeoffment in order.

sentences.zh: 武王徵九牧之君，登豳之阜，以望商邑。

translations.literal: King Wu summoned the lords of the nine regions, ascended the mound at Bin, and gazed at the Shang city.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu summoned the governors of the nine provinces, climbed the hill at Bin, and surveyed the Shang capital.

sentences.zh: 武王至于周，自夜不寐。

translations.literal: King Wu arrived at Zhou, and from night did not sleep.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu reached Zhou, and lay awake through the night.

sentences.zh: 周公旦即王所，曰：「曷為不寐？」

translations.literal: Zhou Gong Dan approached the king's place and said: 'Why do you not sleep?'
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Zhou approached the king's quarters and asked: 'Why do you not sleep?'

sentences.zh: 王曰：「告女：維天不饗殷，自發未生於今六十年，麋鹿在牧，蜚鴻滿野。

translations.literal: The king said: 'I tell you: Heaven no longer feasts Yin. From when Fa was not yet born until now sixty years, deer are in the pastures, flying geese fill the fields.
translations.idiomatic: The king replied: 'I shall tell you: Heaven no longer blesses the Shang. From before my birth until now, sixty years, deer roam the pastures and wild geese crowd the plains.

sentences.zh: 天不享殷，乃今有成。

translations.literal: Heaven does not enjoy Yin, and thus now there is accomplishment.
translations.idiomatic: Heaven has withdrawn its favor from the Shang, and thus now we achieve success.

sentences.zh: 維天建殷，其登名民三百六十夫，不顯亦不賓滅，以至今。

translations.literal: Heaven established Yin, and its registered people numbered three hundred sixty men. Though not illustrious, they were not destroyed in submission, down to the present.
translations.idiomatic: Heaven founded the Shang, and their registered populace numbered three hundred sixty men. Though undistinguished, they were not extinguished in obedience, enduring until now.

sentences.zh: 我未定天保，何暇寐！」

translations.literal: I have not yet secured Heaven's protection. How can I sleep!'
translations.idiomatic: I have not yet secured Heaven's safeguarding. How can I find rest!'

sentences.zh: 王曰：「定天保，依天室，悉求夫惡，貶從殷王受。

translations.literal: The king said: 'Secure Heaven's protection, rely on Heaven's chamber. Fully seek out those who are evil, demote those who followed and received from the Yin king.
translations.idiomatic: The king continued: 'Establish Heaven's safeguarding, dwell in Heaven's sanctuary. Thoroughly identify the wicked, depose those who served and received from the Shang king.

sentences.zh: 日夜勞來定我西土，我維顯服，及德方明。

translations.literal: Day and night toil to settle my western lands. I am illustrious in service, and virtue is now bright.
translations.idiomatic: Day and night we labor to pacify our western territories. I am resplendent in governance, and virtue now shines forth.

sentences.zh: 自洛汭延于伊汭，居易毋固，其有夏之居。

translations.literal: From the Luo bend extending to the Yi bend, dwell at ease without stubbornness, possessing Xia's residence.
translations.idiomatic: From the Luo River's bend extending to the Yi River's bend, reside comfortably without rigidity, holding Xia's ancient dwelling.

sentences.zh: 我南望三涂，北望嶽鄙，顧詹有河，粵詹雒、伊，毋遠天室。」

translations.literal: I look south to the Three Roads, north to the mountain suburbs. Behold, there is the river. And the Luo and Yi—do not be far from Heaven's chamber.'
translations.idiomatic: I gaze south to the Triple Roads, north to the mountain outskirts. Behold the Yellow River, and the Luo and Yi—remain close to Heaven's sanctuary.'

sentences.zh: 營周居于雒邑而後去。

translations.literal: He planned Zhou's residence at Luoyi and then departed.
translations.idiomatic: He laid out Zhou's capital at Luoyi and then departed.

sentences.zh: 縱馬於華山之陽，放牛於桃林之虛；

translations.literal: He released horses on Mount Hua's southern slope, let loose oxen in the Tao Forest's plains.
translations.idiomatic: He set horses free on the sunny slopes of Mount Hua, released cattle into the open meadows of Tao Forest.

sentences.zh: 偃干戈，振兵釋旅：示天下不復用也。

translations.literal: He laid down weapons and dismissed the troops: showing the realm they would not be used again.
translations.idiomatic: He laid aside arms and demobilized the soldiers: demonstrating to the empire they would not be needed again.

translations.literal: King Wu summoned the lords of the nine regions, ascended the mound at Bin, and gazed at the Shang city. King Wu arrived at Zhou and did not sleep from that night onward. Zhou Gong Dan approached the king's location and said: 'Why do you not sleep?' The king said: 'Let me tell you: Heaven no longer favors Yin. From the time Fa was not yet born until now has been sixty years. Deer roam in the pastures, and wild geese fill the fields. Heaven no longer favors Yin, and only now do we have accomplishment. Only Heaven established Yin, and its registered named people numbered three hundred sixty men. Though not illustrious, they were not obedient and extinguished, persisting until now. I have not yet fixed Heaven's protection. What leisure do I have to sleep!' The king said: 'Fix Heaven's protection, rely on Heaven's chamber. Completely seek out those who are evil and demote those who followed the Yin king. Day and night labor to come and fix my western lands. I will only illustriously serve and reach virtue when it is just becoming bright. From the bend of the Luo extending to the bend of the Yi, dwell easily without stubbornness, as it has the Xia residence. I gaze south to Santu, north to the outskirts of Mount Yue. I look and see the river, or see the Luo and Yi. Do not be far from Heaven's chamber.' He built Zhou's residence at Luoyi and then departed. He released horses on the southern slopes of Mount Hua and oxen in the wilderness of Taolin; He laid down weapons and dismissed the troops: showing the realm they would not be used again.

sentences.zh: 武王已克殷，後二年，問箕子殷所以亡。

translations.literal: King Wu had already conquered Yin. Two years later, he asked Ji Zi why Yin had perished.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu had already overthrown the Shang. Two years later, he inquired of Ji Zi the reasons for Yin's downfall.

sentences.zh: 箕子不忍言殷惡，以存亡國宜告。

translations.literal: Ji Zi could not bear to speak of Yin's evils, so informed him of the principles for preserving and perishing states.
translations.idiomatic: Ji Zi could not bring himself to speak of the Shang's wickedness, so instructed him in the principles of state survival and ruin.

sentences.zh: 武王亦醜，故問以天道。

translations.literal: King Wu also considered it shameful, so asked about the way of Heaven.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu also found it distasteful, so inquired about the principles of Heaven.

translations.literal: King Wu had already conquered Yin. Two years later, he asked Ji Zi why Yin had perished. Ji Zi could not bear to speak of Yin's evils, so he told of what was proper for surviving and perished states. King Wu was also ashamed, so he asked about the Way of Heaven.

sentences.zh: 武王病。

translations.literal: King Wu fell ill.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu fell gravely ill.

sentences.zh: 天下未集，群公懼，穆卜，周公乃祓齋，自為質，欲代武王，武王有瘳。

translations.literal: The realm was not yet gathered together, the nobles feared, performed divination. The Duke of Zhou purified himself and fasted, offered himself as hostage, wished to substitute for King Wu. King Wu recovered.
translations.idiomatic: The empire remained unsettled, the nobles were terrified, they performed divination. The Duke of Zhou purified himself through ritual fasting, offered himself as pledge, desiring to take King Wu's place. King Wu regained his health.

sentences.zh: 後而崩，太子誦代立，是為成王。

translations.literal: Later he passed away. Crown Prince Song succeeded him. He was called King Cheng.
translations.idiomatic: Shortly thereafter he passed away. Crown Prince Song ascended the throne. He was known as King Cheng.

translations.literal: King Wu became ill. The realm was not yet gathered together. All the lords were afraid. They divined with Mu. Zhou Gong then purified and fasted, became a hostage himself, wishing to substitute for King Wu. King Wu recovered. Later he collapsed. Crown Prince Song was established in his place, and he was called King Cheng.

sentences.zh: 成王少，周初定天下，周公恐諸侯畔周，公乃攝行政當國。

translations.literal: King Cheng was young. Zhou had just pacified the realm. The Duke of Zhou feared the feudal lords would rebel against Zhou, so he took charge of administration and governed the state.
translations.idiomatic: King Cheng was still a child. Zhou had only recently brought the empire under control. The Duke of Zhou feared the regional lords might revolt against Zhou, so he assumed the regency and ruled the state.

sentences.zh: 管叔、蔡叔群弟疑周公，與武庚作亂，畔周。

translations.literal: Guan Shu, Cai Shu, and the other brothers suspected the Duke of Zhou, joined with Wu Geng in rebellion, revolted against Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: The uncles Guan Shu and Cai Shu, along with their brothers, grew suspicious of the Duke of Zhou, allied with Wu Geng in insurrection, and rebelled against Zhou.

sentences.zh: 周公奉成王命，伐誅武庚、管叔，放蔡叔。

translations.literal: The Duke of Zhou, upholding King Cheng's command, attacked and executed Wu Geng and Guan Shu, exiled Cai Shu.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Zhou, acting on King Cheng's orders, campaigned against and executed Wu Geng and Guan Shu, banishing Cai Shu.

sentences.zh: 以微子開代殷後，國於宋。

translations.literal: He established Wei Zi Kai as the successor to Yin, with his state at Song.
translations.idiomatic: He installed Wei Zi Kai as the legitimate successor to the Shang, establishing his realm at Song.

sentences.zh: 頗收殷餘民，以封武王少弟封為衛康叔。

translations.literal: He somewhat gathered Yin's remaining people to enfeoff King Wu's younger brother Feng as Wei Kang Shu.
translations.idiomatic: He gathered many of the surviving Shang people to enfeoff King Wu's younger brother Feng as the Duke Kang of Wei.

sentences.zh: 晉唐叔得嘉穀，獻之成王，成王以歸周公于兵所。

translations.literal: Jin Tang Shu obtained auspicious grain and offered it to King Cheng. King Cheng returned it to the Duke of Zhou at the army encampment.
translations.idiomatic: Jin Tang Shu discovered marvelous grain and presented it to King Cheng. King Cheng conveyed it to the Duke of Zhou at the military camp.

sentences.zh: 周公受禾東土，魯天子之命。

translations.literal: The Duke of Zhou received the grain from the eastern lands and the command of Lu as Son of Heaven.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Zhou accepted the grain from the eastern territories and the mandate to rule Lu as the Son of Heaven.

sentences.zh: 初，管、蔡畔周，周公討之，三年而畢定，故初作大誥，次作微子之命，次歸禾，次嘉禾，次康誥、酒誥、梓材，其事在周公之篇。

translations.literal: Initially, Guan and Cai rebelled against Zhou. The Duke of Zhou attacked them, and in three years it was completely settled. Therefore he first made the Great Announcement, next the Wei Zi Command, next the Return of Grain, next the Auspicious Grain, next the Kang Announcement, Wine Announcement, and Zi Cai. Their matters are in the Duke of Zhou's chapter.
translations.idiomatic: At first, Guan Shu and Cai Shu rebelled against Zhou. The Duke of Zhou put down their insurrection, and in three years order was fully restored. Thus he first composed the Great Pronouncement, then the Wei Zi Mandate, then the Return of Grain, then the Auspicious Grain, then the Kang Pronouncement, the Wine Pronouncement, and Zi Cai. These events are recorded in the Duke of Zhou's biography.

sentences.zh: 周公行政七年，成王長，周公反政成王，北面就群臣之位。

translations.literal: The Duke of Zhou administered the government for seven years. King Cheng grew up. The Duke of Zhou returned the government to King Cheng and, facing north, took his position among the ministers.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Zhou held the regency for seven years. King Cheng came of age. The Duke of Zhou returned governance to King Cheng and, in proper humility, assumed his place among the ministers.

translations.literal: King Cheng was young. Zhou had initially fixed the realm. Zhou Gong feared the feudal lords would rebel against Zhou, so he administered the government and acted as head of state. Guan Shu and Cai Shu, all younger brothers, doubted Zhou Gong and, together with Wu Geng, made rebellion and rebelled against Zhou. Zhou Gong, upholding King Cheng's command, attacked and executed Wu Geng and Guan Shu, and banished Cai Shu. He had Wei Zi Kai substitute as Yin's descendants, with their state at Song. He somewhat gathered Yin's remaining people to enfeoff King Wu's younger brother Feng as Wei Kang Shu. Jin Tang Shu obtained auspicious grain and offered it to King Cheng. King Cheng returned it to Zhou Gong at the army encampment. Zhou Gong received the grain from the eastern lands and the command of Lu as Son of Heaven. Initially, Guan and Cai rebelled against Zhou. Zhou Gong attacked them, and in three years it was completely settled. Therefore he first made the Great Announcement, next the Wei Zi Command, next the Return of Grain, next the Auspicious Grain, next the Kang Announcement, Wine Announcement, and Zi Cai. Their matters are in Zhou Gong's chapter. Zhou Gong administered the government for seven years. King Cheng grew up. Zhou Gong returned the government to King Cheng and, facing north, took his position among the ministers.

sentences.zh: 成王在豐，使召公復營洛邑，如武王之意。

translations.literal: King Cheng was at Feng. He had Duke Zhao again build Luoyi, as King Wu had intended.
