translations.idiomatic: King Cheng resided at Feng. He commanded Duke Zhao to rebuild Luoyi, fulfilling King Wu's original vision.

sentences.zh: 周公復卜申視，卒營筑，居九鼎焉。

translations.literal: The Duke of Zhou again divined and extended his view. Finally they built and constructed, placing the nine tripods there.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Zhou performed further divination and surveyed the site. In the end, they constructed the city and installed the nine sacred tripods there.

sentences.zh: 曰：「此天下之中，四方入貢道里均。」

translations.literal: He said: 'This is the center of the realm. The four directions' tribute routes are of equal distance.'
translations.idiomatic: He declared: 'This lies at the heart of the empire. Tribute routes from the four quarters are equally balanced in distance.'

sentences.zh: 作召誥、洛誥。

translations.literal: He made the Zhao Gao and Luo Gao.
translations.idiomatic: He composed the Proclamation of Duke Zhao and the Proclamation of Luo.

sentences.zh: 成王既遷殷遺民，周公以王命告，作多士、無佚。

translations.literal: King Cheng having relocated Yin's surviving people, the Duke of Zhou informed them with the king's command, made the Duo Shi and Wu Yi.
translations.idiomatic: King Cheng having resettled the surviving Shang people, the Duke of Zhou addressed them with the king's decree, composing the Many Officers and No Leisure documents.

sentences.zh: 召公為保，周公為師，東伐淮夷，殘奄，遷其君薄泵。

translations.literal: Duke Zhao served as protector, the Duke of Zhou as teacher. They attacked east to the Huai Yi, destroyed Yan, moved their ruler Bo Chou.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Zhao served as guardian, the Duke of Zhou as mentor. They campaigned eastward against the Huai barbarians, destroyed Yan, and relocated their ruler Bo Chou.

sentences.zh: 成王自奄歸，在宗周，作多方。

translations.literal: King Cheng returned from Yan, was in Zong Zhou, made the Duo Fang.
translations.idiomatic: King Cheng returned from Yan and, residing in Zong Zhou, composed the Many Regions proclamation.

sentences.zh: 既絀殷命，襲淮夷，歸在豐，作周官。

translations.literal: Having ended Yin's mandate, attacked the Huai Yi, returned and was at Feng, made the Zhou Guan.
translations.idiomatic: Having terminated the Shang mandate and assaulted the Huai barbarians, he returned to Feng and composed the Zhou Offices.

sentences.zh: 興正禮樂，度制於是改，而民和睦，頌聲興。

translations.literal: He promoted correct rites and music, measures and institutions thus changed, and the people were harmonious, praise songs arose.
translations.idiomatic: He revived proper ceremonies and music, reformed weights and measures, and the people lived in harmony as hymns of praise flourished.

sentences.zh: 成王既伐東夷，息慎來賀，王賜榮伯作賄息慎之命。

translations.literal: King Cheng having attacked the eastern Yi, the Xishen came to congratulate. The king granted Rong Bo to make the Bribe Xishen command.
translations.idiomatic: King Cheng having campaigned against the eastern barbarians, the Xishen came to offer congratulations. The king bestowed Rong Bo to compose the Xishen Tribute decree.

translations.literal: King Cheng was at Feng. He had Zhao Gong again build Luoyi, as King Wu had intended. Zhou Gong again divined and extended his view. Finally they built and constructed, placing the nine tripods there. He said: 'This is the center of the realm. The four directions enter with tribute, and the road distances are equal.' He made the Zhao Announcement and Luo Announcement. King Cheng had already moved Yin's remaining people. Zhou Gong, with the king's command, told them and made the Many Officers and No Leisure. Zhao Gong served as protector, Zhou Gong as teacher. They attacked east to the Huai Yi, destroyed Yan, and moved their ruler to Bo Beng. King Cheng returned from Yan and, at Zong Zhou, made the Many Regions. Having ended Yin's mandate and attacked the Huai Yi, he returned at Feng and made the Zhou Officials. He raised correct rites and music, and the measures and systems were thus changed. The people were harmonious, and songs of praise arose. King Cheng had already attacked the eastern Yi. Xishen came to congratulate. The king granted Rong Bo to make the command for bribing Xishen.

sentences.zh: 成王將崩，懼太子釗之不任，乃命召公、畢公率諸侯以相太子而立之。

translations.literal: King Cheng was about to pass away, feared Crown Prince Zhao was not capable, so commanded Duke Zhao and Duke Bi to lead the feudal lords to assist the crown prince and establish him.
translations.idiomatic: King Cheng neared his end, worried that Crown Prince Zhao might prove unequal to the task, so commanded Duke Zhao and Duke Bi to lead the lords in supporting the crown prince and enthroning him.

sentences.zh: 成王既崩，二公率諸侯，以太子釗見於先王廟，申告以文王、武王之所以為王業之不易，務在節儉，毋多欲，以篤信臨之，作顧命。

translations.literal: King Cheng having passed away, the two dukes led the feudal lords, presented Crown Prince Zhao at the ancestral temple, repeatedly informed him of why King Wen and King Wu's royal enterprise was not easy, emphasized frugality, not many desires, to govern with steadfast faith, made the Gu Ming.
translations.idiomatic: King Cheng having passed away, the two dukes led the lords and presented Crown Prince Zhao at the ancestral shrine, solemnly instructing him on why King Wen and King Wu's royal undertaking was arduous, stressing moderation and self-restraint over excessive desires, to rule with unwavering sincerity. They composed the Testamentary Charge.

sentences.zh: 太子釗遂立，是為康王。

translations.literal: Crown Prince Zhao then was established. He was called King Kang.
translations.idiomatic: Crown Prince Zhao then ascended the throne. He was known as King Kang.

sentences.zh: 康王即位，遍告諸侯，宣告以文武之業以申之，作《康誥》。

translations.literal: King Kang ascended the throne, informed all the feudal lords, declared the Wen and Wu enterprises to reiterate them, made the Kang Gao.
translations.idiomatic: King Kang ascended the throne and addressed all the lords, proclaiming the legacies of Wen and Wu to reinforce them, composing the Kang Proclamation.

sentences.zh: 故成康之際，天下安寧，刑錯四十餘年不用。

translations.literal: Therefore between Cheng and Kang, the realm was peaceful. Punishments were set aside and not used for more than forty years.
translations.idiomatic: Thus during the reigns of Cheng and Kang, the empire enjoyed profound peace. The instruments of punishment gathered dust, unused for more than forty years.

sentences.zh: 康王命作策畢公分居里，成周郊，作《畢命》。

translations.literal: King Kang commanded to make a tally for Duke Bi to divide residences and neighborhoods in the suburbs of Cheng Zhou, made the Bi Ming.
translations.idiomatic: King Kang commanded the composition of a decree for Duke Bi to apportion dwellings and districts in the outskirts of Cheng Zhou, creating the Bi Mandate.

translations.literal: King Cheng was about to collapse. He feared that Crown Prince Zhao was not capable, so he commanded Zhao Gong and Bi Gong to lead the feudal lords to assist the crown prince and establish him. King Cheng had already collapsed. The two nobles led the feudal lords and, with Crown Prince Zhao, appeared at the ancestral kings' temple. They repeatedly explained the reasons why Wen Wang and Wu Wang's kingly undertakings were not easy: devotion to frugality, no many desires, and overseeing them with sincere trust. They made the Testament Command. Crown Prince Zhao was then established, and he was called King Kang. King Kang ascended the throne and comprehensively told the feudal lords. He declared the undertaking of Wen and Wu to repeat it and made the Kang Announcement. Therefore, between Cheng and Kang, the realm was peaceful. Punishments were set aside and not used for more than forty years. King Kang commanded the making of a document for Bi Gong to divide and dwell in the li, in the suburbs of Chengzhou. He made the Bi Command.

sentences.zh: 康王卒，子昭王瑕立。

translations.literal: King Kang died, and his son King Zhao Xia was established.
translations.idiomatic: King Kang passed away, and his son King Zhao Xia ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 昭王之時，王道微缺。

translations.literal: In King Zhao's time, the royal way slightly declined.
translations.idiomatic: During King Zhao's reign, the royal way began to falter.

sentences.zh: 昭王南巡狩不返，卒於江上。

translations.literal: King Zhao toured south and did not return, died on the Jiang River.
translations.idiomatic: King Zhao journeyed south on inspection and never returned, meeting his end upon the Yangtze River.

sentences.zh: 其卒不赴告，諱之也。

translations.literal: His death was not reported in haste, to avoid the taboo.
translations.idiomatic: His passing was not immediately announced, out of deference to ritual propriety.

sentences.zh: 立昭王子滿，是為穆王。

translations.literal: King Zhao's son Man was established. He was called King Mu.
translations.idiomatic: King Zhao's son Man ascended the throne. He was known as King Mu.

sentences.zh: 穆王即位，春秋已五十矣。

translations.literal: King Mu ascended the throne, his years were already fifty.
translations.idiomatic: King Mu ascended the throne already fifty years of age.

sentences.zh: 王道衰微，穆王閔文武之道缺，乃命伯臩申誡太仆國之政，作臩命。

translations.literal: The royal way declined slightly. King Mu grieved that the Wen and Wu way was deficient, so commanded Bo Xiang to reiterate warnings to the Grand Servitor about state administration, made the Xiang Ming.
translations.idiomatic: The royal path grew somewhat dim. King Mu lamented the fading of Wen and Wu's teachings, so commanded Bo Xiang to reinforce admonitions to the Grand Steward regarding governance, composing the Xiang Mandate.

sentences.zh: 復寧。

translations.literal: He returned to peace.
translations.idiomatic: Order was restored.

translations.literal: King Kang died, and his son Zhao Wang Xia was established. In Zhao Wang's time, the kingly way was slightly deficient. Zhao Wang toured south and hunted but did not return. He died above the Jiang. His death was not urgently announced; it was tabooed. Zhao Wang's son Man was established, and he was called King Mu. King Mu ascended the throne when he was already fifty years old. The kingly way declined and weakened. King Mu grieved that Wen and Wu's way was deficient, so he commanded Bo Quan to declare and warn the Grand Coach about state politics. He made the Quan Command. It became peaceful again.

sentences.zh: 穆王將征犬戎，祭公謀父諫曰：「不可。

translations.literal: King Mu was about to campaign against the Quanrong. Ji Gong Mou Fu advised: 'Cannot.
translations.idiomatic: King Mu prepared to campaign against the Quanrong. The Earl of Ji, Mou Fu, counseled: 'This must not be done.

sentences.zh: 先王燿德不觀兵。

translations.literal: The former kings displayed virtue, not weapons.
translations.idiomatic: Our ancestors illuminated virtue, not brandished arms.

sentences.zh: 夫兵戢而時動，動則威，觀則玩，玩則無震。

translations.literal: Indeed, weapons are stored and move at the proper time. When they move they are awe-inspiring. When displayed they become playthings. Playthings have no terror.
translations.idiomatic: Weapons are sheathed and deployed only when timely. When deployed they inspire dread. When merely displayed they become toys. Toys inspire no fear.

sentences.zh: 是故周文公之頌曰：『載戢干戈，載櫜弓矢，我求懿德，肆于時夏，允王保之。』

translations.literal: Therefore the Duke of Zhou's ode says: 'They stored the shields and spears, they cased the bows and arrows. I seek excellent virtue, to extend to the Xia of this time. Truly the king preserves it.'
translations.idiomatic: Thus the Duke of Zhou's hymn declares: 'They sheathed the spears and shields, they covered the bows and arrows. I seek perfect virtue, to spread through the Xia of our age. May the true king safeguard it.'

sentences.zh: 先王之於民也，茂正其德而厚其性，阜其財求而利其器用，明利害之鄉，以文修之，使之務利而辟害，懷德而畏威，故能保世以滋大。

translations.literal: The former kings toward the people luxuriantly corrected their virtue and thickened their nature, enriched their wealth seeking and benefited their implements, clarified the direction of benefit and harm, with culture refined them, caused them to pursue benefit and avoid harm, cherish virtue and fear authority, therefore could preserve generations and grow great.
translations.idiomatic: Our ancestors treated the people by abundantly rectifying their morals and enriching their character, multiplying their prosperity and improving their tools, clarifying the paths of advantage and detriment, refining them through civilization, directing them to seek benefit and shun harm, to embrace virtue and revere authority. Thus they preserved their legacy and grew mighty.

sentences.zh: 昔我先王世后稷以服事虞、夏。

translations.literal: Formerly our ancestral kings followed Hou Ji to serve Yu and Xia.
translations.idiomatic: In ancient times our forebears, following Hou Ji's example, served the regimes of Yu and Xia.

sentences.zh: 及夏之衰也，棄稷不務，我先王不窋用失其官，而自竄於戎狄之閒。

translations.literal: When Xia declined, they abandoned Ji's ways and were not diligent. Our ancestral king Bu Xu therefore lost his office, and hid himself among the Rong and Di.
translations.idiomatic: When the Xia fell into decay, they forsook Ji's teachings and grew neglectful. Our forefather Bu Xu thereby forfeited his position and concealed himself among the Rong and Di peoples.

sentences.zh: 不敢怠業，時序其德，遵修其緒，修其訓典，朝夕恪勤，守以敦篤，奉以忠信。

translations.literal: He dared not neglect his undertaking, timely arranged his virtue, followed and repaired his legacy, repaired his teachings and standards, morning and evening respectfully diligent, guarded with sincerity and solidity, served with loyalty and faith.
translations.idiomatic: He dared not slacken in his enterprise, methodically cultivated virtue, preserved and enhanced his heritage, refined his doctrines and institutions, remained respectfully diligent from dawn till dusk, guarded with steadfast sincerity, served with unwavering loyalty and good faith.

sentences.zh: 奕世載德，不忝前人。

translations.literal: Generations carried virtue, not disgracing the ancestors.
translations.idiomatic: Generation after generation bore virtue aloft, bringing no shame upon their forebears.

sentences.zh: 至于文王、武王，昭前之光明而加之以慈和，事神保民，無不欣喜。

translations.literal: Arriving at King Wen and King Wu, they illuminated the former brightness and added compassion and harmony, served the spirits and protected the people, nothing was not joyful.
translations.idiomatic: Coming to King Wen and King Wu, they illuminated past glories and infused them with benevolence and concord, served the gods and safeguarded the people, leaving nothing but delight.

sentences.zh: 商王帝辛大惡于民，庶民不忍，訢載武王，以致戎于商牧。

translations.literal: The Shang king Di Xin greatly harmed the people. The common people could not endure it, united and supported King Wu, to bring weapons to the Shang pasture.
translations.idiomatic: The Shang king Di Xin grievously oppressed the people. The common folk could bear it no longer, united behind King Wu, bringing war to the Shang plains.

sentences.zh: 是故先王非務武也，勸恤民隱而除其害也。

translations.literal: Therefore the former kings were not devoted to warfare, but encouraged compassion for the people's hardships and removed their harms.
translations.idiomatic: Thus our ancestors did not pursue militarism, but fostered sympathy for the people's sufferings and eliminated their afflictions.

sentences.zh: 夫先王之制，邦內甸服，邦外侯服，侯衛賓服，夷蠻要服，戎翟荒服。

translations.literal: Indeed the former kings' system: within the state Dian service, outside the state Hou service, Hou guard Bin service, Yi Man Yao service, Rong Di Huang service.
translations.idiomatic: Our ancestors' system indeed: within the realm, the Dian domain; beyond the borders, the Hou domain; guarding the Hou, the Bin domain; binding the Yi and Man, the Yao domain; restraining the Rong and Di, the Huang domain.

sentences.zh: 甸服者祭，侯服者祀，賓服者享，要服者貢，荒服者王。

translations.literal: Dian service: sacrifice. Hou service: ancestral rites. Bin service: present. Yao service: tribute. Huang service: king.
translations.idiomatic: The Dian domain offers sacrifices. The Hou domain performs ancestral rites. The Bin domain presents tribute. The Yao domain sends contributions. The Huang domain acknowledges the king.

sentences.zh: 日祭，月祀，時享，歲貢，終王。

translations.literal: Daily sacrifices, monthly ancestral rites, seasonal offerings, yearly tribute, finally the king.
translations.idiomatic: Daily rites, monthly sacrifices, seasonal presentations, annual contributions, culminating in allegiance to the king.

sentences.zh: 先王之順祀也，有不祭則修意，有不祀則修言，有不享則修文，有不貢則修名，有不王則修德，序成而有不至則修刑。

translations.literal: The former kings' orderly sacrifices: if not sacrificing then cultivate intention, if not performing rites then cultivate speech, if not offering then cultivate culture, if not contributing then cultivate reputation, if not acknowledging king then cultivate virtue. When the sequence is complete and there are those not arriving, then cultivate punishment.
translations.idiomatic: Our ancestors' ritual order: when sacrifices are neglected, refine the will; when rites are omitted, refine speech; when offerings fail, refine culture; when tribute ceases, refine reputation; when kingship is denied, refine virtue. When the hierarchy is established yet some fail to appear, then apply punishment.

sentences.zh: 於是有刑不祭，伐不祀，征不享，讓不貢，告不王。

translations.literal: Thus there is punishment for not sacrificing, attack for not performing rites, campaign for not offering, reproach for not contributing, announcement for not acknowledging king.
translations.idiomatic: Hence punishment for those who sacrifice not, conquest for those who perform rites not, expedition for those who offer not, rebuke for those who contribute not, proclamation for those who acknowledge the king not.

sentences.zh: 於是有刑罰之辟，有攻伐之兵，有征討之備，有威讓之命，有文告之辭。

translations.literal: Thus there are punishments' precedents, attacking troops, campaigning preparations, awe-inspiring commands, cultured announcements' words.
translations.idiomatic: Thus exist the statutes of punishment, the armies of conquest, the instruments of expedition, the commands of authority, the declarations of civilization.

sentences.zh: 布令陳辭而有不至，則增修於德，無勤民於遠。

translations.literal: When decrees are issued and words are set forth yet there are those not arriving, then increase cultivation of virtue, do not labor the people from afar.
translations.idiomatic: When edicts are promulgated and statements proclaimed yet some fail to appear, then redouble efforts in virtue, spare the distant people exertion.

sentences.zh: 是以近無不聽，遠無不服。

translations.literal: Therefore the near have none not listening, the far have none not submitting.
translations.idiomatic: Thus the nearby all obey, the distant all submit.

sentences.zh: 今自大畢、伯士之終也，犬戎氏以其職來王，天子曰『予必以不享征之，且觀之兵』，無乃廢先王之訓，而王幾頓乎？

translations.literal: Now since the end of Da Bi and Bo Shi, the Quanrong clan with their duties came to acknowledge the king. The Son of Heaven said 'I must campaign against them for not offering, and moreover observe their troops.' Might this not abandon the former kings' teachings, and cause the king's foundation to collapse?
translations.idiomatic: Now since the passing of Da Bi and Bo Shi, the Quanrong people have fulfilled their obligations and acknowledged the king. The Son of Heaven declared 'I must campaign against them for failing to present offerings, and moreover inspect their forces.' Might this not discard our ancestors' doctrines, causing the royal foundation to crumble?

sentences.zh: 吾聞犬戎樹敦，率舊德而守終純固，其有以御我矣。」

translations.literal: I have heard the Quanrong establish sincerity, follow old virtue and guard the end with pure firmness. They have what can defend against us.'
translations.idiomatic: I have heard the Quanrong cultivate integrity, uphold ancient virtues and maintain their commitments with steadfast purity. They possess the means to resist us.'

sentences.zh: 王遂征之，得四白狼四白鹿以歸。

translations.literal: The king then campaigned against them, obtained four white wolves and four white deer to return.
translations.idiomatic: The king proceeded with the campaign, acquiring four white wolves and four white deer as trophies.

sentences.zh: 自是荒服者不至。

translations.literal: From this the Huang service ones did not arrive.
translations.idiomatic: Henceforth the distant tributaries ceased to appear.

translations.literal: King Mu was about to campaign against the Quanrong. Ji Gong Moufu advised: 'It is not possible. The former kings shone with virtue and did not inspect troops. Indeed, troops are stored and only move at the right time. When they move, they inspire awe. When inspected, they become frivolous. When frivolous, they inspire no fear. This is why the ode of Zhou Wen Gong says: 'Loaded and stored the weapons, loaded and sheathed the bows and arrows. I seek excellent virtue, extending it to timely Xia. Truly the king protects it.' The former kings toward the people: luxuriantly corrected their virtue and thickened their nature, enriched their wealth-seeking and benefited their utensil use, clarified the directions of benefit and harm, and repaired them with culture. They made them devote themselves to benefit and avoid harm, cherish virtue and fear awe. Therefore they could preserve generations and increase greatly. Formerly my former kings, generation after generation, served Yu and Xia as Hou Ji. When Xia declined, they abandoned Ji and were not diligent. My former king Bu Xu lost his office because of this, and then fled himself among the Rong and Di. They dared not be lax in their undertakings, timely arranged their virtue, followed and repaired their continuation, repaired their instruction canons, and were respectfully diligent morning and evening. They guarded with sincere solidity and served with loyal trust. Many generations carried virtue and did not disgrace their predecessors. When it arrived at Wen Wang and Wu Wang, they illuminated the former brightness and added kind harmony. They served the spirits and protected the people. Nothing was not joyful. Shang king Di Xin was greatly evil toward the people. The common people could not bear it, united and carried Wu Wang, to bring weapons to the Shang pasture. This is why the former kings were not devoted to martial matters. They urged relief of the people's hidden sufferings and removed their harms. Indeed, the former kings' system: within the state dian service, outside the state hou service, hou wei bin service, yi man yao service, rong di huang service. Dian service: sacrifice. Hou service: ancestral rites. Bin service: present. Yao service: tribute. Huang service: king. Day: sacrifice. Month: rites. Season: present. Year: tribute. Finally: king. The former kings' orderly sacrifices: if there was no sacrifice, then they repaired their intention. If no rites, repaired their words. If no present, repaired their culture. If no tribute, repaired their name. If no king, repaired their virtue. When the order was complete and there were those who did not arrive, then they repaired with punishment. Thus there were punishments for not sacrificing, attacks for not performing rites, campaigns for not presenting, remonstrations for not tributing, and announcements for not kinging. Thus there were laws of punishment, troops for attacking and campaigning, preparations for campaigning and attacking, commands of awe and remonstration, and words of cultural announcements. When commands were spread and words arranged but there were those who did not arrive, then they increased repair at virtue, without laboring the people from afar. This is why nothing near did not listen, nothing far did not submit. Now, since the end of Da Bi and Bo Shi, the Quanrong clan came with their duty to king. The Son of Heaven said: 'I must campaign against them for not presenting, and moreover observe their troops.' Is this not abandoning the former kings' instruction, and will the king nearly collapse? I have heard that the Quanrong establish solidity, follow old virtue and guard the end purely and firmly. They have means to defend against me.' The king then campaigned against them and got four white wolves and four white deer to return with. From this time, the huang service did not arrive.

sentences.zh: 諸侯有不睦者，甫侯言於王，作修刑辟。

translations.literal: When feudal lords had discord, Fu Hou spoke to the king, made the Xiu Xing Bi.
translations.idiomatic: When lords fell into discord, the Marquis of Fu addressed the king, composing the Revised Penal Code.

sentences.zh: 王曰：「吁，來！

translations.literal: The king said: 'Ah, come!
translations.idiomatic: The king exclaimed: 'Ah, approach!

sentences.zh: 有國有土，告汝祥刑。

translations.literal: You who have states and lands, I announce to you auspicious punishments.
translations.idiomatic: You lords of realms and territories, I proclaim to you the benevolent laws.

sentences.zh: 在今爾安百姓，何擇非其人，何敬非其刑，何居非其宜與？

translations.literal: In the present you settle the common people, what to choose is not their person, what to respect is not their punishment, what to dwell in is not their propriety, yes?
translations.idiomatic: In these times you pacify the populace—what to select is not the right person, what to honor is not the proper law, what to inhabit is not the appropriate dwelling, is it not?

sentences.zh: 兩造具備，師聽五辭。

translations.literal: Both parties fully prepared, the master hears the five arguments.
translations.idiomatic: When both sides are present, the judge hears the five statements of testimony.

sentences.zh: 五辭簡信，正於五刑。

translations.literal: The five arguments are simple and trustworthy, corrected by the five punishments.
translations.idiomatic: The five statements of testimony are clear and credible, verified by the five penalties.

sentences.zh: 五刑不簡，正於五罰。

translations.literal: The five punishments are not simple, corrected by the five penalties.
translations.idiomatic: The five punishments lack clarity, verified by the five fines.

sentences.zh: 五罰不服，正於五過。

translations.literal: The five penalties are not accepted, corrected by the five transgressions.
translations.idiomatic: The five fines are unacceptable, verified by the five offenses.

sentences.zh: 五過之疵，官獄內獄，閱實其罪，惟鈞其過。

translations.literal: The five transgressions' flaws, official prisons inner prisons, examine truly their crimes, only balance their transgressions.
translations.idiomatic: The defects in the five offenses, between official courts and private tribunals, verify the reality of their crimes, but balance their faults.

sentences.zh: 五刑之疑有赦，五罰之疑有赦，其審克之。

translations.literal: The five punishments' doubts have pardon, the five penalties' doubts have pardon, investigate and overcome them.
translations.idiomatic: When the five punishments are doubtful, grant amnesty; when the five fines are doubtful, grant amnesty. Investigate thoroughly to resolve them.

sentences.zh: 簡信有眾，惟訊有稽。

translations.literal: Simple trustworthiness has multitude, only interrogation has verification.
translations.idiomatic: Clear credibility has witnesses, interrogation alone provides verification.

sentences.zh: 無簡不疑，共嚴天威。

translations.literal: Without simplicity there is doubt, together respect Heaven's awe.
translations.idiomatic: Without clarity there is suspicion; together revere Heaven's majesty.

sentences.zh: 黥辟疑赦，其罰百率，閱實其罪。

translations.literal: Tattooing precedent doubtful, grant amnesty, its penalty one hundred liu, examine truly its crime.
translations.idiomatic: When tattooing is doubtful, grant amnesty; the fine is one hundred liu; verify the reality of the crime.

sentences.zh: 劓辟疑赦，其罰倍灑，閱實其罪。

translations.literal: Nose-cutting precedent doubtful, grant amnesty, its penalty double sa, examine truly its crime.
translations.idiomatic: When nose-cutting is doubtful, grant amnesty; the fine is double sa; verify the reality of the crime.

sentences.zh: 臏辟疑赦，其罰倍差，閱實其罪。

translations.literal: Hamstringing precedent doubtful, grant amnesty, its penalty double cha, examine truly its crime.
translations.idiomatic: When hamstringing is doubtful, grant amnesty; the fine is double cha; verify the reality of the crime.

sentences.zh: 宮辟疑赦，其罰五百率，閱實其罪。

translations.literal: Castration precedent doubtful, grant amnesty, its penalty five hundred liu, examine truly its crime.
translations.idiomatic: When castration is doubtful, grant amnesty; the fine is five hundred liu; verify the reality of the crime.

sentences.zh: 大辟疑赦，其罰千率，閱實其罪。

translations.literal: Death penalty precedent doubtful, grant amnesty, its penalty one thousand liu, examine truly its crime.
translations.idiomatic: When execution is doubtful, grant amnesty; the fine is one thousand liu; verify the reality of the crime.

sentences.zh: 墨罰之屬千，劓罰之屬千，臏罰之屬五百，宮罰之屬三百，大辟之罰其屬二百：五刑之屬三千。」

translations.literal: Tattooing penalties' categories one thousand, nose-cutting penalties' categories one thousand, hamstringing penalties' categories five hundred, castration penalties' categories three hundred, death penalty's penalties their categories two hundred: five punishments' categories three thousand.'
translations.idiomatic: Tattooing fines comprise one thousand categories, nose-cutting fines one thousand categories, hamstringing fines five hundred categories, castration fines three hundred categories, execution fines comprise two hundred categories: the five punishments total three thousand categories.'

sentences.zh: 命曰甫刑。

translations.literal: Commanded it called Fu Xing.
translations.idiomatic: It was named the Fu Penal Code.

translations.literal: When feudal lords were not harmonious, Fu Hou spoke to the king and made the repair punishment laws. The king said: 'Ah, come! You have states and lands. I tell you of auspicious punishments. Now you pacify the common people. What do you choose that is not the right people? What do you respect that is not the right punishments? What do you dwell in that is not suitable? Both sides are fully prepared. The master hears the five arguments. The five arguments are simple and trustworthy, corrected by the five punishments. The five punishments are not simple, corrected by the five penalties. The five penalties do not submit, corrected by the five faults. The blemish of the five faults: official prison, inner prison. Examine the reality of their crimes, only balance their faults. For doubts in the five punishments there is pardon, for doubts in the five penalties there is pardon. Examine and overcome them. Simple and trustworthy have the multitude. Only interrogation has records. Nothing simple is not doubted. Together stern with Heaven's majesty. For tattoo law doubts there is pardon. Its penalty is one hundred rates. Examine the reality of their crimes. For nose-cutting law doubts there is pardon. Its penalty is double the drink. Examine the reality of their crimes. For shin-cutting law doubts there is pardon. Its penalty is double the difference. Examine the reality of their crimes. For castration law doubts there is pardon. Its penalty is five hundred rates. Examine the reality of their crimes. For great execution law doubts there is pardon. Its penalty is one thousand rates. Examine the reality of their crimes. Tattoo penalties belong to one thousand, nose-cutting penalties belong to one thousand, shin-cutting penalties belong to five hundred, castration penalties belong to three hundred, great execution penalties belong to two hundred: the five punishments belong to three thousand.' It was commanded to be called the Fu Punishment.

sentences.zh: 穆王立五十五年，崩，子共王繄扈立。

translations.literal: King Mu stood fifty-five years, passed away, son King Gong Yi Hu established.
translations.idiomatic: King Mu reigned fifty-five years, then passed away. His son King Gong Yi Hu ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 共王游於涇上，密康公從，有三女奔之。

translations.literal: King Gong toured on the Jing River, the Marquis Kang of Mi followed, and three women fled to him.
translations.idiomatic: King Gong was boating on the Jing River when the Marquis Kang of Mi accompanied him, and three beautiful women took refuge with the marquis.

sentences.zh: 其母曰：「必致之王。

translations.literal: His mother said: 'You must present them to the king.
translations.idiomatic: His mother counseled: 'You must offer them to the king.

sentences.zh: 夫獸三為群，人三為眾，女三為粲。

translations.literal: Indeed, beasts three become a herd, people three become a multitude, women three become resplendent.
translations.idiomatic: Indeed, three beasts form a herd, three people form a crowd, three women form a bevy of beauty.

sentences.zh: 王田不取群，公行不下眾，王御不參一族。

translations.literal: The king on hunts does not take herds, dukes in travel do not go below multitudes, kings in receiving do not participate in one clan.
translations.idiomatic: The king on hunts does not take entire herds, nobles in procession do not descend below crowds, kings in marriage do not wed within the same clan.

sentences.zh: 夫粲，美之物也。

translations.literal: Indeed, resplendence is a beautiful thing.
translations.idiomatic: Indeed, such beauty is a precious thing.

sentences.zh: 眾以美物歸女，而何德以堪之？

translations.literal: The multitude with beautiful things come to you, and what virtue do you have to bear it?
translations.idiomatic: The people bring you these beauties, and what merit do you possess to deserve them?

sentences.zh: 王猶不堪，況爾之小醜乎！

translations.literal: Even the king still cannot bear it, let alone your petty ugliness!
translations.idiomatic: Even the king cannot properly handle such allure, let alone a minor lord like you!

sentences.zh: 小醜備物，終必亡。」

translations.literal: Petty ugliness complete with objects, in the end must perish.'
translations.idiomatic: A petty lord possessing such treasures will surely come to ruin.'

sentences.zh: 康公不獻，一年，共王滅密。

translations.literal: The Marquis Kang did not present them. One year, King Gong extinguished Mi.
translations.idiomatic: The Marquis Kang refused to surrender them. One year later, King Gong destroyed the state of Mi.

sentences.zh: 共王崩，子懿王艱立。

translations.literal: King Gong passed away, son King Yi Jian established.
translations.idiomatic: King Gong died, and his son King Yi Jian ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 懿王之時，王室遂衰，詩人作刺。

translations.literal: In King Yi's time, the royal house then declined, poets made satires.
translations.idiomatic: During King Yi's reign, the Zhou house began its decline, and poets composed critical verses.

translations.literal: King Mu was established for fifty-five years. He collapsed, and his son King Gong Yi Hu was established. King Gong toured above the Jing. Mi Kang Gong followed. Three women fled to him. Their mother said: 'You must present them to the king. Indeed, three beasts make a herd, three people make a multitude, three women make resplendence. The king on a hunt does not take a herd. The duke on a journey does not go below a multitude. The king in taking does not mix with one clan. Indeed, resplendence is a thing of beauty. The multitude returns beautiful things to you. What virtue do you have to bear it? Even the king cannot bear it. How much more your small ugliness! Small ugliness prepares things. In the end it must perish.' Kang Gong did not offer them. After one year, King Gong extinguished Mi. King Gong collapsed, and his son King Yi Jian was established. In King Yi's time, the royal house then declined. Poets made satires.

sentences.zh: 懿王崩，共王弟辟方立，是為孝王。

translations.literal: King Yi passed away, King Gong's younger brother Pi Fang established, he was called King Xiao.
translations.idiomatic: King Yi died, and King Gong's younger brother Pi Fang ascended, known as King Xiao.

sentences.zh: 孝王崩，諸侯復立懿王太子燮，是為夷王。

translations.literal: King Xiao passed away, the feudal lords again established King Yi's crown prince Xie, he was called King Yi.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiao died, and the lords reinstated King Yi's crown prince Xie as King Yi.

translations.literal: King Yi collapsed. King Gong's younger brother Bi Fang was established, and he was called King Xiao. King Xiao collapsed. The feudal lords again established King Yi's crown prince Xie, and he was called King Yi.

sentences.zh: 夷王崩，子厲王胡立。

translations.literal: King Yi passed away, son King Li Hu established.
translations.idiomatic: King Yi died, and his son King Li Hu ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 厲王即位三十年，好利，近榮夷公。

translations.literal: King Li ascended thirty years, loved profit, drew near Rong Yi Gong.
translations.idiomatic: King Li had reigned thirty years when he grew enamored of profit and favored the Duke Rong Yi.

sentences.zh: 大夫芮良夫諫厲王曰：「王室其將卑乎？

translations.literal: Grandee Rui Liang Fu advised King Li: 'The royal house is about to be humbled, yes?
translations.idiomatic: The noble Rui Liang Fu counseled King Li: 'Is the Zhou house about to be brought low?

sentences.zh: 夫榮公好專利而不知大難。

translations.literal: Indeed, Duke Rong loves monopolizing profit and does not know great calamity.
translations.idiomatic: Indeed, the Duke Rong loves to monopolize profits and fails to foresee great disaster.

sentences.zh: 夫利，百物之所生也，天地之所載也，而有專之，其害多矣。

translations.literal: Indeed, profit is what all things are born from, what Heaven and Earth carry, and yet there is monopolizing it, its harms are many.
translations.idiomatic: Indeed, wealth is the source from which all things spring, borne by Heaven and Earth themselves. Yet to monopolize it brings great harm.

sentences.zh: 天地百物皆將取焉，何可專也？

translations.literal: Heaven and Earth and all things will all take from it, how can it be monopolized?
translations.idiomatic: Heaven, Earth, and all creation draw from it—how can one person claim it exclusively?

sentences.zh: 所怒甚多，不備大難。

translations.literal: Those angered are very many, not prepared for great calamity.
translations.idiomatic: Many will be enraged, unprepared for catastrophe.

sentences.zh: 以是教王，王其能久乎？

translations.literal: With this teaching the king, can the king last long?
translations.idiomatic: Teaching the king thus—how long can he endure?

sentences.zh: 夫王人者，將導利而布之上下者也。

translations.literal: Indeed, one who is king will guide profit and distribute it to upper and lower.
translations.idiomatic: Indeed, a true king guides wealth and distributes it throughout high and low alike.

sentences.zh: 使神人百物無不得極，猶日怵惕懼怨之來也。

translations.literal: Cause spirits and people and all things none not to obtain their utmost, still daily apprehensive fearing resentment's coming.
translations.idiomatic: Ensuring that gods, men, and all things each receive their due, yet still daily vigilant against the rise of grievances.

sentences.zh: 故《頌》曰『思文后稷，克配彼天，立我蒸民，莫匪爾極』。

translations.literal: Therefore the Ode says: 'Think of cultured Hou Ji, able to match that Heaven, established our numerous people, none not your utmost.'
translations.idiomatic: Thus the Hymn declares: 'Remember cultured Hou Ji, who matched Heaven itself, established our myriad folk, none failing of his perfect guidance.'

sentences.zh: 大雅曰『陳錫載周』。

translations.literal: The Greater Elegance says 'Displayed and bestowed carried Zhou.'
translations.idiomatic: The Greater Odes proclaim 'Displayed bounty and carried Zhou.'

sentences.zh: 是不布利而懼難乎，故能載周以至于今。

translations.literal: This is not distributing profit and fearing calamity, therefore could carry Zhou down to the present.
translations.idiomatic: This means distributing wealth while fearing disaster, thus sustaining Zhou until the present day.

sentences.zh: 今王學專利，其可乎？

translations.literal: Now the king learns monopolizing profit, can this be?
translations.idiomatic: Now the king learns to monopolize wealth—is this acceptable?

sentences.zh: 匹夫專利，猶謂之盜，王而行之，其歸鮮矣。

translations.literal: A common man monopolizes profit, still called a thief. The king does it, his return will be rare.
translations.idiomatic: Even a commoner monopolizing wealth is called a thief. For a king to do so—his fate will be grim indeed.

sentences.zh: 榮公若用，周必敗也。」

translations.literal: If Duke Rong is employed, Zhou must fail.'
translations.idiomatic: If Duke Rong is given power, Zhou will surely perish.'

sentences.zh: 厲王不聽，卒以榮公為卿士，用事。

translations.literal: King Li did not listen, in the end made Duke Rong the Chief Minister, handling affairs.
translations.idiomatic: King Li paid no heed and ultimately appointed Duke Rong as Chief Minister to govern affairs.

translations.literal: King Yi collapsed, and his son King Li Hu was established. King Li ascended the throne for thirty years. He liked profit and approached Rong Yi Gong. The grandee Rui Liangfu advised King Li: 'Will the royal house perhaps be brought low? Indeed, Rong Gong likes to monopolize profit and does not know great difficulties. Indeed, profit is what the hundred things are born from, what heaven and earth carry. If someone monopolizes it, the harm is great. Heaven and earth's hundred things will all take from it. How can it be monopolized? What has angered many people. Not prepared for great difficulties. With this teaching the king, will the king perhaps last long? Indeed, ruling people means guiding profit and distributing it to superiors and inferiors. Making spirits, people, and the hundred things all achieve their utmost, yet still daily alarmed and fearing resentment's coming. Therefore the Ode says: 'Think of cultured Hou Ji, who was able to match that heaven, established our numerous people, nothing was not your utmost.' The Great Elegant says: 'Display and bestow, carrying Zhou.' This did not distribute profit and feared difficulties, therefore could carry Zhou until now. Now the king learns to monopolize profit. Is this possible? A common man monopolizing profit is still called a thief. If the king does it, his following will be few. If Rong Gong is employed, Zhou will certainly fail.' King Li did not listen. He finally made Rong Gong the chief minister to handle affairs.

sentences.zh: 王行暴虐侈傲，國人謗王。

translations.literal: The king practiced tyranny extravagant arrogance, the people of the state slandered the king.
translations.idiomatic: The king grew tyrannical, extravagant, and arrogant, and the people began to criticize him openly.

sentences.zh: 召公諫曰：「民不堪命矣。」

translations.literal: Duke Zhao advised: 'The people cannot bear the commands anymore.'
translations.idiomatic: Duke Zhao counseled: 'The people can no longer endure these decrees.'

sentences.zh: 王怒，得衛巫，使監謗者，以告則殺之。

translations.literal: The king angered, obtained a Wei sorcerer, had him monitor the slanderers, reported them then killed them.
translations.idiomatic: The king flew into a rage, procured a sorcerer from Wei, and had him spy on critics, executing those he reported.

sentences.zh: 其謗鮮矣，諸侯不朝。

translations.literal: Their slander became few, the feudal lords did not come to court.
translations.idiomatic: Criticism dwindled, but the lords ceased attending court.

sentences.zh: 三十四年，王益嚴，國人莫敢言，道路以目。

translations.literal: Thirty-four years, the king became increasingly harsh, the people of the state dared not speak, on the roads communicated with eyes.
translations.idiomatic: In his thirty-fourth year, the king grew ever more severe. The people dared not speak, communicating only with glances on the roads.

sentences.zh: 厲王喜，告召公曰：「吾能弭謗矣，乃不敢言。」

translations.literal: King Li was pleased, told Duke Zhao: 'I can stop the slander now, and they dare not speak.'
translations.idiomatic: King Li was delighted and told Duke Zhao: 'I have silenced the critics—they now dare not speak.'

sentences.zh: 召公曰：「是鄣之也。

translations.literal: Duke Zhao said: 'This is blocking them.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Zhao replied: 'This is damming them up.

sentences.zh: 防民之口，甚於防水。

translations.literal: Blocking the people's mouths is worse than blocking water.
translations.idiomatic: Damming the people's mouths is more dangerous than damming a river.

sentences.zh: 水壅而潰，傷人必多，民亦如之。

translations.literal: Water dammed up and bursts, injuring people must be many, the people are also like this.
translations.idiomatic: When dammed water bursts forth, it injures many. The people are the same.

sentences.zh: 是故為水者決之使導，為民者宣之使言。

translations.literal: Therefore for water, open it to make it flow; for the people, spread it to make them speak.
translations.idiomatic: Thus for water, breach the dam to let it flow; for the people, open channels to let them speak.

sentences.zh: 故天子聽政，使公卿至於列士獻詩，瞽獻曲，史獻書，師箴，瞍賦，矇誦，百工諫，庶人傳語，近臣盡規，親戚補察，瞽史教誨，耆艾修之，而後王斟酌焉，是以事行而不悖。

translations.literal: Therefore the Son of Heaven hears government, causes the nobles and ministers down to the ranked scholars to offer poems, the blind to offer songs, the scribes to offer books, the masters to admonish, the sighted-blind to compose, the fully-blind to recite, the hundred craftsmen to remonstrate, the common people to transmit words, close ministers to exhaust their advice, relatives to supplement and examine, blind scribes to teach and guide, elders to refine it, and then the king weighs it, thus affairs proceed without error.
translations.idiomatic: Thus the Son of Heaven in governing ensures that nobles and ministers down to the scholars offer poems, blind musicians offer songs, scribes offer writings, tutors offer admonitions, sighted poets compose verses, blind reciters chant hymns, artisans remonstrate, commoners convey opinions, close advisors give full counsel, kin supplement and scrutinize, blind historians teach and instruct, elders refine the wisdom—and only then does the king deliberate. Thus governance proceeds without contradiction.

sentences.zh: 民之有口也，猶土之有山川也，財用於是乎出：猶其有原隰衍沃也，衣食於是乎生。

translations.literal: The people's having mouths is like soil having mountains and rivers, wealth and resources from this come out: like it having plains marshes expanses fertile, clothing and food from this are born.
translations.idiomatic: The people's voices are like mountains and rivers in the soil—from them wealth and resources emerge. Like plains, marshes, expanses, and fertile lands—from them clothing and food are produced.

sentences.zh: 口之宣言也，善敗於是乎興。

translations.literal: The mouth's open declarations, good and bad from this arise.
translations.idiomatic: Through open speech, both virtue and vice emerge.

sentences.zh: 行善而備敗，所以產財用衣食者也。

translations.literal: Practice good and prepare for bad, thus produce wealth resources clothing food.
translations.idiomatic: Practice virtue while preparing for failure—thus wealth, resources, clothing, and food are produced.

sentences.zh: 夫民慮之於心而宣之於口，成而行之。

translations.literal: Indeed the people consider it in heart and declare it in mouth, complete and act upon it.
translations.idiomatic: The people ponder in their hearts and express through their mouths, then form plans and act.

sentences.zh: 若壅其口，其與能幾何？」

translations.literal: If dam their mouths, how long can it last?'
translations.idiomatic: If you dam their mouths, how long can such repression endure?'

sentences.zh: 王不聽。

translations.literal: The king did not listen.
translations.idiomatic: The king paid no heed.

sentences.zh: 於是國莫敢出言，三年，乃相與畔，襲厲王。

translations.literal: Thus the state none dared speak out. Three years, then together rebelled, attacked King Li.
translations.idiomatic: Thus no one in the realm dared speak. After three years, they united in rebellion and assaulted King Li.

sentences.zh: 厲王出奔於彘。

translations.literal: King Li fled to Zhi.
translations.idiomatic: King Li fled into exile at Zhi.

translations.literal: The king acted tyrannically, extravagantly, and arrogantly. The people of the state slandered the king. Zhao Gong advised: 'The people cannot bear the commands anymore.' The king was angry. He got a sorcerer from Wei to monitor slanderers, and when they were reported, he killed them. Their slander became few. The feudal lords did not come to court. In the thirty-fourth year, the king became increasingly strict. The people of the state dared not speak. On the roads they communicated with their eyes. King Li was pleased and told Zhao Gong: 'I can stop the slander now. They dare not speak.' Zhao Gong said: 'This dams it. Blocking the people's mouths is worse than blocking water. When water is dammed it bursts, injuring many people. The people are also like that. This is why for water one opens it to make it flow, for people one proclaims it to make them speak. Therefore the Son of Heaven hears government and makes nobles down to ranked scholars offer poems, the blind offer tunes, historians offer books, masters admonish, the blind assign compositions, the blind recite, the hundred craftsmen remonstrate, common people transmit words, close ministers exhaust their admonitions, relatives supplement their observations, blind historians teach and instruct, elders and aged repair them, and then the king considers them. This is why affairs proceed without contradiction. The people having mouths is like the earth having mountains and rivers—wealth and use come out from this. It is like having plains, marshes, level lands, and fertile areas—clothing and food are born from this. Mouths declaring words—good and bad arise from this. Practicing good while preparing for bad is what produces wealth, use, clothing, and food. Indeed, the people consider it in their hearts and declare it with their mouths, complete it and do it. If their mouths are dammed, how much can it endure?' The king did not listen. Thus none in the state dared speak out. After three years, they mutually rebelled and attacked King Li. King Li fled to Zhi.

sentences.zh: 厲王太子靜匿召公之家，國人聞之，乃圍之。

translations.literal: King Li's crown prince Jing hid in Duke Zhao's house. The people of the state heard of it, then surrounded it.
translations.idiomatic: King Li's crown prince Jing took refuge in Duke Zhao's home. When the people learned of this, they besieged it.

sentences.zh: 召公曰：「昔吾驟諫王，王不從，以及此難也。

translations.literal: Duke Zhao said: 'Formerly I repeatedly advised the king. The king did not follow, and thus reached this calamity.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Zhao said: 'I repeatedly counseled the king before. He would not listen, and thus brought about this disaster.

sentences.zh: 今殺王太子，王其以我為讎而懟怒乎？

translations.literal: Now if they kill the king's crown prince, will the king consider me an enemy and be resentful and angry?
translations.idiomatic: If they kill the king's heir now, will the king regard me as his foe and harbor lasting resentment?

sentences.zh: 夫事君者，險而不讎懟，怨而不怒，況事王乎！」

translations.literal: Indeed those who serve a lord, in danger do not become enemies and resentful, resentful but not angry. How much more so serving a king!'
translations.idiomatic: Those who serve a ruler face peril without becoming bitter enemies, harbor resentment without rage. How much more so when serving a king!'

sentences.zh: 乃以其子代王太子，太子竟得脫。

translations.literal: Then he used his own son to substitute for the king's crown prince. The crown prince finally escaped.
translations.idiomatic: He offered his own son as substitute for the crown prince. The heir at last got away safely.

translations.literal: King Li's crown prince Jing hid in Zhao Gong's home. The people of the state heard this and surrounded it. Zhao Gong said: 'Formerly I repeatedly advised the king. The king did not follow, and we have reached this difficulty. Now if we kill the king's crown prince, will the king consider me an enemy and resentfully be angry? Indeed, serving a ruler: perilous but not treating as enemy with resentment, resentful but not angry. How much more serving a king!' Then he used his own son to substitute for the king's crown prince. The crown prince finally escaped.

sentences.zh: 召公、周公二相行政，號曰「共和」。

translations.literal: Duke Zhao and Duke Zhou, two ministers, administered government, called it 'Gong He.'
translations.idiomatic: Dukes Zhao and Zhou, the two ministers, jointly governed, naming the era 'Gong He.'

sentences.zh: 共和十四年，厲王死于彘。

translations.literal: Fourteenth year of Gong He, King Li died at Zhi.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourteenth year of Gong He, King Li died in exile at Zhi.

sentences.zh: 太子靜長於召公家，二相乃共立之為王，是為宣王。

translations.literal: Crown prince Jing grew up in Duke Zhao's house. The two ministers then together established him as king. He was called King Xuan.
translations.idiomatic: Crown prince Jing came of age in Duke Zhao's home. The two ministers jointly enthroned him as king. He was known as King Xuan.

sentences.zh: 宣王即位，二相輔之，修政，法文、武、成、康之遺風，諸侯復宗周。

translations.literal: King Xuan ascended the throne. The two ministers assisted him, repaired government, imitated the remaining ways of Wen, Wu, Cheng, Kang. The feudal lords again honored Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: King Xuan ascended the throne with the two ministers as his advisors. They reformed governance, following the legacies of Wen, Wu, Cheng, and Kang. The lords once more acknowledged Zhou's supremacy.

sentences.zh: 十二年，魯武公來朝。

translations.literal: Twelfth year, Lu Wu Gong came to court.
translations.idiomatic: In the twelfth year, Duke Wu of Lu came to pay homage.

translations.literal: Zhao Gong and Zhou Gong, the two ministers, administered the government. It was titled 'Republican.' In the fourteenth year of the Republican period, King Li died at Zhi. Crown prince Jing grew up in Zhao Gong's home. The two ministers then jointly established him as king. He was called King Xuan. King Xuan ascended the throne. The two ministers assisted him, repaired the government, and imitated the remaining customs of Wen, Wu, Cheng, and Kang. The feudal lords again revered Zhou. In the twelfth year, Lu Wu Gong came to court.

sentences.zh: 宣王不修籍於千畝，虢文公諫曰不可，王弗聽。

translations.literal: King Xuan did not maintain the boundaries at Qianmu. Duke Wen of Guo advised it was not possible. The king did not listen.
translations.idiomatic: King Xuan neglected the field boundaries at Qianmu. Duke Wen of Guo warned this was unwise. The king paid no heed.

sentences.zh: 三十九年，戰于千畝，王師敗績于姜氏之戎。

translations.literal: Thirty-ninth year, battled at Qianmu. The king's army suffered defeat at the hands of the Jiang clan's Rong.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirty-ninth year, they fought at Qianmu. The royal army was routed by the Jiang Rong barbarians.

translations.literal: King Xuan did not repair the registry at the thousand mu. Guo Wen Gong advised that it was not possible. The king did not listen. In the thirty-ninth year, they fought at the thousand mu. The king's army was defeated by the Jiang clan Rong.

sentences.zh: 宣王既亡南國之師，乃料民於太原。

translations.literal: King Xuan having lost the southern region's army, then took census of the people at Taiyuan.
translations.idiomatic: After losing the southern army, King Xuan conducted a population census at Taiyuan.

sentences.zh: 仲山甫諫曰：「民不可料也。」

translations.literal: Zhong Shan Fu advised: 'The people cannot be censused.'
translations.idiomatic: Zhong Shan Fu counseled: 'The people should not be counted.'

sentences.zh: 宣王不聽，卒料民。

translations.literal: King Xuan did not listen, in the end censused the people.
translations.idiomatic: King Xuan refused to listen and proceeded with the census.

translations.literal: King Xuan had already lost the army of the southern states, so he tallied the people at Taiyuan. Zhong Shan Fu advised: 'The people cannot be tallied.' King Xuan did not listen. He finally tallied the people.

sentences.zh: 四十六年，宣王崩，子幽王宮湦立。

translations.literal: Forty-sixth year, King Xuan passed away. Son King You Gong Shen established.
translations.idiomatic: In the forty-sixth year, King Xuan died. His son King You Gong Shen ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 幽王二年，西周三川皆震。

translations.literal: King You's second year, Western Zhou's three rivers all shook.
translations.idiomatic: In King You's second year, all three rivers in Western Zhou suffered earthquakes.

sentences.zh: 伯陽甫曰：「周將亡矣。

translations.literal: Bo Yang Fu said: 'Zhou is about to perish.
translations.idiomatic: Bo Yang Fu declared: 'Zhou is doomed to fall.

sentences.zh: 夫天地之氣，不失其序；

translations.literal: Indeed Heaven and Earth's qi do not lose their order.
translations.idiomatic: The vital energies of Heaven and Earth maintain their proper sequence.

sentences.zh: 若過其序，民亂之也。

translations.literal: If they exceed their order, the people disorder them.
translations.idiomatic: When they transgress this order, it is because the people have thrown them into chaos.

sentences.zh: 陽伏而不能出，陰迫而不能蒸，於是有地震。

translations.literal: Yang lies hidden and cannot emerge, yin presses and cannot ascend, thus there are earthquakes.
translations.idiomatic: Yang energy lies dormant unable to rise, yin energy is compressed unable to circulate—hence earthquakes occur.

sentences.zh: 今三川實震，是陽失其所而填陰也。

translations.literal: Now the three rivers truly shake, this is yang losing its place and filling yin.
translations.idiomatic: Now all three rivers tremble—this means yang has lost its proper domain and yin has overrun it.

sentences.zh: 陽失而在陰，原必塞；

translations.literal: Yang lost and in yin, the sources must block.
translations.idiomatic: With yang displaced into yin's realm, the springs must become obstructed.

sentences.zh: 原塞，國必亡。

translations.literal: Sources blocked, the state must perish.
translations.idiomatic: Springs obstructed, the nation must fall.

sentences.zh: 夫水土演而民用也。

translations.literal: Indeed water and soil spread and the people use them.
translations.idiomatic: Water and soil flow freely for the people's benefit.

sentences.zh: 土無所演，民乏財用，不亡何待！

translations.literal: Soil has nowhere to spread, the people lack wealth and resources. If not perish, what to wait for!
translations.idiomatic: If soil cannot spread, people lack resources and livelihood. If the nation does not fall, what are we waiting for!

sentences.zh: 昔伊、洛竭而夏亡，河竭而商亡。

translations.literal: Formerly the Yi and Luo dried up and Xia perished, the River dried up and Yin perished.
translations.idiomatic: In ancient times, when the Yi and Luo rivers ran dry, Xia fell; when the Yellow River dried up, Shang perished.

sentences.zh: 今周德若二代之季矣，其川原又塞，塞必竭。

translations.literal: Now Zhou's virtue is like the two dynasties' end. Their rivers and sources again block. Blocked must dry up.
translations.idiomatic: Now Zhou's moral standing resembles the final days of those two dynasties. Their rivers and springs are obstructed once more. Obstructed, they must run dry.

sentences.zh: 夫國必依山川，山崩川竭，亡國之徵也。

translations.literal: Indeed states must rely on mountains and rivers. Mountains collapse rivers dry up, signs of perishing states.
translations.idiomatic: Nations depend upon mountains and rivers. When mountains crumble and rivers run dry—these are omens of a doomed state.

sentences.zh: 川竭必山崩。

translations.literal: Rivers dry up, mountains must collapse.
translations.idiomatic: When rivers run dry, mountains inevitably crumble.

sentences.zh: 若國亡不過十年，數之紀也。

translations.literal: If the state perishes, no more than ten years. The number's limit.
translations.idiomatic: The nation's fall will come within ten years—a cyclical limit ordained by fate.

sentences.zh: 天之所棄，不過其紀。」

translations.literal: Heaven's abandoned ones do not exceed their limit.'
translations.idiomatic: Those whom Heaven has forsaken do not outlast their allotted span.'

sentences.zh: 是歲也，三川竭，岐山崩。

translations.literal: This year, the three rivers dried up, Mount Qi collapsed.
translations.idiomatic: That very year, all three rivers ran dry and Mount Qi crumbled.

translations.literal: In the forty-sixth year, King Xuan collapsed. His son King You Gong Ning was established. In King You's second year, all three rivers of western Zhou shook. Bo Yang Fu said: 'Zhou will perish. Indeed, the qi of heaven and earth does not lose its order; If it exceeds its order, the people have caused the chaos. When yang is hidden and cannot emerge, yin is pressed and cannot steam, then there are earthquakes. Now the three rivers actually shake—this is yang losing its place and filling yin. When yang is lost and in yin, the sources are certainly blocked; When sources are blocked, the state certainly perishes. Indeed, when water and earth spread, the people use them. When earth spreads nowhere, the people lack wealth and use. If it does not perish, what does it wait for! Formerly when the Yi and Luo dried up, Xia perished. When the river dried up, Shang perished. Now Zhou's virtue is like the end of the two dynasties. Their rivers and sources are again blocked. When blocked, they certainly dry up. Indeed, states certainly rely on mountains and rivers. Mountains collapsing and rivers drying are omens of a perished state. When rivers dry, mountains certainly collapse. If the state perishes, it will not exceed ten years—the record of numbers. What heaven has abandoned does not exceed its record.' This year, the three rivers dried up and Mount Qi collapsed.

sentences.zh: 三年，幽王嬖愛褒姒。

translations.literal: Third year, King You doted on and loved Bao Si.
translations.idiomatic: In the third year, King You became infatuated with Bao Si.

sentences.zh: 褒姒生子伯服，幽王欲廢太子。

translations.literal: Bao Si gave birth to son Bo Fu. King You wished to depose the crown prince.
translations.idiomatic: Bao Si bore him a son named Bo Fu. King You desired to set aside the crown prince.

sentences.zh: 太子母申侯女，而為后。

translations.literal: The crown prince's mother was Shen Hou's daughter, and was queen.
translations.idiomatic: The crown prince's mother was the daughter of the Marquis of Shen, and served as queen.

sentences.zh: 後幽王得褒姒，愛之，欲廢申后，并去太子宜臼，以褒姒為后，以伯服為太子。

translations.literal: Later King You obtained Bao Si, loved her, wished to depose Queen Shen, and also remove Crown Prince Yi Jiu, to make Bao Si queen, and Bo Fu crown prince.
translations.idiomatic: Later King You acquired Bao Si and became enamored of her. He desired to depose Queen Shen and remove Crown Prince Yi Jiu, installing Bao Si as queen and Bo Fu as heir.

sentences.zh: 周太史伯陽讀史記曰：「周亡矣。」

translations.literal: Zhou Grand Historian Bo Yang read the historical records and said: 'Zhou is finished.'
translations.idiomatic: The Zhou Grand Historian Bo Yang perused the ancient records and declared: 'Zhou is doomed.'

sentences.zh: 昔自夏后氏之衰也，有二神龍止於夏帝庭而言曰：「余，褒之二君。」

translations.literal: Formerly from the Xia Hou clan's decline, there were two spirit dragons that halted in the Xia emperor's court and spoke saying: 'We are Bao's two lords.'
translations.idiomatic: In ancient times, during the decline of the Xia dynasty, two divine dragons appeared in the Xia emperor's courtyard and declared: 'We are the two rulers of Bao.'

sentences.zh: 夏帝卜殺之與去之與止之，莫吉。

translations.literal: The Xia emperor divined killing them or expelling them or keeping them. None auspicious.
translations.idiomatic: The Xia emperor consulted the oracle about killing them, driving them away, or letting them stay. None of the divinations proved favorable.

sentences.zh: 卜請其漦而藏之，乃吉。

translations.literal: Divined requesting their saliva and storing it, then auspicious.
translations.idiomatic: The divination for requesting their saliva and preserving it proved favorable.

sentences.zh: 於是布幣而策告之，龍亡而漦在，櫝而去之。

translations.literal: Thus spread silks and informed them with tablets. The dragons departed and saliva remained. Boxed and removed it.
translations.idiomatic: Thus they spread silken offerings and notified the dragons with inscribed tablets. The dragons vanished but left their saliva behind. They sealed it in a casket and stored it away.

sentences.zh: 夏亡，傳此器殷。

translations.literal: Xia perished, transmitted this vessel to Yin.
translations.idiomatic: When Xia fell, this relic was passed to the Shang dynasty.

sentences.zh: 殷亡，又傳此器周。

translations.literal: Yin perished, again transmitted this vessel to Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: When Shang fell, this relic was passed once more to the Zhou dynasty.

sentences.zh: 比三代，莫敢發之，至厲王之末，發而觀之。

translations.literal: Through the three dynasties, none dared open it. Until King Li's end, opened and viewed it.
translations.idiomatic: Throughout the three dynasties, none dared to open it. Only at the end of King Li's reign was it opened and examined.

sentences.zh: 漦流于庭，不可除。

translations.literal: The saliva flowed in the courtyard, could not be removed.
translations.idiomatic: The saliva spread across the courtyard and could not be cleared away.

sentences.zh: 厲王使婦人裸而譟之。

translations.literal: King Li had women strip naked and shout at it.
translations.idiomatic: King Li commanded women to bare themselves and clamor at the substance.

sentences.zh: 漦化為玄黿，以入王後宮。

translations.literal: The saliva transformed into a black tortoise, entering the king's rear palace.
translations.idiomatic: The saliva metamorphosed into a dark tortoise that entered the king's inner chambers.

sentences.zh: 後宮之童妾既齔而遭之，既笄而孕，無夫而生子，懼而棄之。

translations.literal: The rear palace's young concubine, having grown teeth, encountered it. Having hair bound, became pregnant. Without husband gave birth to child. Feared and abandoned it.
translations.idiomatic: A young concubine in the inner palace, having just reached puberty, encountered the tortoise. She became pregnant and, without a husband, bore a child. Terrified, she abandoned the infant.

sentences.zh: 宣王之時童女謠曰：「厭弧箕服，實亡周國。」

translations.literal: In King Xuan's time, young girls chanted: 'Arc-foot Ji's garment will truly destroy Zhou state.'
translations.idiomatic: During King Xuan's reign, young girls sang a rhyme: 'The curved bow and winnowing basket's garb will surely ruin Zhou.'

sentences.zh: 於是宣王聞之，有夫婦賣是器者，宣王使執而戮之。

translations.literal: Thus King Xuan heard it. There were a husband and wife selling this vessel. King Xuan had them seized and executed.
translations.idiomatic: Thus King Xuan learned of the prophecy. A couple was selling the relic. King Xuan had them arrested and put to death.

sentences.zh: 逃於道，而見鄉者後宮童妾所棄妖子出於路者，聞其夜啼，哀而收之，夫婦遂亡，奔於褒。

translations.literal: Fled on the road, and saw villagers—the rear palace young concubine's abandoned monstrous child emerging on the road. Heard its night crying, pitied and took it. Husband and wife then fled, ran to Bao.
translations.idiomatic: They fled along the road and encountered villagers—the inner palace concubine's abandoned monstrous child lying in the path. Hearing its nighttime wailing, they took pity and gathered it up. The couple then absconded, fleeing to the state of Bao.

sentences.zh: 褒人有罪，請入童妾所棄女子者於王以贖罪。

translations.literal: The Bao people had crime, requested presenting the young concubine's abandoned girl to the king to redeem the crime.
translations.idiomatic: The people of Bao, guilty of some offense, offered to present the abandoned girl to the king as atonement for their crime.

sentences.zh: 棄女子出於褒，是為褒姒。

translations.literal: The abandoned girl came from Bao. She was Bao Si.
translations.idiomatic: The abandoned girl originated from Bao. She became known as Bao Si.

sentences.zh: 當幽王三年，王之後宮見而愛之，生子伯服，竟廢申后及太子，以褒姒為后，伯服為太子。

translations.literal: In King You's third year, the king's rear palace saw and loved her. She gave birth to son Bo Fu. In the end deposed Queen Shen and the crown prince, made Bao Si queen, Bo Fu crown prince.
translations.idiomatic: In King You's third year, the women of his inner palace beheld her and adored her. She bore him a son named Bo Fu. Ultimately he deposed Queen Shen and the crown prince, installing Bao Si as queen and Bo Fu as heir.

sentences.zh: 太史伯陽曰：「禍成矣，無可奈何！」

translations.literal: Grand Historian Bo Yang said: 'Calamity is complete, nothing can be done!'
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian Bo Yang declared: 'Disaster is upon us—nothing can be done about it now!'

translations.literal: In the third year, King You favored and loved Bao Si. Bao Si gave birth to a son named Bo Fu. King You wished to depose the crown prince. The crown prince's mother was a woman of Shen Hou, and she was the queen. Later King You got Bao Si and loved her. He wished to depose the Shen queen and remove the crown prince Yi Jiu, making Bao Si the queen and Bo Fu the crown prince. Zhou's grand historian Bo Yang read the history records and said: 'Zhou has perished.' Formerly, when the Xia Hou clan declined, two spirit dragons stopped in the Xia emperor's court and spoke, saying: 'We are Bao's two lords.' The Xia emperor divined whether to kill them, drive them away, or let them stay. None were auspicious. He divined to request their saliva and store it, and then it was auspicious. Thus he spread silks and bamboo to announce it. The dragons were gone but the saliva remained. He boxed it and removed it. Xia perished, and this vessel was passed to Yin. Yin perished, and this vessel was again passed to Zhou. Compared to the three dynasties, none dared open it. Until the end of King Li's reign, it was opened and viewed. The saliva flowed in the court and could not be removed. King Li made women go naked and shout at it. The saliva transformed into a black turtle and entered the king's harem. A young concubine in the harem, already with teeth, encountered it. Already with hairpin, she became pregnant. Without a husband, she gave birth to a son. She feared it and abandoned him. In King Xuan's time, a young girl made a rhyme saying: 'Bows are bent, Ji is served—it actually perishes the Zhou state.' Thus King Xuan heard of it. There was a couple selling this vessel. King Xuan had them seized and executed. They fled on the road and saw a villager's harem young concubine abandoned monster child emerged on the road. They heard its night crying, pitied it and took it. The couple then fled and ran to Bao. A Bao person had committed a crime. He requested to present the young concubine abandoned girl to the king to redeem his crime. The abandoned girl emerged from Bao. She was Bao Si. During King You's third year, the king's harem saw her and loved her. She gave birth to a son named Bo Fu. He finally deposed the Shen queen and crown prince, making Bao Si the queen and Bo Fu the crown prince. Grand Historian Bo Yang said: 'The disaster is complete. Nothing can be done!'

sentences.zh: 褒姒不好笑，幽王欲其笑萬方，故不笑。

translations.literal: Bao Si did not like to laugh. King You wished her to laugh by any means, thus she did not laugh.
translations.idiomatic: Bao Si never smiled. King You desperately wanted to make her laugh, but she remained unsmiling.

sentences.zh: 幽王為烽燧大鼓，有寇至則舉烽火。

translations.literal: King You made beacon fires great drums. When bandits arrived then raised beacon fires.
translations.idiomatic: King You constructed beacon towers and great drums. When enemies approached, the beacons would be lit.

sentences.zh: 諸侯悉至，至而無寇，褒姒乃大笑。

translations.literal: The feudal lords all arrived. Arrived and no bandits. Bao Si then laughed greatly.
translations.idiomatic: All the lords rushed to his aid. When they arrived to find no enemy, Bao Si burst into laughter.

sentences.zh: 幽王說之，為數舉烽火。

translations.literal: King You delighted in it, repeatedly raised beacon fires.
translations.idiomatic: King You was thrilled by this and repeatedly lit the beacons as a joke.

sentences.zh: 其後不信，諸侯益亦不至。

translations.literal: Thereafter not believed, the feudal lords increasingly also did not come.
translations.idiomatic: Henceforth the beacons were not trusted, and the lords increasingly failed to respond.

translations.literal: Bao Si was not good at laughing. King You wished her to laugh in ten thousand ways, so she did not laugh. King You made beacon fires and great drums. When bandits arrived, they would raise the beacon fires. All the feudal lords arrived. They arrived and there were no bandits. Bao Si then greatly laughed. King You was pleased by it. He raised the beacon fires several times. Afterwards it was not trusted. The feudal lords increasingly also did not come.

sentences.zh: 幽王以虢石父為卿，用事，國人皆怨。

translations.literal: King You made Guo Shi Fu Chief Minister, handled affairs. The people of the state all resented.
translations.idiomatic: King You appointed Guo Shi Fu as Chief Minister to govern affairs. All the people grew resentful.

sentences.zh: 石父為人佞巧善諛好利，王用之。

translations.literal: Shi Fu was a person flattering clever good at fawning loved profit. The king employed him.
translations.idiomatic: Shi Fu was a cunning flatterer who excelled at sycophancy and loved gain. The king relied upon him.

sentences.zh: 又廢申后，去太子也。

translations.literal: Again deposed Queen Shen, removed the crown prince also.
translations.idiomatic: He further deposed Queen Shen and banished the crown prince as well.

sentences.zh: 申侯怒，與繒、西夷犬戎攻幽王。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Shen angered, joined with Zeng and western barbarian Quanrong attacked King You.
translations.idiomatic: The Marquis of Shen, enraged, allied with Zeng and the western Quanrong barbarians to attack King You.

sentences.zh: 幽王舉烽火徵兵，兵莫至。

translations.literal: King You raised beacon fires summoned troops. Troops none arrived.
translations.idiomatic: King You lit the beacons and called for troops. No soldiers came.

sentences.zh: 遂殺幽王驪山下，虜褒姒，盡取周賂而去。

translations.literal: Then killed King You below Mount Li, captured Bao Si, completely took Zhou treasures and departed.
translations.idiomatic: Thus they slew King You at the foot of Mount Li, abducted Bao Si, plundered all Zhou's treasures, and departed.

sentences.zh: 於是諸侯乃即申侯而共立故幽王太子宜臼，是為平王，以奉周祀。

translations.literal: Thus the feudal lords then approached the Marquis of Shen and together established the former King You's crown prince Yi Jiu. He was called King Ping, to uphold Zhou sacrifices.
translations.idiomatic: Thus the lords went to the Marquis of Shen and jointly enthroned the former King You's crown prince Yi Jiu. He became King Ping, to maintain the Zhou ancestral rites.

translations.literal: King You made Guo Shi Fu the chief minister to handle affairs. All the people of the state resented this. Shi Fu as a person was flattering and clever, good at flattery and liked profit. The king used him. He again deposed the Shen queen and removed the crown prince as well. Shen Hou was angry. Together with Zeng and the western Yi Quanrong, he attacked King You. King You raised the beacon fires to summon troops. No troops arrived. Then they killed King You below Mount Li, captured Bao Si, completely took Zhou's treasures and left. Thus the feudal lords then approached Shen Hou and jointly established the former King You's crown prince Yi Jiu. He was Ping Wang, to serve the Zhou sacrifices.

sentences.zh: 平王立，東遷于雒邑，辟戎寇。

translations.literal: King Ping established, eastward migrated to Luoyi, avoided the Rong bandits.
translations.idiomatic: King Ping ascended and moved the capital eastward to Luoyi to escape the barbarian invaders.

sentences.zh: 平王之時，周室衰微，諸侯彊并弱，齊、楚、秦、晉始大，政由方伯。

translations.literal: In King Ping's time, the Zhou house declined faintly. The feudal lords strong annexed weak. Qi, Chu, Qin, Jin began great. Government by regional lords.
translations.idiomatic: During King Ping's reign, the Zhou house grew feeble. The regional lords—the strong absorbed the weak. Qi, Chu, Qin, and Jin began their rise to greatness. Governance passed to the provincial rulers.

translations.literal: King Ping was established. He moved east to Luoyi to avoid the Rong bandits. In King Ping's time, the Zhou house declined and weakened. The feudal lords—the strong annexed the weak. Qi, Chu, Qin, and Jin began to grow great. Government came from the regional lords.

sentences.zh: 四十九年，魯隱公即位。

translations.literal: Forty-ninth year, Lu Yin Gong ascended the throne.
translations.idiomatic: In the forty-ninth year, Duke Yin of Lu ascended the throne.

translations.literal: In the forty-ninth year, Duke Yin of Lu took the throne.

sentences.zh: 五十一年，平王崩，太子洩父蚤死，立其子林，是為桓王。

translations.literal: Fifty-first year, King Ping passed away. Crown prince Xie Fu died early. Established his son Lin. He was called King Huan.
translations.idiomatic: In the fifty-first year, King Ping died. The crown prince Xie Fu had died prematurely. His son Lin was enthroned as King Huan.

sentences.zh: 桓王，平王孫也。

translations.literal: King Huan was King Ping's grandson.
translations.idiomatic: King Huan was King Ping's grandson.

translations.literal: In the fifty-first year, King Ping collapsed. The crown prince Xie Fu had died early. They established his son Lin. He was King Huan. King Huan was King Ping's grandson.

sentences.zh: 桓王三年，鄭莊公朝，桓王不禮。

translations.literal: King Huan third year, Zheng Zhuang Gong came to court. King Huan was not courteous.
translations.idiomatic: In King Huan's third year, Duke Zhuang of Zheng came to pay homage. King Huan treated him discourteously.

sentences.zh: 五年，鄭怨，與魯易許田。

translations.literal: Fifth year, Zheng resented, exchanged Xu fields with Lu.
translations.idiomatic: In the fifth year, Zheng grew resentful and traded the Xu fields with Lu.

sentences.zh: 許田，天子之用事太山田也。

translations.literal: Xu fields were the Son of Heaven's sacrificial Mount Tai fields.
translations.idiomatic: The Xu fields were the Son of Heaven's sacrificial lands at Mount Tai.

sentences.zh: 八年，魯殺隱公，立桓公。

translations.literal: Eighth year, Lu killed Yin Gong, established Huan Gong.
translations.idiomatic: In the eighth year, Lu assassinated Duke Yin and installed Duke Huan.

sentences.zh: 十三年，伐鄭，鄭射傷桓王，桓王去歸。

translations.literal: Thirteenth year, attacked Zheng. Zheng shot and wounded King Huan. King Huan departed and returned.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirteenth year, he campaigned against Zheng. Zheng archers wounded King Huan. King Huan withdrew and returned home.

translations.literal: In King Huan's third year, Duke Zhuang of Zheng came to court. King Huan was not courteous. In the fifth year, Zheng resented this and exchanged the Xu field with Lu. The Xu field was the field where the Son of Heaven handled affairs at Mount Tai. In the eighth year, Lu killed Duke Yin and established Duke Huan. In the thirteenth year, they attacked Zheng. Zheng shot and wounded King Huan. King Huan left and returned.

sentences.zh: 二十三年，桓王崩，子莊王佗立。

translations.literal: Twenty-third year, King Huan passed away. Son King Zhuang Tuo established.
translations.idiomatic: In the twenty-third year, King Huan died. His son King Zhuang Tuo ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 莊王四年，周公黑肩欲殺莊王而立王子克。

translations.literal: King Zhuang fourth year, Zhou Gong Hei Jian wished to kill King Zhuang and establish Prince Zi Ke.
translations.idiomatic: In King Zhuang's fourth year, the Duke Hei Jian plotted to assassinate King Zhuang and enthrone Prince Zi Ke.

sentences.zh: 辛伯告王，王殺周公。

translations.literal: Xin Bo informed the king. The king killed Zhou Gong.
translations.idiomatic: Xin Bo alerted the king. The king executed the Duke.

sentences.zh: 王子克奔燕。

translations.literal: Prince Zi Ke fled to Yan.
translations.idiomatic: Prince Zi Ke fled to Yan.

translations.literal: In the twenty-third year, King Huan collapsed. His son King Zhuang Tuo was established. In King Zhuang's fourth year, Zhou Gong Hei Jian wished to kill King Zhuang and establish Prince Ke. Xin Bo told the king. The king killed Zhou Gong. Prince Ke fled to Yan.

sentences.zh: 十五年，莊王崩，子釐王胡齊立。

translations.literal: Fifteenth year, King Zhuang passed away. Son King Xi Hu Qi established.
translations.idiomatic: In the fifteenth year, King Zhuang died. His son King Xi Hu Qi ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 釐王三年，齊桓公始霸。

translations.literal: King Xi third year, Qi Huan Gong began hegemony.
translations.idiomatic: In King Xi's third year, Duke Huan of Qi began his hegemony.

translations.literal: In the fifteenth year, King Zhuang collapsed. His son King Xi Hu Qi was established. In King Xi's third year, Duke Huan of Qi began his hegemony.

sentences.zh: 五年，釐王崩，子惠王閬立。

translations.literal: Fifth year, King Xi passed away. Son King Hui Lang established.
translations.idiomatic: In the fifth year, King Xi died. His son King Hui Lang ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 惠王二年。

translations.literal: King Hui second year.
translations.idiomatic: King Hui's second year.

sentences.zh: 初，莊王嬖姬姚，生子穨，穨有寵。
