translations.literal: Initially, King Zhuang favored concubine Yao, gave birth to son Sui, Sui had favor.
translations.idiomatic: At first, King Zhuang favored his concubine Yao. She bore him a son named Sui, who was much beloved.

sentences.zh: 及惠王即位，奪其大臣以為囿，故大夫邊伯等五人作亂，謀召燕、衛師，伐惠王。

translations.literal: When King Hui ascended the throne, seized his ministers to make a park, therefore grandee Bian Bo and others five people rebelled, plotted to summon Yan and Wei troops, attacked King Hui.
translations.idiomatic: When King Hui ascended the throne, he seized his ministers' lands to create a royal park. Thus five nobles led by Bian Bo rebelled, plotting to summon troops from Yan and Wei to attack King Hui.

sentences.zh: 惠王犇溫，已居鄭之櫟。

translations.literal: King Hui fled to Wen, then resided at Zheng's Yue.
translations.idiomatic: King Hui fled to Wen, then took refuge at Zheng's Yue.

sentences.zh: 立釐王弟穨為王。

translations.literal: Established King Xi's younger brother Sui as king.
translations.idiomatic: They enthroned King Xi's younger brother Sui as king.

sentences.zh: 樂及徧舞，鄭、虢君怒。

translations.literal: Music and universal dancing, Zheng and Guo lords angered.
translations.idiomatic: The music and universal dancing enraged the lords of Zheng and Guo.

sentences.zh: 四年，鄭與虢君伐殺王穨，復入惠王。

translations.literal: Fourth year, Zheng and Guo lords attacked and killed King Sui, again entered King Hui.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourth year, the lords of Zheng and Guo attacked and killed King Sui, restoring King Hui to the throne.

sentences.zh: 惠王十年，賜齊桓公為伯。

translations.literal: King Hui tenth year, granted Qi Huan Gong as Bo.
translations.idiomatic: In King Hui's tenth year, he granted Duke Huan of Qi the title of Bo (hegemon).

translations.literal: In the fifth year, King Xi collapsed. His son King Hui Lang was established. King Hui's second year. Initially, King Zhuang favored his concubine Yao. She gave birth to a son named Sui. Sui had favor. When King Hui took the throne, he seized his great minister's land to make a park. Therefore five great ministers including Bian Bo made rebellion. They plotted to summon Yan and Wei armies to attack King Hui. King Hui fled to Wen, and already resided in Zheng's Li. They established King Xi's younger brother Sui as king. The music reached universal dance. The lords of Zheng and Guo were angry. In the fourth year, Zheng together with the lord of Guo attacked and killed King Sui. They again entered King Hui. In King Hui's tenth year, he granted Duke Huan of Qi the title of Bo.

sentences.zh: 二十五年，惠王崩，子襄王鄭立。

translations.literal: Twenty-fifth year, King Hui passed away. Son King Xiang Zheng established.
translations.idiomatic: In the twenty-fifth year, King Hui died. His son King Xiang Zheng ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 襄王母蚤死，後母曰惠后。

translations.literal: King Xiang's mother died early, stepmother called Queen Hui.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang's mother died young, and his stepmother was known as Queen Hui.

sentences.zh: 惠后生叔帶，有寵於惠王，襄王畏之。

translations.literal: Queen Hui gave birth to Uncle Dai, had favor with King Hui. King Xiang feared him.
translations.idiomatic: Queen Hui bore a son named Uncle Dai, who was favored by King Hui. King Xiang lived in fear of him.

sentences.zh: 三年，叔帶與戎、翟謀伐襄王，襄王欲誅叔帶，叔帶奔齊。

translations.literal: Third year, Uncle Dai plotted with Rong and Di to attack King Xiang. King Xiang wished to execute Uncle Dai. Uncle Dai fled to Qi.
translations.idiomatic: In the third year, Uncle Dai conspired with the Rong and Di barbarians to attack King Xiang. King Xiang sought to execute Uncle Dai, who fled to Qi.

sentences.zh: 齊桓公使管仲平戎于周，使隰朋平戎于晉。

translations.literal: Qi Huan Gong sent Guan Zhong to pacify the Rong at Zhou, sent Xi Peng to pacify the Rong at Jin.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Huan of Qi dispatched Guan Zhong to pacify the Rong threat at Zhou, and sent Xi Peng to settle the Rong disturbances in Jin.

sentences.zh: 王以上卿禮管仲。

translations.literal: The king treated Guan Zhong with upper minister rites.
translations.idiomatic: The king honored Guan Zhong with the ceremonies due a chief minister.

sentences.zh: 管仲辭曰：「臣賤有司也，有天子之二守國、高在。

translations.literal: Guan Zhong declined saying: 'Your servant is a lowly functionary. There are the Son of Heaven's two guardians Guo and Gao present.
translations.idiomatic: Guan Zhong declined, saying: 'I am but a humble official. The Son of Heaven's two guardians, Guo and Gao, are present.

sentences.zh: 若節春秋來承王命，何以禮焉。

translations.literal: If in due seasons I come to receive the king's command, then how to treat me with ceremony.'
translations.idiomatic: If I come in the proper seasons to receive the king's commands, then treat me accordingly.'

sentences.zh: 陪臣敢辭。」

translations.literal: This vassal dares to decline.'
translations.idiomatic: This humble servant dares to decline the honor.'

sentences.zh: 王曰：「舅氏，余嘉乃勳，毋逆朕命。」

translations.literal: The king said: 'Uncle, I praise your merit. Do not oppose Our command.'
translations.idiomatic: The king replied: 'My maternal uncle, I commend your achievements. Do not defy Our decree.'

sentences.zh: 管仲卒受下卿之禮而還。

translations.literal: Guan Zhong finally accepted the lower minister rites and returned.
translations.idiomatic: Guan Zhong ultimately accepted the honors of a junior minister and departed.

sentences.zh: 九年，齊桓公卒。

translations.literal: Ninth year, Qi Huan Gong died.
translations.idiomatic: In the ninth year, Duke Huan of Qi passed away.

sentences.zh: 十二年，叔帶復歸于周。

translations.literal: Twelfth year, Uncle Dai again returned to Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: In the twelfth year, Uncle Dai returned once more to Zhou.

translations.literal: In the twenty-fifth year, King Hui collapsed. His son King Xiang Zheng was established. King Xiang's mother died early. His stepmother was called Empress Hui. Empress Hui gave birth to Uncle Dai. He had favor with King Hui. King Xiang feared him. In the third year, Uncle Dai together with the Rong and Di plotted to attack King Xiang. King Xiang wished to execute Uncle Dai. Uncle Dai fled to Qi. Duke Huan of Qi sent Guan Zhong to pacify the Rong at Zhou and sent Xi Peng to pacify the Rong at Jin. The king treated Guan Zhong with the rites of an upper minister. Guan Zhong declined and said: 'Your minister is a lowly official. The Son of Heaven has two guardians—Guo and Gao are present. If I come according to the seasons of spring and autumn to receive the king's commands, how should I be treated with rites? This attendant minister dares to decline.' The king said: 'Maternal uncle, I praise your merits. Do not oppose my commands.' Guan Zhong finally accepted the rites of a lower minister and returned. In the ninth year, Duke Huan of Qi died. In the twelfth year, Uncle Dai again returned to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 十三年，鄭伐滑，王使游孫、伯服請滑，鄭人囚之。

translations.literal: Thirteenth year, Zheng attacked Hua. The king sent You Sun and Bo Fu to request Hua. Zheng people imprisoned them.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirteenth year, Zheng attacked Hua. The king dispatched You Sun and Bo Fu to petition for Hua's release. The Zheng imprisoned them.

sentences.zh: 鄭文公怨惠王之入不與厲公爵，又怨襄王之與衛滑，故囚伯服。

translations.literal: Zheng Wen Gong resented King Hui's entry not giving Li Gong the title, also resented King Xiang's giving Wei Hua, therefore imprisoned Bo Fu.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Wen of Zheng resented King Hui's restoration for not granting Duke Li his title, and resented King Xiang's gift of Wei Hua to Zheng. Thus he imprisoned Bo Fu.

sentences.zh: 王怒，將以翟伐鄭。

translations.literal: The king angered, was about to use Di to attack Zheng.
translations.idiomatic: The king grew furious and prepared to use Di forces to attack Zheng.

sentences.zh: 富辰諫曰：「凡我周之東徙，晉、鄭焉依。

translations.literal: Fu Chen advised: 'In general our Zhou's eastern migration, Jin and Zheng are what we rely on.
translations.idiomatic: Fu Chen counseled: 'Since our Zhou moved eastward, Jin and Zheng have been our chief supports.

sentences.zh: 子穨之亂，又鄭之由定，今以小怨棄之！」

translations.literal: The Sui rebellion, moreover Zheng's assistance in settling it. Now because of small resentment abandon them!'
translations.idiomatic: During the Sui rebellion, Zheng helped settle matters. Now to abandon them over petty grievances!'

sentences.zh: 王不聽。

translations.literal: The king did not listen.
translations.idiomatic: The king paid no heed.

sentences.zh: 十五年，王降翟師以伐鄭。

translations.literal: Fifteenth year, the king led Di troops to attack Zheng.
translations.idiomatic: In the fifteenth year, the king commanded Di forces to attack Zheng.

sentences.zh: 王德翟人，將以其女為后。

translations.literal: The king favored the Di people, was about to take their daughter as queen.
translations.idiomatic: The king grew fond of the Di people and planned to take their daughter as his queen.

sentences.zh: 富辰諫曰：「平、桓、莊、惠皆受鄭勞，王棄親親翟，不可從。」

translations.literal: Fu Chen advised: 'Ping, Huan, Zhuang, Hui all received Zheng's toil. The king abandons close kin for Di, cannot follow.'
translations.idiomatic: Fu Chen counseled: 'Kings Ping, Huan, Zhuang, and Hui all benefited from Zheng's efforts. For the king to abandon kin for Di allies is inadvisable.'

sentences.zh: 王不聽。

translations.literal: The king did not listen.
translations.idiomatic: The king refused to listen.

sentences.zh: 十六年，王絀翟后，翟人來誅，殺譚伯。

translations.literal: Sixteenth year, the king deposed the Di queen. Di people came to punish, killed Tan Bo.
translations.idiomatic: In the sixteenth year, the king deposed the Di queen. The Di came seeking vengeance and killed Lord Tan.

sentences.zh: 富辰曰：「吾數諫不從。

translations.literal: Fu Chen said: 'I repeatedly advised but was not followed.
translations.idiomatic: Fu Chen declared: 'I counseled repeatedly but was ignored.

sentences.zh: 如是不出，王以我為懟乎？」

translations.literal: If like this I do not go out, will the king consider me resentful?'
translations.idiomatic: If I remain hidden like this, will the king think me disloyal?'

sentences.zh: 乃以其屬死之。

translations.literal: Then he died with his retainers.
translations.idiomatic: Thus he perished along with his followers.

translations.literal: In the thirteenth year, Zheng attacked Hua. The king sent You Sun and Bo Fu to petition for Hua. The Zheng people imprisoned them. Duke Wen of Zheng resented that King Hui's entry did not give nobility to Duke Li, and also resented that King Xiang gave Wei Hua. Therefore he imprisoned Bo Fu. The king was angry. He would attack Zheng with the Di. Fu Chen advised and said: 'For all our Zhou's eastern migration, Jin and Zheng are what we relied on. For Zi Sui's rebellion, Zheng was what stabilized it. Now with small resentment we abandon it!' The king did not listen. In the fifteenth year, the king brought down Di armies to attack Zheng. The king favored the Di people. He would take their daughter as queen. Fu Chen advised and said: 'Kings Ping, Huan, Zhuang, and Hui all received toil from Zheng. The king abandons his close kin for the Di—this cannot be followed.' The king did not listen. In the sixteenth year, the king deposed the Di queen. The Di people came to punish him and killed Tan Bo. Fu Chen said: 'I repeatedly advised but was not followed. If I don't go out like this, will the king resent me?' Then with his followers he died for it.

sentences.zh: 初，惠后欲立王子帶，故以黨開翟人，翟人遂入周。

translations.literal: Initially, Queen Hui wished to establish Prince Zi Dai, therefore with faction opened the Di people. Di people then entered Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: At first, Queen Hui desired to enthrone Prince Zi Dai, so through her faction she invited the Di people. The Di then invaded Zhou.

sentences.zh: 襄王出奔鄭，鄭居王于汜。

translations.literal: King Xiang fled to Zheng. Zheng housed the king at Si.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang fled to Zheng. Zheng provided him refuge at Si.

sentences.zh: 子帶立為王，取襄王所絀翟后與居溫。

translations.literal: Zi Dai established himself as king, took King Xiang's deposed Di queen and dwelt with her at Wen.
translations.idiomatic: Zi Dai enthroned himself as king, took King Xiang's discarded Di queen and lived with her at Wen.

sentences.zh: 十七年，襄王告急于晉，晉文公納王而誅叔帶。

translations.literal: Seventeenth year, King Xiang appealed urgently to Jin. Jin Wen Gong received the king and executed Uncle Dai.
translations.idiomatic: In the seventeenth year, King Xiang sent desperate pleas to Jin. Duke Wen of Jin welcomed the king and executed Uncle Dai.

sentences.zh: 襄王乃賜晉文公珪鬯弓矢，為伯，以河內地與晉。

translations.literal: King Xiang then granted Jin Wen Gong gui, chang, bows and arrows, made him Bo, gave the lands within the river to Jin.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang then bestowed upon Duke Wen of Jin the ritual jade, libation vessels, bows and arrows, appointing him hegemon, and ceded the lands south of the Yellow River to Jin.

sentences.zh: 二十年，晉文公召襄王，襄王會之河陽、踐土，諸侯畢朝，書諱曰「天王狩于河陽」。

translations.literal: Twentieth year, Jin Wen Gong summoned King Xiang. King Xiang met him at Heyang, Jiantu. Feudal lords all came to court. The records euphemistically said 'The Heavenly King hunted at Heyang.'
translations.idiomatic: In the twentieth year, Duke Wen of Jin summoned King Xiang. King Xiang met him at Heyang and Jiantu. All the lords paid homage. The chronicles delicately recorded: 'The Son of Heaven hunted at Heyang.'

translations.literal: Initially, Empress Hui wished to establish Prince Dai. Therefore with her faction she opened the way for the Di people. The Di people then entered Zhou. King Xiang fled to Zheng. Zheng housed the king at Si. Zi Dai was established as king. He took the Di queen whom Xiang Wang had deposed and resided with her at Wen. In the seventeenth year, King Xiang urgently appealed to Jin. Duke Wen of Jin received the king and executed Uncle Dai. King Xiang then granted Duke Wen of Jin the gui, chang, bow, and arrows, making him Bo. He gave the land within the Yellow River to Jin. In the twentieth year, Duke Wen of Jin summoned King Xiang. King Xiang met him at Heyang and Jiantu. All the feudal lords came to court. The annals euphemistically said 'The Heavenly King hunted at Heyang'.

sentences.zh: 二十四年，晉文公卒。

translations.literal: Twenty-fourth year, Jin Wen Gong died.
translations.idiomatic: In the twenty-fourth year, Duke Wen of Jin passed away.

translations.literal: In the twenty-fourth year, Duke Wen of Jin died.

sentences.zh: 三十一年，秦穆公卒。

translations.literal: Thirty-first year, Qin Mu Gong died.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirty-first year, Duke Mu of Qin passed away.

translations.literal: In the thirty-first year, Duke Mu of Qin died.

sentences.zh: 三十二年，襄王崩，子頃王壬臣立。

translations.literal: Thirty-second year, King Xiang passed away. Son King Qing Ren Chen established.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirty-second year, King Xiang died. His son King Qing Ren Chen ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 頃王六年，崩，子匡王班立。

translations.literal: King Qing sixth year, passed away. Son King Kuang Ban established.
translations.idiomatic: In King Qing's sixth year, he died. His son King Kuang Ban ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 匡王六年，崩，弟瑜立，是為定王。

translations.literal: King Kuang sixth year, passed away. Younger brother Yu established. He was called King Ding.
translations.idiomatic: In King Kuang's sixth year, he died. His younger brother Yu ascended. He was known as King Ding.

translations.literal: In the thirty-second year, King Xiang collapsed. His son King Qing Ren Chen was established. In King Qing's sixth year, he collapsed. His son King Kuang Ban was established. In King Kuang's sixth year, he collapsed. His younger brother Yu was established. He was King Ding.

sentences.zh: 定王元年，楚莊王伐陸渾之戎，次洛，使人問九鼎。

translations.literal: King Ding first year, Chu Zhuang Wang attacked Luhun's Rong, halted at Luo, sent people to inquire about the nine tripods.
translations.idiomatic: In King Ding's first year, King Zhuang of Chu attacked the Rong of Luhun, encamped at Luo, and dispatched envoys to inquire about the nine sacred tripods.

sentences.zh: 王使王孫滿應設以辭，楚兵乃去。

translations.literal: The king sent Wangsun Man to respond with prepared words. Chu troops then departed.
translations.idiomatic: The king dispatched Wangsun Man to reply with carefully chosen words. The Chu army then withdrew.

sentences.zh: 十年，楚莊王圍鄭，鄭伯降，已而復之。

translations.literal: Tenth year, Chu Zhuang Wang besieged Zheng. Zheng Bo surrendered, then Chu restored him.
translations.idiomatic: In the tenth year, King Zhuang of Chu besieged Zheng. Duke Zheng surrendered, but Chu later restored him.

sentences.zh: 十六年，楚莊王卒。

translations.literal: Sixteenth year, Chu Zhuang Wang died.
translations.idiomatic: In the sixteenth year, King Zhuang of Chu passed away.

translations.literal: In King Ding's first year, King Zhuang of Chu attacked the Rong of Luhun. He halted at the Luo and sent someone to ask about the nine tripods. The king sent Wang Sun Man to respond with words. The Chu troops then left. In the tenth year, King Zhuang of Chu surrounded Zheng. The lord of Zheng surrendered, but he soon restored it. In the sixteenth year, King Zhuang of Chu died.

sentences.zh: 二十一年，定王崩，子簡王夷立。

translations.literal: Twenty-first year, King Ding passed away. Son King Jian Yi established.
translations.idiomatic: In the twenty-first year, King Ding died. His son King Jian Yi ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 簡王十三年，晉殺其君厲公，迎子周於周，立為悼公。

translations.literal: King Jian thirteenth year, Jin killed their lord Li Gong, welcomed Zi Zhou from Zhou, established as Dao Gong.
translations.idiomatic: In King Jian's thirteenth year, Jin assassinated their ruler Duke Li, retrieved Zi Zhou from Zhou, and enthroned him as Duke Dao.

translations.literal: In the twenty-first year, King Ding collapsed. His son King Jian Yi was established. In King Jian's thirteenth year, Jin killed their ruler Duke Li. They welcomed Zi Zhou from Zhou and established him as Duke Dao.

sentences.zh: 十四年，簡王崩，子靈王泄心立。

translations.literal: Fourteenth year, King Jian passed away. Son King Ling Xie Xin established.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourteenth year, King Jian died. His son King Ling Xie Xin ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 靈王二十四年，齊崔杼弒其君莊公。

translations.literal: King Ling twenty-fourth year, Qi Cui Zhu assassinated their lord Zhuang Gong.
translations.idiomatic: In King Ling's twenty-fourth year, Cui Zhu of Qi assassinated their ruler Duke Zhuang.

translations.literal: In the fourteenth year, King Jian collapsed. His son King Ling Xie Xin was established. In King Ling's twenty-fourth year, Cui Zhu of Qi assassinated their ruler Duke Zhuang.

sentences.zh: 二十七年，靈王崩，子景王貴立。

translations.literal: Twenty-seventh year, King Ling passed away. Son King Jing Gui established.
translations.idiomatic: In the twenty-seventh year, King Ling died. His son King Jing Gui ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 景王十八年，后太子聖而蚤卒。

translations.literal: King Jing eighteenth year, queen's crown prince Sheng died early.
translations.idiomatic: In King Jing's eighteenth year, the crown prince Sheng of the queen died prematurely.

sentences.zh: 二十年，景王愛子朝，欲立之，會崩，子丐之黨與爭立，國人立長子猛為王，子朝攻殺猛。

translations.literal: Twentieth year, King Jing loved son Zhao, wished to establish him. Met with passing away. Zi Kai's faction contended for establishment. State people established eldest son Meng as king. Zi Zhao attacked and killed Meng.
translations.idiomatic: In the twentieth year, King Jing favored his son Zhao and desired to enthrone him. He died unexpectedly. Zi Kai's faction disputed the succession. The people established the eldest son Meng as king. Zi Zhao attacked and killed Meng.

sentences.zh: 猛為悼王。

translations.literal: Meng was Dao Wang.
translations.idiomatic: Meng became King Dao.

sentences.zh: 晉人攻子朝而立丐，是為敬王。

translations.literal: Jin people attacked Zi Zhao and established Kai. He was called King Jing.
translations.idiomatic: The Jin attacked Zi Zhao and enthroned Kai. He became known as King Jing.

translations.literal: In the twenty-seventh year, King Ling collapsed. His son King Jing Gui was established. In King Jing's eighteenth year, the queen's crown prince Sheng died early. In the twentieth year, King Jing loved his son Zhao and wished to establish him. He happened to collapse. Zi Gai's faction contended for the establishment. The state people established the eldest son Meng as king. Zi Zhao attacked and killed Meng. Meng was King Dao. The Jin people attacked Zi Zhao and established Gai. He was King Jing.

sentences.zh: 敬王元年，晉人入敬王，子朝自立，敬王不得入，居澤。

translations.literal: King Jing first year, Jin people entered King Jing. Zi Zhao established himself. King Jing could not enter, resided at Ze.
translations.idiomatic: In King Jing's first year, the Jin installed King Jing. Zi Zhao enthroned himself. King Jing could not enter the capital and resided at Ze.

sentences.zh: 四年，晉率諸侯入敬王于周，子朝為臣，諸侯城周。

translations.literal: Fourth year, Jin led feudal lords entered King Jing into Zhou. Zi Zhao became minister. Feudal lords walled Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourth year, Jin led the lords to install King Jing in Zhou. Zi Zhao became a vassal. The lords fortified Zhou's walls.

sentences.zh: 十六年，子朝之徒復作亂，敬王奔于晉。

translations.literal: Sixteenth year, Zi Zhao's followers again made rebellion. King Jing fled to Jin.
translations.idiomatic: In the sixteenth year, Zi Zhao's partisans rebelled again. King Jing fled to Jin.

sentences.zh: 十七年，晉定公遂入敬王于周。

translations.literal: Seventeenth year, Jin Ding Gong then entered King Jing into Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: In the seventeenth year, Duke Ding of Jin restored King Jing to Zhou.

translations.literal: In King Jing's first year, the Jin people entered King Jing. Zi Zhao established himself. King Jing could not enter and resided at Ze. In the fourth year, Jin led the feudal lords to enter King Jing at Zhou. Zi Zhao became a minister. The feudal lords walled Zhou. In the sixteenth year, Zi Zhao's followers again made rebellion. King Jing fled to Jin. In the seventeenth year, Duke Ding of Jin then entered King Jing at Zhou.

sentences.zh: 三十九年，齊田常殺其君簡公。

translations.literal: Thirty-ninth year, Qi Tian Chang killed their lord Jian Gong.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirty-ninth year, Tian Chang of Qi assassinated their ruler Duke Jian.

translations.literal: In the thirty-ninth year, Tian Chang of Qi killed their ruler Duke Jian.

sentences.zh: 四十一年，楚滅陳。

translations.literal: Forty-first year, Chu extinguished Chen.
translations.idiomatic: In the forty-first year, Chu annihilated Chen.

sentences.zh: 孔子卒。

translations.literal: Kong Qiu died.
translations.idiomatic: Confucius passed away.

translations.literal: In the forty-first year, Chu extinguished Chen. Confucius died.

sentences.zh: 四十二年，敬王崩，子元王仁立。

translations.literal: Forty-second year, King Jing passed away. Son King Yuan Ren established.
translations.idiomatic: In the forty-second year, King Jing died. His son King Yuan Ren ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 元王八年，崩，子定王介立。

translations.literal: King Yuan eighth year, passed away. Son King Ding Jie established.
translations.idiomatic: In King Yuan's eighth year, he died. His son King Ding Jie ascended the throne.

translations.literal: In the forty-second year, King Jing collapsed. His son King Yuan Ren was established. In King Yuan's eighth year, he collapsed. His son King Ding Jie was established.

sentences.zh: 定王十六年，三晉滅智伯，分有其地。

translations.literal: King Ding sixteenth year, three Jin extinguished Zhi Bo, divided and possessed his lands.
translations.idiomatic: In King Ding's sixteenth year, the three Jin states destroyed Zhi Bo and divided his territories.

translations.literal: In King Ding's sixteenth year, the three Jin states extinguished Zhi Bo and divided up his territory.

sentences.zh: 二十八年，定王崩，長子去疾立，是為哀王。

translations.literal: Twenty-eighth year, King Ding passed away. Eldest son Qu Ji established. He was called King Ai.
translations.idiomatic: In the twenty-eighth year, King Ding died. His eldest son Qu Ji ascended. He became known as King Ai.

sentences.zh: 哀王立三月，弟叔襲殺哀王而自立，是為思王。

translations.literal: King Ai established three months. Younger brother Shu attacked and killed King Ai, established himself. He was called King Si.
translations.idiomatic: King Ai reigned three months. His younger brother Shu assassinated him and enthroned himself. He became known as King Si.

sentences.zh: 思王立五月，少弟嵬攻殺思王而自立，是為考王。

translations.literal: King Si established five months. Younger brother Wei attacked and killed King Si, established himself. He was called King Kao.
translations.idiomatic: King Si reigned five months. His youngest brother Wei assassinated him and enthroned himself. He became known as King Kao.

sentences.zh: 此三王皆定王之子。

translations.literal: These three kings all were King Ding's sons.
translations.idiomatic: All three of these kings were sons of King Ding.

translations.literal: In the twenty-eighth year, King Ding collapsed. His eldest son Qu Ji was established. He was King Ai. King Ai was established for three months. His younger brother Shu attacked and killed King Ai, then established himself. He was King Si. King Si was established for five months. His younger brother Wei attacked and killed King Si, then established himself. He was King Kao. These three kings were all sons of King Ding.

sentences.zh: 考王十五年，崩，子威烈王午立。

translations.literal: King Kao fifteenth year, passed away. Son King Wei Lie Wu established.
translations.idiomatic: In King Kao's fifteenth year, he died. His son King Wei Lie Wu ascended the throne.

translations.literal: In King Kao's fifteenth year, he collapsed. His son King Wei Lie Wu was established.

sentences.zh: 考王封其弟于河南，是為桓公，以續周公之官職。

translations.literal: King Kao enfeoffed his younger brother at Henan. He was called Huan Gong, to continue Zhou Gong's official duties.
translations.idiomatic: King Kao enfeoffed his younger brother at Henan. He became Duke Huan, to continue the Duke of Zhou's administrative functions.

sentences.zh: 桓公卒，子威公代立。

translations.literal: Duke Huan died. Son Duke Wei succeeded.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Huan passed away. His son Duke Wei succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 威公卒，子惠公代立，乃封其少子於鞏以奉王，號東周惠公。

translations.literal: Duke Wei died. Son Duke Hui succeeded. Then enfeoffed his youngest son at Gong to serve the king, called Eastern Zhou Hui Gong.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Wei died. His son Duke Hui succeeded him. He then enfeoffed his youngest son at Gong to attend the king, known as Duke Hui of Eastern Zhou.

translations.literal: King Kao enfeoffed his younger brother at Henan. He was Duke Huan, to continue the Zhou Gong's official duties. Duke Huan died. His son Duke Wei succeeded him. Duke Wei died. His son Duke Hui succeeded him. He then enfeoffed his youngest son at Gong to serve the king, giving him the title East Zhou Duke Hui.

sentences.zh: 威烈王二十三年，九鼎震。

translations.literal: King Wei Lie twenty-third year, nine tripods shook.
translations.idiomatic: In King Wei Lie's twenty-third year, the nine sacred tripods trembled.

sentences.zh: 命韓、魏、趙為諸侯。

translations.literal: Commanded Han, Wei, Zhao as feudal lords.
translations.idiomatic: He elevated Han, Wei, and Zhao to the status of regional lords.

translations.literal: In King Wei Lie's twenty-third year, the nine tripods shook. He commanded Han, Wei, and Zhao to be feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 二十四年，崩，子安王驕立。

translations.literal: Twenty-fourth year, passed away. Son King An Jiao established.
translations.idiomatic: In the twenty-fourth year, he died. His son King An Jiao ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 是歲盜殺楚聲王。

translations.literal: This year bandits killed Chu Sheng Wang.
translations.idiomatic: That same year, assassins killed King Sheng of Chu.

translations.literal: In the twenty-fourth year, he collapsed. His son King An Jiao was established. This year, bandits killed King Sheng of Chu.

sentences.zh: 安王立二十六年，崩，子烈王喜立。

translations.literal: King An established twenty-six years, passed away. Son King Lie Xi established.
translations.idiomatic: King An reigned twenty-six years, then died. His son King Lie Xi ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 烈王二年，周太史儋見秦獻公曰：「始周與秦國合而別，別五百載復合，合十七歲而霸王者出焉。」

translations.literal: King Lie second year, Zhou Grand Historian Dan saw Qin Xian Gong and said: 'Beginning Zhou and Qin states united then separated. Separated five hundred years then reunite. Reunite seventeen years and a hegemon king will emerge.'
translations.idiomatic: In King Lie's second year, the Zhou Grand Historian Dan met Duke Xian of Qin and declared: 'Originally Zhou and Qin were united then divided. After five hundred years of separation they will reunite. Seventeen years after reuniting, a hegemon king will arise.'

translations.literal: King An was established for twenty-six years. He collapsed. His son King Lie Xi was established. In King Lie's second year, Zhou's grand historian Dan saw Duke Xian of Qin and said: 'Originally Zhou and Qin were united then separated. Separated for five hundred years they reunite. United for seventeen years and a hegemon king will emerge.'

sentences.zh: 十年，烈王崩，弟扁立，是為顯王。

translations.literal: Tenth year, King Lie passed away. Younger brother Bian established. He was called King Xian.
translations.idiomatic: In the tenth year, King Lie died. His younger brother Bian ascended. He became known as King Xian.

sentences.zh: 顯王五年，賀秦獻公，獻公稱伯。

translations.literal: King Xian fifth year, congratulated Qin Xian Gong. Xian Gong called Bo.
translations.idiomatic: In King Xian's fifth year, he congratulated Duke Xian of Qin. Duke Xian assumed the title of Bo (hegemon).

sentences.zh: 九年，致文武胙於秦孝公。

translations.literal: Ninth year, presented Wen Wu zhu to Qin Xiao Gong.
translations.idiomatic: In the ninth year, he presented the sacrificial meats of Wen and Wu to Duke Xiao of Qin.

sentences.zh: 二十五年，秦會諸侯於周。

translations.literal: Twenty-fifth year, Qin assembled feudal lords at Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: In the twenty-fifth year, Qin convened the regional lords at Zhou.

sentences.zh: 二十六年，周致伯於秦孝公。

translations.literal: Twenty-sixth year, Zhou presented Bo to Qin Xiao Gong.
translations.idiomatic: In the twenty-sixth year, Zhou conferred the title of Bo upon Duke Xiao of Qin.

sentences.zh: 三十三年，賀秦惠王。

translations.literal: Thirty-third year, congratulated Qin Hui Wang.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirty-third year, he congratulated King Hui of Qin.

sentences.zh: 三十五年，致文武胙於秦惠王。

translations.literal: Thirty-fifth year, presented Wen Wu zhu to Qin Hui Wang.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirty-fifth year, he presented the sacrificial meats of Wen and Wu to King Hui of Qin.

sentences.zh: 四十四年，秦惠王稱王。

translations.literal: Forty-fourth year, Qin Hui Wang called wang.
translations.idiomatic: In the forty-fourth year, King Hui of Qin assumed the title of wang (king).

sentences.zh: 其後諸侯皆為王。

translations.literal: Thereafter feudal lords all became wang.
translations.idiomatic: Henceforth all the regional lords assumed the title of wang.

translations.literal: In the tenth year, King Lie collapsed. His younger brother Bian was established. He was King Xian. In King Xian's fifth year, he congratulated Duke Xian of Qin. Duke Xian called himself Bo. In the ninth year, he presented the Wen and Wu sacrifices to Duke Xiao of Qin. In the twenty-fifth year, Qin assembled the feudal lords at Zhou. In the twenty-sixth year, Zhou presented the title of Bo to Duke Xiao of Qin. In the thirty-third year, he congratulated King Hui of Qin. In the thirty-fifth year, he presented the Wen and Wu sacrifices to King Hui of Qin. In the forty-fourth year, King Hui of Qin called himself king. Afterwards, all the feudal lords became kings.

sentences.zh: 四十八年，顯王崩，子慎靚王定立。

translations.literal: Forty-eighth year, King Xian passed away. Son King Shenjing Ding established.
translations.idiomatic: In the forty-eighth year, King Xian died. His son King Shenjing Ding ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 慎靚王立六年，崩，子赧王延立。

translations.literal: King Shenjing established six years, passed away. Son King Nan Yan established.
translations.idiomatic: King Shenjing reigned six years, then died. His son King Nan Yan ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 王赧時東西周分治。

translations.literal: During King Nan's time, eastern and western Zhou separately governed.
translations.idiomatic: During King Nan's reign, Eastern and Western Zhou were governed separately.

sentences.zh: 王赧徙都西周。

translations.literal: King Nan moved capital to Western Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: King Nan relocated his capital to Western Zhou.

translations.literal: In the forty-eighth year, King Xian collapsed. His son King Shen Jing Ding was established. King Shen Jing was established for six years. He collapsed. His son King Nan Yan was established. In King Nan's time, east and west Zhou were governed separately. King Nan moved his capital to West Zhou.

sentences.zh: 西周武公之共太子死，有五庶子，毋適立。

translations.literal: Western Zhou Wu Gong's heir apparent died. Had five concubine sons. No legitimate to establish.
translations.idiomatic: The crown prince of Duke Wu of Western Zhou died. He had five sons by concubines. None was legitimate to succeed.

sentences.zh: 司馬翦謂楚王曰：「不如以地資公子咎，為請太子。」

translations.literal: Sima Jian told Chu Wang: 'Better to provide land to support Gongzi Jiu, to request crown prince for him.'
translations.idiomatic: Sima Jian counseled the King of Chu: 'It would be better to provide territories to support Prince Jiu, and petition to make him crown prince.'

sentences.zh: 左成曰：「不可。

translations.literal: Zuo Cheng said: 'Cannot.
translations.idiomatic: Zuo Cheng replied: 'This must not be done.

sentences.zh: 周不聽，是公之知困而交疏於周也。

translations.literal: Zhou will not listen. This is the duke knowing difficulty and relations becoming distant with Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: Zhou will not heed this. The duke foresees trouble and seeks to distance himself from Zhou.

sentences.zh: 不如請周君孰欲立，以微告翦，翦請令楚（賀）［資］之以地。」

translations.literal: Better to inquire which Zhou lord wishes to establish, secretly inform Jian, Jian will request to have Chu support with land.'
translations.idiomatic: It would be better to ascertain which Zhou lord desires the throne, then discreetly inform Jian. Jian can petition Chu to provide territories in support.'

sentences.zh: 果立公子咎為太子。

translations.literal: Indeed established Prince Jiu as crown prince.
translations.idiomatic: Indeed, Prince Jiu was established as crown prince.

translations.literal: West Zhou Duke Wu's crown prince died. He had five concubine sons. No proper heir was established. Si Ma Jian told the Chu king and said: 'Better to aid Gong Zi Jiu with land and petition for him to be crown prince.' Zuo Cheng said: 'Cannot. Zhou will not listen. This is the duke's wisdom in distress and relations distant with Zhou as well. Better to ask the Zhou ruler who he wishes to establish, subtly tell Jian, and Jian will petition to have Chu provide him with land.' Indeed Gong Zi Jiu was established as crown prince.

sentences.zh: 八年，秦攻宜陽，楚救之。

translations.literal: Eighth year, Qin attacked Yiyang, Chu rescued it.
translations.idiomatic: In the eighth year, Qin attacked Yiyang, and Chu came to its rescue.

sentences.zh: 而楚以周為秦故，將伐之。

translations.literal: But Chu because Zhou for Qin reason, will attack it.
translations.idiomatic: But Chu, holding Zhou responsible for Qin's actions, prepared to attack it.

sentences.zh: 蘇代為周說楚王曰：「何以周為秦之禍也？

translations.literal: Su Dai for Zhou persuaded Chu King said: 'Why make Zhou Qin calamity?
translations.idiomatic: Su Dai, acting for Zhou, persuaded the King of Chu: 'Why treat Zhou as Qin's accomplice?

sentences.zh: 言周之為秦甚於楚者，欲令周入秦也，故謂『周秦』也。

translations.literal: Speaking Zhou's serving Qin more than Chu, wishes to make Zhou enter Qin. Therefore call 'Zhou Qin'.
translations.idiomatic: Those who claim Zhou serves Qin more than Chu do so to force Zhou into Qin's camp. That's why they speak of 'Zhou and Qin' as allies.

sentences.zh: 周知其不可解，必入於秦，此為秦取周之精者也。

translations.literal: Zhou knows it cannot be resolved, must enter Qin. This is for Qin taking Zhou's essence.
translations.idiomatic: Zhou realizes the situation cannot be resolved and will have no choice but to join Qin. This serves Qin by draining Zhou's vital strength.

sentences.zh: 為王計者，周於秦因善之，不於秦亦言善之，以疏之於秦。

translations.literal: For king planning, Zhou at Qin then praise it, not at Qin also speak praise it, to distance it from Qin.
translations.idiomatic: The wisest course for Your Majesty is to praise Zhou whether it joins Qin or not, so as to drive a wedge between Zhou and Qin.

sentences.zh: 周絕於秦，必入於郢矣。」

translations.literal: Zhou cut off from Qin, must enter Ying.'
translations.idiomatic: If Zhou breaks with Qin, it will surely turn to Ying.'

translations.literal: In the eighth year, Qin attacked Yiyang. Chu rescued it. But Chu, because Zhou was on Qin's side, would attack it. Su Dai persuaded the Chu king for Zhou and said: 'Why consider Zhou to be Qin's disaster? They say Zhou is more valuable to Qin than to Chu. They wish to make Zhou enter Qin, so they call it 'Zhou Qin'. Zhou knew the alliance could not be broken. It would certainly enter Qin. This was the way for Qin to take Zhou's essence. For your majesty's plan: If Zhou is at Qin, then favor it. If not at Qin, also speak of favoring it, to distance it from Qin. If Zhou is cut off from Qin, it will certainly enter Ying.'

sentences.zh: 秦借道兩周之閒，將以伐韓，周恐借之畏於韓，不借畏於秦。

translations.literal: Qin requested passage between two Zhou, will use to attack Han. Zhou fears lending fears Han, not lending fears Qin.
translations.idiomatic: Qin requested passage through the territory between the two Zhou states to attack Han. Zhou feared that granting passage would offend Han, but refusing would provoke Qin.

sentences.zh: 史厭謂周君曰：「何不令人謂韓公叔曰『秦之敢絕周而伐韓者，信東周也。

translations.literal: Shi Yan told Zhou lord said: 'Why not have someone tell Han Gongshu said 'Qin's daring to cut off Zhou and attack Han, believes Eastern Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: Shi Yan advised the Zhou lord: 'Why not have someone tell Han Gongshu: "Qin's boldness in isolating Zhou to attack Han comes from trusting Eastern Zhou."

sentences.zh: 公何不與周地，發質使之楚』？

translations.literal: Lord why not give Zhou land, send hostage make it go to Chu?'
translations.idiomatic: Why not give Zhou some territory and send a hostage to force it to side with Chu?'

sentences.zh: 秦必疑楚不信周，是韓不伐也。

translations.literal: Qin must suspect Chu does not trust Zhou. This is Han not attacked.
translations.idiomatic: Qin will surely suspect Chu's distrust of Zhou. This means Han will not be attacked.

sentences.zh: 又謂秦曰『韓彊與周地，將以疑周於秦也，周不敢不受』。

translations.literal: Also tell Qin said 'Han strong gives Zhou land, will use to make Zhou suspicious of Qin, Zhou dares not not accept'.
translations.idiomatic: Also tell Qin: 'If Han gives Zhou land, it will sow suspicion between Zhou and Qin, and Zhou will not dare refuse.'

sentences.zh: 秦必無辭而令周不受，是受地於韓而聽於秦。」

translations.literal: Qin must without words make Zhou not accept. This is receiving land from Han but listening to Qin.'
translations.idiomatic: Qin will have no choice but to pressure Zhou not to accept, thus Han gains land from Qin while Zhou remains obedient to Qin.'

translations.literal: Qin borrowed a road between the two Zhou states. It would use it to attack Han. Zhou feared borrowing would offend Han, but not borrowing would offend Qin. Shi Yan told the Zhou ruler and said: 'Why not have someone tell Han Gong Shu that Qin dares to cut off Zhou and attack Han because it trusts East Zhou.' Why doesn't the duke give Zhou land and send a hostage to make it go to Chu?' Qin will certainly doubt Chu and not trust Zhou. This means Han will not be attacked. Also tell Qin that 'Han is strong and gave Zhou land. It would use this to make Qin doubt Zhou. Zhou would not dare not to receive it.' Qin will certainly have no excuse and make Zhou not receive it. This means receiving land from Han while listening to Qin.'

sentences.zh: 秦召西周君，西周君惡往，故令人謂韓王曰：「秦召西周君，將以使攻王之南陽也，王何不出兵於南陽？

translations.literal: Qin summoned Western Zhou lord. Western Zhou lord disliked going. Therefore had someone tell Han King said: 'Qin summons Western Zhou lord, will use to make attack Your Majesty's Nanyang. Your Majesty why not send troops to Nanyang?
translations.idiomatic: Qin summoned the Western Zhou lord, but he dreaded going. So he had someone tell the Han king: 'Qin is summoning the Western Zhou lord to use him in an attack on Your Majesty's Nanyang territory. Why not station troops in Nanyang?

sentences.zh: 周君將以為辭於秦。

translations.literal: Zhou lord will use as excuse toward Qin.
translations.idiomatic: The Zhou lord will use this as an excuse to defy Qin.

sentences.zh: 周君不入秦，秦必不敢踰河而攻南陽矣。」

translations.literal: Zhou lord not enter Qin, Qin must not dare cross river and attack Nanyang.'
translations.idiomatic: If the Zhou lord does not go to Qin, Qin will not dare cross the river to attack Nanyang.'

translations.literal: Qin summoned the West Zhou ruler. The West Zhou ruler hated to go, so he had someone tell the Han king: 'Qin has summoned the West Zhou ruler. It will use him to attack your South Yang. Why doesn't your majesty send troops to South Yang? The Zhou ruler would use this as an excuse with Qin. If the Zhou ruler does not enter Qin, Qin will certainly not dare cross the river and attack South Yang.'

sentences.zh: 東周與西周戰，韓救西周。

translations.literal: Eastern Zhou with Western Zhou fought, Han rescued Western Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: Eastern Zhou fought with Western Zhou, and Han came to Western Zhou's rescue.

sentences.zh: 或為東周說韓王曰：「西周故天子之國，多名器重寶。

translations.literal: Someone for Eastern Zhou persuaded Han King said: 'Western Zhou former Son of Heaven's state, many famous vessels heavy treasures.
translations.idiomatic: Someone acting for Eastern Zhou persuaded the Han king: 'Western Zhou was formerly the Son of Heaven's domain, rich in ceremonial vessels and precious treasures.

sentences.zh: 王案兵毋出，可以德東周，而西周之寶必可以盡矣。」

translations.literal: King hold troops do not send out, can favor Eastern Zhou, and Western Zhou's treasures must can exhaust.'
translations.idiomatic: If Your Majesty keeps your troops at home, you can win Eastern Zhou's gratitude while Western Zhou's treasures will surely be depleted.'

translations.literal: East Zhou fought with West Zhou. Han rescued West Zhou. Someone persuaded the Han king for East Zhou and said: 'West Zhou was formerly the Son of Heaven's country. It has many famous vessels and heavy treasures. If your majesty holds his troops and does not send them out, he can favor East Zhou, and West Zhou's treasures will certainly be exhausted.'

sentences.zh: 王赧謂成君。

translations.literal: King Nan called Cheng Jun.
translations.idiomatic: King Nan addressed Lord Cheng.

sentences.zh: 楚圍雍氏，韓徵甲與粟於東周，東周君恐，召蘇代而告之。

translations.literal: Chu besieged Yongshi. Han demanded armor and grain from Eastern Zhou. Eastern Zhou lord feared. Summoned Su Dai and told him.
translations.idiomatic: Chu besieged Yongshi. Han demanded armor and grain from Eastern Zhou. The Eastern Zhou lord, terrified, summoned Su Dai and informed him.

sentences.zh: 代曰：「君何患於是。

translations.literal: Dai said: 'Lord why worry about this.
translations.idiomatic: Dai replied: 'My lord, why worry about this?

sentences.zh: 臣能使韓毋徵甲與粟於周，又能為君得高都。」

translations.literal: Minister can make Han not demand armor and grain from Zhou, also can for lord obtain Gaodu.'
translations.idiomatic: I can prevent Han from demanding armor and grain from Zhou, and I can even secure Gaodu for you.'

sentences.zh: 周君曰：「子茍能，請以國聽子。」

translations.literal: Zhou lord said: 'You if can, please with state listen to you.'
translations.idiomatic: The Zhou lord said: 'If you can accomplish this, I will entrust the entire state to you.'

sentences.zh: 代見韓相國曰：「楚圍雍氏，期三月也，今五月不能拔，是楚病也。

translations.literal: Dai saw Han prime minister said: 'Chu besieges Yongshi, period three months. Now five months cannot capture, is Chu illness.
translations.idiomatic: Dai met with Han's prime minister and said: 'Chu has besieged Yongshi for three months now, but after five months still cannot capture it. This shows Chu is weakening.

sentences.zh: 今相國乃徵甲與粟於周，是告楚病也。」

translations.literal: Now prime minister moreover demands armor and grain from Zhou, is informing Chu illness.'
translations.idiomatic: Now if the prime minister demands armor and grain from Zhou, it will reveal Chu's weakness.'

sentences.zh: 韓相國曰：「善。

translations.literal: Han prime minister said: 'Good.
translations.idiomatic: The Han prime minister said: 'Excellent.

sentences.zh: 使者已行矣。」

translations.literal: Envoy already gone.'
translations.idiomatic: The envoy has already been dispatched.'

sentences.zh: 代曰：「何不與周高都？」

translations.literal: Dai said: 'Why not give Zhou Gaodu?'
translations.idiomatic: Dai suggested: 'Why not give Gaodu to Zhou?'

sentences.zh: 韓相國大怒曰：「吾毋徵甲與粟於周亦已多矣，何故與周高都也？」

translations.literal: Han prime minister greatly angered said: 'I not demand armor and grain from Zhou already too much, why moreover give Zhou Gaodu?'
translations.idiomatic: The Han prime minister flew into a rage: 'I've already done enough by not demanding armor and grain from Zhou. Why should I give them Gaodu?'

sentences.zh: 代曰：「與周高都，是周折而入於韓也，秦聞之必大怒忿周，即不通周使，是以獘高都得完周也。

translations.literal: Dai said: 'Give Zhou Gaodu, is Zhou bend and enter Han. Qin hears it must greatly anger resent Zhou, then not pass Zhou envoys, is with crippled Gaodu obtain preserve Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: Dai explained: 'Giving Gaodu to Zhou will force Zhou to submit to Han. When Qin hears of this, they will rage against Zhou and cut off their envoys. Thus with a weakened Gaodu, you preserve Zhou.'

sentences.zh: 曷為不與？」

translations.literal: Why not give?'
translations.idiomatic: Why not give it?'

sentences.zh: 相國曰：「善。」

translations.literal: Prime minister said: 'Good.'
translations.idiomatic: The prime minister agreed: 'Very well.'

sentences.zh: 果與周高都。

translations.literal: Indeed gave Zhou Gaodu.
translations.idiomatic: And so Gaodu was given to Zhou.

translations.literal: King Nan called Cheng Jun. Chu surrounded Yongshi. Han demanded armor and grain from East Zhou. The East Zhou ruler feared this, summoned Su Dai and told him. Dai said: 'Why does my lord worry about this? Your minister can make Han not demand armor and grain from Zhou, and can also get Gaodu for my lord.' The Zhou ruler said: 'If you can do this, I will listen to you regarding the state.' Dai saw the Han prime minister and said: 'Chu surrounds Yongshi. The period was three months, but now five months and it cannot be taken. This is Chu's weakness. Now the prime minister demands armor and grain from Zhou. This tells Chu of our weakness.' The Han prime minister said: 'Good. The messenger has already gone.' Dai said: 'Why not give Zhou Gaodu?' The Han prime minister was greatly angry and said: 'I am already not demanding armor and grain from Zhou—that is already too much. Why give Zhou Gaodu?' Dai said: 'Giving Zhou Gaodu means Zhou bends and enters Han. Qin will hear of it and certainly be greatly angry, resent Zhou, and cut off Zhou's envoys. This way, with crippled Gaodu we get a complete Zhou. Why not give it?' The prime minister said: 'Good.' Indeed gave Zhou Gaodu.

sentences.zh: 三十四年，蘇厲謂周君曰：「秦破韓、魏，撲師武，北取趙藺、離石者，皆白起也。

translations.literal: Thirty-fourth year, Su Li told Zhou lord said: 'Qin broke Han, Wei, captured Shi Wu, north took Zhao Lin, Lishi, all Bai Qi.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirty-fourth year, Su Li advised the Zhou lord: 'Qin defeated Han and Wei, captured Shi Wu, and took Lin and Lishi from Zhao in the north - all achieved by Bai Qi.

sentences.zh: 是善用兵，又有天命。

translations.literal: This is skilled at using troops, also has heavenly mandate.
translations.idiomatic: He is a master of warfare and enjoys heaven's favor.

sentences.zh: 今又將兵出塞攻梁，梁破則周危矣。

translations.literal: Now again will lead troops exit passes attack Liang. Liang broken then Zhou endangered.
translations.idiomatic: Now he is leading troops beyond the passes to attack Liang. If Liang falls, Zhou will be in grave danger.

sentences.zh: 君何不令人說白起乎？

translations.literal: Lord why not have someone persuade Bai Qi?
translations.idiomatic: Why not send someone to persuade Bai Qi?

sentences.zh: 曰『楚有養由基者，善射者也。

translations.literal: Say 'Chu has Yang Youji, good archer.
translations.idiomatic: Tell him: 'In Chu there was Yang Youji, a master archer.

sentences.zh: 去柳葉百步而射之，百發而百中之。

translations.literal: From willow leaf hundred paces shoot it, hundred shots hundred hit them.
translations.idiomatic: He could shoot willow leaves from a hundred paces away, hitting his target with every shot.

sentences.zh: 左右觀者數千人，皆曰善射。

translations.literal: Left and right observers several thousand people, all said good shooting.
translations.idiomatic: Thousands of spectators on all sides praised his skill.

sentences.zh: 有一夫立其旁，曰「善，可教射矣」。

translations.literal: Had one man stood by his side, said 'Good, can teach archery.'
translations.idiomatic: But one man standing nearby said: 'Excellent. Now you can be taught how to shoot.'

sentences.zh: 養由基怒，釋弓搤劍，曰「客安能教我射乎」？

translations.literal: Yang Youji angered, released bow grasped sword, said 'Guest how can teach me archery?'
translations.idiomatic: Yang Youji grew furious, dropped his bow and grasped his sword: 'How dare this stranger presume to teach me archery?'

sentences.zh: 客曰「非吾能教子支左詘右也。

translations.literal: Guest said 'Not I can teach you stretch left bend right.
translations.idiomatic: The stranger replied: 'I cannot teach you to draw the bow left or bend it right.

sentences.zh: 夫去柳葉百步而射之，百發而百中之，不以善息，少焉氣衰力倦，弓撥矢鉤，一發不中者，百發盡息」。

translations.literal: Man from willow leaf hundred paces shoot it, hundred shots hundred hit them, not with skill rest. Soon breath declines strength tires, bow warps arrow hooks, one shot not hit, hundred shots all lost.'
translations.idiomatic: You shoot willow leaves from a hundred paces with perfect accuracy every time. But if you do not rest after success, soon your breath will fail and strength tire. Your bow will warp, your arrows hook - one miss and all your previous shots are wasted.'

sentences.zh: 今破韓、魏，撲師武，北取趙藺、離石者，公之功多矣。

translations.literal: Now broke Han, Wei, captured Shi Wu, north took Zhao Lin, Lishi, duke's merit much.
translations.idiomatic: You have broken Han and Wei, captured Shi Wu, taken Lin and Lishi from Zhao - your achievements are already great.

sentences.zh: 今又將兵出塞，過兩周，倍韓，攻梁，一舉不得，前功盡棄。

translations.literal: Now again will lead troops exit passes, pass two Zhou, double Han, attack Liang, one effort not obtain, previous merit all abandon.
translations.idiomatic: Now you lead troops beyond the passes, through both Zhou states, past Han, to attack Liang. If this campaign fails, all your past victories will be lost.

sentences.zh: 公不如稱病而無出』。」

translations.literal: Duke better claim illness and not go out.'
translations.idiomatic: You would do better to feign illness and not undertake this campaign.'

translations.literal: In the thirty-fourth year, Su Li told the Zhou ruler and said: 'Qin broke Han and Wei, defeated Shi Wu, took Lin and Lishi from Zhao in the north—all this was Bai Qi.' He is good at using troops and also has the mandate of heaven. Now he will again lead troops out the border to attack Liang. If Liang is broken, then Zhou will be in danger. Why doesn't my lord have someone persuade Bai Qi? Say 'Chu has Yang Youji, who is a good archer. He shoots willow leaves from a hundred paces, a hundred shots a hundred hits. The observers on left and right, several thousand people, all said he was good at shooting. One man stood by his side and said 'Good, he can be taught shooting.' Yang Youji was angry. He released his bow and grasped his sword, saying 'How can a guest teach me shooting?' The guest said 'I cannot teach you to support left and bend right. Indeed, shooting willow leaves from a hundred paces, a hundred shots a hundred hits, without resting on the good, in a little time qi declines and strength tires, bow becomes crooked and arrow hooked, one shot misses and a hundred shots all come to rest.' Now breaking Han and Wei, defeating Shi Wu, taking Lin and Lishi from Zhao in the north—your merit is much already. Now you will again lead troops out the border, pass the two Zhou, double back on Han, attack Liang. If one move doesn't succeed, all previous merit will be abandoned. You would be better to claim illness and not go out.'

sentences.zh: 四十二年，秦破華陽約。

translations.literal: Forty-second year, Qin broke Huayang alliance.
translations.idiomatic: In the forty-second year, Qin shattered the Huayang alliance.

sentences.zh: 馬犯謂周君曰：「請令梁城周。」

translations.literal: Ma Fan told Zhou lord said: 'Please make Liang fortify Zhou.'
translations.idiomatic: Ma Fan advised the Zhou lord: 'Please have Liang fortify Zhou's defenses.'

sentences.zh: 乃謂梁王曰：「周王病若死，則犯必死矣。

translations.literal: Then told Liang king said: 'Zhou king illness if dies, then Fan must die.
translations.idiomatic: He then told the King of Liang: 'If the Zhou king dies of illness, then Fan will surely die.

sentences.zh: 犯請以九鼎自入於王，王受九鼎而圖犯。」

translations.literal: Fan requests with nine tripods myself enter to king. King receives nine tripods and plans against Fan.'
translations.idiomatic: Fan will personally deliver the nine tripods to the king. When the king accepts them, he can plot against Fan.'

sentences.zh: 梁王曰：「善。」

translations.literal: Liang king said: 'Good.'
translations.idiomatic: The King of Liang agreed: 'Excellent.'

sentences.zh: 遂與之卒，言戍周。

translations.literal: Then gave him troops, saying fortify Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: He then provided troops, ostensibly to garrison Zhou.

sentences.zh: 因謂秦王曰：「梁非戍周也，將伐周也。

translations.literal: Then told Qin king said: 'Liang not fortifying Zhou, will attack Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: He then told the King of Qin: 'Liang is not garrisoning Zhou - they intend to attack it.

sentences.zh: 王試出兵境以觀之。」

translations.literal: King try send troops to border to observe it.'
translations.idiomatic: Your Majesty should send troops to the border to observe the situation.'

sentences.zh: 秦果出兵。

translations.literal: Qin indeed sent troops.
translations.idiomatic: Qin indeed deployed troops.

sentences.zh: 又謂梁王曰：「周王病甚矣，犯請後可而復之。

translations.literal: Again told Liang king said: 'Zhou king illness severe, Fan requests later possible then return them.
translations.idiomatic: He then told the King of Liang: 'The Zhou king's illness is grave. Fan requests that when possible, return the troops.

sentences.zh: 今王使卒之周，諸侯皆生心，後舉事且不信。

translations.literal: Now king sends troops to Zhou, feudal lords all give birth to thoughts, later raise affairs moreover not trustworthy.
translations.idiomatic: Now that Your Majesty has sent troops to Zhou, the other lords are growing suspicious. Any future undertakings will lack credibility.

sentences.zh: 不若令卒為周城，以匿事端。」

translations.literal: Not if make troops fortify Zhou, to conceal affair beginnings.'
translations.idiomatic: It would be better to have the troops fortify Zhou to conceal our true intentions.'

sentences.zh: 梁王曰：「善。」

translations.literal: Liang king said: 'Good.'
translations.idiomatic: The King of Liang agreed: 'Very well.'

sentences.zh: 遂使城周。

translations.literal: Then caused fortify Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: He then had Zhou's defenses fortified.

translations.literal: In the forty-second year, Qin broke the Huayang alliance. Ma Fan told the Zhou ruler and said: 'Please have Liang wall Zhou.' Then he told the Liang king and said: 'If the Zhou king dies from illness, then Fan will certainly die. Fan requests to personally bring the nine tripods to the king. The king receives the nine tripods and plots against Fan.' The Liang king said: 'Good.' Then gave him troops, saying they would garrison Zhou. Then he told the Qin king and said: 'Liang is not garrisoning Zhou. It will attack Zhou. Your majesty, try sending troops to the border to observe it.' Qin indeed sent troops. Again he told the Liang king and said: 'The Zhou king's illness is severe. Fan requests to return it when it is later suitable. Now the king sends troops to Zhou. All the feudal lords will have thoughts. Later when raising affairs, it will moreover not be trusted. It would be better to have the troops wall Zhou, to hide the beginning of affairs.' The Liang king said: 'Good.' Then had them wall Zhou.

sentences.zh: 四十五年，周君之秦客謂周（最）［聚］曰：「公不若譽秦王之孝，因以應為太后養地，秦王必喜，是公有秦交。

translations.literal: Forty-fifth year, Zhou lord's Qin guest told Zhou Ju said: 'Lord not if praise Qin king's filial piety, by which Ying serves as dowager queen's support land. Qin king must be happy. This is lord has Qin relations.
translations.idiomatic: In the forty-fifth year, a Zhou envoy to Qin told Zhou Ju: 'My lord, you should praise the Qin king's filial devotion and offer Ying as land to support the dowager queen. The Qin king will be pleased, giving you influence in Qin.'

sentences.zh: 交善，周君必以為公功。

translations.literal: Relations good, Zhou lord must consider it lord's merit.
translations.idiomatic: If relations improve, the Zhou lord will credit you with the achievement.

sentences.zh: 交惡，勸周君入秦者必有罪矣。」

translations.literal: Relations bad, advise Zhou lord enter Qin, those must have crime.'
translations.idiomatic: If relations sour, those who advised the Zhou lord to ally with Qin will be blamed.'

sentences.zh: 秦攻周，而周聚謂秦王曰：「為王計者不攻周。

translations.literal: Qin attacked Zhou, but Zhou Ju told Qin king said: 'For king planning, not attack Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: Qin attacked Zhou, but Zhou Ju advised the Qin king: 'The wisest course for Your Majesty is not to attack Zhou.

sentences.zh: 攻周，實不足以利，聲畏天下。

translations.literal: Attack Zhou, substance not sufficient to benefit, reputation fears world.
translations.idiomatic: Attacking Zhou brings little real benefit, but creates a fearsome reputation worldwide.

sentences.zh: 天下以聲畏秦，必東合於齊。

translations.literal: World with reputation fears Qin, must east unite with Qi.
translations.idiomatic: The world, fearing Qin's reputation, will unite with Qi in the east.

sentences.zh: 兵獘於周。

translations.literal: Troops crippled at Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: Troops will be depleted fighting Zhou.

sentences.zh: 合天下於齊，則秦不王矣。

translations.literal: Unite world at Qi, then Qin not wang.
translations.idiomatic: Uniting the world under Qi means Qin will never achieve kingship.

sentences.zh: 天下欲獘秦，勸王攻周。

translations.literal: World desires cripple Qin, advises king attack Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: The world wishes to weaken Qin, which is why they urge Your Majesty to attack Zhou.

sentences.zh: 秦與天下獘，則令不行矣。」

translations.literal: Qin with world crippled, then commands not carried out.'
translations.idiomatic: If Qin fights the entire world, your commands will go unheeded.'

translations.literal: In the forty-fifth year, the Zhou ruler's Qin guest told Zhou Ju and said: 'You would be better to praise the Qin king's filial piety, and because of this give Ying as land to support the empress dowager. The Qin king will certainly be happy. This way you have Qin relations. If relations are good, the Zhou ruler will certainly take it as your merit. If relations are bad, those who advise the Zhou ruler to enter Qin will certainly have crime.' Qin attacked Zhou, but Zhou Ju told the Qin king and said: 'For your majesty's plan, do not attack Zhou. Attacking Zhou is not sufficient substance to profit, but reputation fears the world. The world, fearing Qin because of reputation, will certainly unite east at Qi. Troops will be crippled at Zhou. Uniting the world at Qi, then Qin will not become king. The world wishes to cripple Qin, so they advise the king to attack Zhou. If Qin is crippled with the world, then commands will not be carried out.'

sentences.zh: 五十八年，三晉距秦。

translations.literal: Fifty-eighth year, three Jin resisted Qin.
translations.idiomatic: In the fifty-eighth year, the three Jin states opposed Qin.

sentences.zh: 周令其相國之秦，以秦之輕也，還其行。

translations.literal: Zhou commanded its prime minister go to Qin, because Qin light regard, returned his journey.
translations.idiomatic: Zhou sent its prime minister to Qin, but Qin treated him with disdain, so he returned.

sentences.zh: 客謂相國曰：「秦之輕重未可知也。

translations.literal: Guest told prime minister said: 'Qin's light heavy not yet know.
translations.idiomatic: A guest advised the prime minister: 'We cannot yet know Qin's true intentions.

sentences.zh: 秦欲知三國之情。

translations.literal: Qin desires know three states' situation.
translations.idiomatic: Qin wishes to learn about the three states' conditions.

sentences.zh: 公不如急見秦王曰『請為王聽東方之變』，秦王必重公。

translations.literal: Lord not if hurry see Qin king said 'request for king listen eastern changes', Qin king must respect lord.
translations.idiomatic: You should urgently meet the Qin king and say: 'Allow me to monitor developments in the east for Your Majesty.' The Qin king will surely value you.

sentences.zh: 重公，是秦重周，周以取秦也；

translations.literal: Respect lord, this is Qin respect Zhou. Zhou thereby gains Qin;
translations.idiomatic: If they value you, Qin values Zhou, and Zhou gains influence over Qin;

sentences.zh: 齊重，則固有周聚以收齊：是周常不失重國之交也。」

translations.literal: Qi heavy, then originally has Zhou Ju to receive Qi: this is Zhou constantly not lose major states' relations.'
translations.idiomatic: If Qi gains power, Zhou Ju can still win them over. Thus Zhou maintains alliances with major powers.'

sentences.zh: 秦信周，發兵攻三晉。

translations.literal: Qin trusted Zhou, sent troops attacked three Jin.
translations.idiomatic: Qin, trusting Zhou, sent troops to attack the three Jin states.

translations.literal: In the fifty-eighth year, the three Jin states resisted Qin. Zhou ordered their prime minister to Qin. Because Qin was light, they returned his journey. The guest told the prime minister and said: 'Whether Qin is light or heavy is not yet known. Qin wishes to know the three states' situation. You would be better to quickly see the Qin king and say 'Please let me listen to the eastern changes for the king.' The Qin king will certainly value you. Valuing you means Qin values Zhou. Zhou thereby takes Qin; If Qi values, then originally Zhou Ju can receive Qi: this way Zhou constantly does not lose relations with heavy states.' Qin trusted Zhou and sent troops to attack the three Jin states.

sentences.zh: 五十九年，秦取韓陽城負黍，西周恐，倍秦，與諸侯約從，將天下銳師出伊闕攻秦，令秦無得通陽城。

translations.literal: Fifty-ninth year, Qin took Han Yangcheng Fushu. Western Zhou feared, betrayed Qin, with feudal lords allied together, led world elite troops out Yique attacked Qin, made Qin not able pass Yangcheng.
translations.idiomatic: In the fifty-ninth year, Qin captured Yangcheng and Fushu from Han. Western Zhou, terrified, betrayed Qin and allied with the other lords, leading the world's finest troops out of Yique Pass to attack Qin, blocking their access to Yangcheng.

sentences.zh: 秦昭王怒，使將軍摎攻西周。

translations.literal: Qin Zhao Wang angered, sent general Liu attack Western Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: King Zhao of Qin, enraged, sent General Liu to attack Western Zhou.

sentences.zh: 西周君犇秦，頓首受罪，盡獻其邑三十六，口三萬。

translations.literal: Western Zhou lord fled to Qin, knocked head accepted crime, completely offered his cities thirty-six, population thirty thousand.
translations.idiomatic: The Western Zhou lord fled to Qin, prostrated himself and admitted guilt, surrendering all thirty-six of his cities and thirty thousand subjects.

sentences.zh: 秦受其獻，歸其君於周。

translations.literal: Qin accepted his surrender, returned his lord to Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: Qin accepted the surrender and restored the lord to Zhou.

translations.literal: In the fifty-ninth year, Qin took Han's Yangcheng and Fushu. West Zhou feared, betrayed Qin, allied horizontally with the feudal lords, led the world's sharp troops out of Yique to attack Qin, making Qin unable to connect to Yangcheng. King Zhao of Qin was angry and sent General Liu to attack West Zhou. The West Zhou ruler fled to Qin, kowtowed and accepted his crime, completely offering his thirty-six cities and thirty thousand people. Qin accepted his offering and returned his ruler to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 周君、王赧卒，周民遂東亡。

translations.literal: Zhou lord, King Nan died. Zhou people then east fled.
translations.idiomatic: The Zhou lord and King Nan died. The Zhou people then fled eastward.

sentences.zh: 秦取九鼎寶器，而遷西周公於憚狐。

translations.literal: Qin took nine tripods precious vessels, and relocated Western Zhou Gong to Danhu.
translations.idiomatic: Qin seized the nine sacred tripods and precious vessels, relocating the Western Zhou duke to Danhu.

sentences.zh: 後七歲，秦莊襄王滅東（西）周。

translations.literal: After seven years, Qin Zhuang Xiang Wang extinguished Eastern Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: Seven years later, King Zhuang Xiang of Qin destroyed Eastern Zhou.

sentences.zh: 東西周皆入于秦，周既不祀。

translations.literal: Eastern and Western Zhou all entered Qin. Zhou already not sacrificed to.
translations.idiomatic: Both Eastern and Western Zhou fell to Qin. The Zhou sacrifices ceased.

translations.literal: The Zhou ruler King Nan died. The Zhou people then fled east. Qin took the nine tripods and precious vessels, and moved the West Zhou Gong to Danhu. After seven years, King Zhuang Xiang of Qin extinguished East Zhou. Both east and west Zhou entered Qin. Zhou then ceased to sacrifice.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：學者皆稱周伐紂，居洛邑，綜其實不然。

translations.literal: Grand Historian says: Scholars all say Zhou attacked Zhou, resided Luoyi. Comprehensively its substance not so.
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian remarks: Scholars all claim Zhou attacked Zhou and settled at Luoyi, but comprehensively this is not the case.

sentences.zh: 武王營之，成王使召公卜居，居九鼎焉，而周復都豐、鎬。

translations.literal: Wu Wang planned it. Cheng Wang made Duke Zhao divine residence, placed nine tripods there, but Zhou again capitaled Feng, Hao.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu planned it. King Cheng had Duke Zhao divine the site and placed the nine tripods there, but Zhou made its capital Feng and Hao once more.

sentences.zh: 至犬戎敗幽王，周乃東徙于洛邑。

translations.literal: Until Quanrong defeated King You, Zhou then east moved to Luoyi.
translations.idiomatic: Only when the Quanrong defeated King You did Zhou move eastward to Luoyi.

sentences.zh: 所謂「周公葬（我）［於］畢」，畢在鎬東南杜中。

translations.literal: So-called 'Duke of Zhou buried at Bi', Bi at Hao southeast Du middle.
translations.idiomatic: The saying 'the Duke of Zhou was buried at Bi' - Bi is in the middle of Du southeast of Hao.

sentences.zh: 秦滅周。

translations.literal: Qin extinguished Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: Qin destroyed Zhou.

sentences.zh: 漢興九十有餘載，天子將封泰山，東巡狩至河南，求周苗裔，封其後嘉三十里地，號曰周子南君，比列侯，以奉其先祭祀。

translations.literal: Han rose ninety remaining years. Son of Heaven will seal Mount Tai, east inspect hunt to Henan, seek Zhou descendants, enfeoff their descendant Jia thirty li land, called Zhou Zi Nan Jun, compared to marquises, to serve their ancestors' sacrifices.
translations.idiomatic: The Han dynasty arose ninety years later. The Son of Heaven, about to perform the Feng sacrifice on Mount Tai, traveled east on inspection to Henan. He sought Zhou descendants and enfeoffed their descendant Jia with thirty li of land, titled Zhou Zi Nan Jun, ranking as a marquis, to maintain their ancestral sacrifices.

translations.literal: The Grand Historian says: Scholars all say Zhou attacked Zhou and resided in Luoyi, but comprehensively this is actually not so. King Wu planned it. King Cheng had the Duke of Shao divine the residence and placed the nine tripods there. But Zhou again made its capital Feng and Hao. Until the Quanrong defeated King You, Zhou then moved east to Luoyi. What is called 'the Duke of Zhou was buried at Bi'—Bi is in the middle of Du southeast of Hao. Qin extinguished Zhou. The Han rose for ninety remaining years. The Son of Heaven would seal Mount Tai, and on his eastern inspection reached Henan. He sought Zhou descendants and enfeoffed their descendant Jia with thirty li of land, titling him Zhou Zi Nan Jun, equal to marquises, to serve their ancestors' sacrifices.
